This species has been taken at depths up to at least 150 meters in the sea. Unverified records indicate presence up to several miles offshore in California and Alaska (USFWS 1994). In estuaries this fish usually is found in the middle or bottom of the water column (Moyle 2002). Adults in lakes occupy deep water by day, move upward in water at night (Wydoski and Whitney 2003). Spawning occurs in fresh water, over sandy-gravel substrates, rocks, and aquatic plants (Moyle 2002). Anadromous populations spawn in fresh water close to the ocean. After hatching, larvae move up into surface waters and are transported downstream into brackish-water nursery areas. Lake populations spawn in tributaries (Wydoski and Whitney 2003).
threats:
Localized threats exist, but on a range-wide scale no major threats are known. 


Threats have been defined only in areas of known declines in the California portion of the range. Declines in the Sacramento-San Joaquin estuary in California are due mainly to the effects of water diversions from the Delta (Moyle 2002). Low flows result in upstream movement of the productive freshwater-saltwater mixing zone, constricting the size of favorable habitat and making the fishes vulnerable to diversion into water project pumps and structures (U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service 1994). It is unlikely that many individuals survive entrainment, but the degree of effect on larvae is not well known (Moyle et al. 1995). Low flows also fail to disperse larvae downstream into productive nursery areas in Suisun Bay (U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service 1994, Moyle et al. 1995). The causes for decline in the northern California estuaries are unknown but probably similar to the causes for declines in the Sacramento-San Joaquin estuary (Moyle et al. 1995, Moyle 2002).

Other potential threats include pesticide runoff from agricultural areas and invasions by exotic species such as clams and copepods (Moyle et al. 1995, Moyle 2002). Sedimentation due to human activities may also have an effect on northern California estuaries. The loss of tidal marsh habitat and resulting reduced productivity, together with reduced flows in the Mad River due to water diversions and land reclamation, may have caused disappearance from Humboldt Bay, California. Due to a two-year life cycle, relatively brief periods of reproductive failure could lead to extirpations (U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service 1994).
population:
This species is represented by at least a couple dozen subpopulations (counting each estuary as a single occurrence or subpopulation).

Total adult population size is unknown but presumably exceeds 100,000. This species may be common in Willapa Bay, Skagit Bay, and Puget Sound in Washington and in Coos Bay and Yaquina Bay in Oregon; it is evidently common to highly abundant in the Columbia River and Grays Harbor, Washington. In Alaska, large numbers are found in the Gulf of Alaska (U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service 1994).

Declines are well documented in California, but there is a lack of trend information for most of the remainder of the range, where populations are generally considered common or abundant (U. S. Fish and Wildlife Service 1994). In the San Francisco Estuary this species historically exhibited wide fluctuations in abundance that paralleled variations in rainfall (lowest abundance during drought years) (Moyle 2002). In California, the species has declined dramatically since the early 1980s in the Sacramento-San Joaquin estuary (Moyle 2002) and has apparently disappeared from Humboldt Bay. In the 1970s this fish was considered abundant in Humboldt Bay, California, but since 1983 numbers have plummeted. Despite extensive sampling it has not been collected from Humboldt Bay since 1994. The remaining California populations are small and of uncertain status (Moyle et al. 1995, Moyle 2002).

Current trends are not well documented in most of the range, but extent of occurrence, area of occupancy, and number of subpopulations probably are relatively stable or declining at a rate of less than 10 percent over 10 years.
range: Range extends along the Pacific coast of North America from the Sacramento-San Joaquin estuary and Monterey Bay (single record), California, north to the southwestern Gulf of Alaska (westward beyond Prince William Sound to the base of the Alaska Peninsula), Alaska; landlocked populations occurs in Harrison Lake, British Columbia, and lakes Washington and Union, Washington (Page and Burr 1991, Moyle 2002, Wydoski and Whitney 2003). Range includes Willapa Bay, Skagit Bay, Columbia River, Grays Harbor, and Puget Sound in Washington; Coos Bay and Yaquina Bay in Oregon; Fraser River estuary and near Prince Rupert and Vancouver in British Columbia; Dixon Entrance, Yakutat Bay, Prince William Sound, and Cook Inlet in Alaska, Klamath River mouth (few confirmed records), Humboldt Bay (large decline, extirpated?), Eel River mouth (little suitable habitat, no recent records), Van Duzen River in Eel River drainage, Russian River estuary, San Francisco Bay-Sacramento-San Joaquin estuary, and the Gulf of the Farallones in California (U. S. Fish and Wildlife Service 1994, Moyle et al. 1995, Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Moyle 2002, Wydoski and Whitney 2003).
conservationActions: Currently, this species is of relatively low conservation concern in most of the range and does not require significant additional protection or major management, monitoring, or research action.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of the large extent of occurrence, large number of subpopulations, and large population size. Trend over the past 10 years or three generations is uncertain; species may be declining but probably not fast enough to qualify for any of the threatened categories under Criterion A (reduction in population size).
habitat: Nearshore ocean bottom, coastal inlets. Adults live at moderate sea depths (commonly 20-200 m but have been recorded as deep as 625 m) in echo-sounding layer not far from shore; young apparently occur in deeper water (Lee et al. 1980, Page and Burr 1991, Willson et al. 2003). Spawns in coastal freshwater streams over bottoms of silt, sand, gravel, cobble or detritus but apparently prefer bar and riffle habitat containing sand or pea-gravel, seldom more than a few miles inland (Estes and Vincent-Lang 1984, Willson et al. 2003). Presence of spring freshets is a factor common to nearly all spawning streams or rivers; typically characteristic of rivers that drain large snowpacks or glaciers (Hay and McCarter 2000, Willson et al. 2003).
threats:
Threatened by overfishing in subsistence and commercial fisheries, continued/increased bycatch in commercial groundfish and shrimp fisheries, industry pollution of freshwater and marine habitats, human impact on spawning habitat (logging, dredging, diversions, etc.) and climate change (Hay and McCarter 2000).

Subsistence harvest is widespread throughout this species' range, is mostly unregulated, and could potentially slow recovery of declining populations. Bycatch of eulachon in commercial offshore groundfish and shrimp trawl fisheries may be substantial; shrimp trawling, especially, has increased in the last decade (Hay and McCarter 2000).

Threats to eulachon habitat include diversions/dams, logging, dredging and industrial pollution of streams and rivers, all of which may affect water volume, temperature and sediment levels in spawning habitat. Native communities in Southeast Alaska have noted declining eulachon harvests and expressed concern about the effects of log rafting and pollution on fish habitat (Drake and Wilson 1991).

Recent changes in ocean climate, including increased surface water temperatures, have been recognized in the Gulf of Alaska and elsewhere in the species range, and have resulted in a general reorganization of fish communities in some areas (Anderson and Piatt 1999, Hay and McCarter 2000). High water temperatures can be lethal to cold-water acclimated fish. A study of 5°C-acclimated eulachon immersed in 11°C water for several days resulted in 50% mortality and spawning failure (Blahm and McConnell 1971 in Willson et al. 2003).
population:
This species is represented by a large number of subpopulations and locations.

In Alaska, this species is seasonally abundant from Southeast to Cook Inlet (Hay et al. 1997); abundance decreases from east to west toward the Aleutian Islands (Bartlett 1994). Relative abundance in the Bering Sea is highest between Unimak Island/end of the Alaska Peninsula and the Pribilof Islands (Anderson, in Willson et al. 2003). Eulachon is reported as widespread in trawl samples in the coastal fjords of northern southeast Alaska (Willson et al. 2003). Catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) in the Gulf of Alaska varied almost cyclically between 1972 and 1997 from ~0.3 kg/km to ~1.9 kg/km (Anderson and Piatt 1999). However, catch data are not necessarily considered a reliable measure of population abundance or even presence/absence (NMFS 1999), nor are they available for species' entire range in the state.

Highly variable or possibly cyclical run size makes trends in abundance hard to interpret (NMFS 1999). Nearly all runs in the southern part of their range (California to BC) have declined during the last 20 years (Hay and McCarter 2000). Commercial catches on the Fraser River have declined since the 1940s and 1950s (Hay et al. 1997). In 1994, sudden drastic declines were recorded in three large southern rivers, the Fraser, Columbia, and Klinaklini, resulting in the closure of major commercial fisheries on the Fraser and Columbia Rivers in the late 1990s (Hay and McCarter 2000, Willson et al. 2003). Due to continued low abundance, NMFS was petitioned to list the Columbia River populations as endangered or threatened under the Endangered Species Act (ESA) in 1999. Eulachon runs diminished over the last two decades in the Kitimat River, BC, and became chemically tainted as a result of industry and urbanization (Hay et al. 1997, Hay and McCarter 2000).

Trend over the past 10 years or three generations is uncertain but likely relatively stable or slowly declining.
range: Found only in the eastern Pacific, from Monterey Bay, California, to Nushagak River and Pribilof Islands, Bering Sea, Alaska (Lee et al. 1980, Page and Burr 1991). Distribution coincides closely with coastal temperate rainforest, although there may not be a functional linkage (Hay and McCarter 2000). Historically spawned in the Sacramento River system and farther south along the California and Baja California coast but have been extirpated from those locations, occurring now only as far south as Monterey Bay (one record from this location) and in the Klamath River in California, rivers in Oregon and the Columbia River in Washington (Hay and McCarter 2000, Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Willson et al. 2003). In Alaska, seasonally abundant in most major drainages from Southeast Alaska west to Cook Inlet and become less abundant westward toward the Aleutian Islands and the Pribilof Islands in the Bering Sea (Fritz et al. 1993, Willson et al. 2003).
conservationActions:
Conservation needs: continued protection of spawning habitat through restricted dredging and management of logging and industrial water pollution; limitation of bycatch in commercial shrimp fisheries by conducting catch-monitoring assessments and mandating area closures when bycatch limits are reached; require use of fishery observers and selectivity devices which allow passive exit of bycatch species through escape panels (i.e., the Nordmore grid).

In British Columbia, shrimp trawl fisheries are required to use bycatch reduction devices (BRDs) and to close shrimp fishing when bycatch limits of eulachon and other non-target species are reached, even if shrimp catch is below the allowable quota (Hay and McCarter 2000). In the U.S., the Magnuson-Stevens Act requires NMFS to reduce non-targeted bycatch in commercial fisheries, but currently there are few BRD requirements to shrimp fisheries in the Pacific Northwest.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of the large extent of occurrence, large number of subpopulations, large population size, and lack of major threats. Trend over the past 10 years or three generations is uncertain but likely relatively stable, or the species may be declining but not fast enough to qualify for any of the threatened categories under Criterion A (reduction in population size).
habitat: Cool quiet waters of ponds, lakes, estuaries, and streams; usually in shallow vegetated areas, sometimes in open water over sand. In lakes, may occupy deep water in winter, shallows in summer. Marine populations occur near shore. Spawns in fresh water; estuarine populations move into creeks and streams to spawn. Eggs laid in nest made by male among rocks or plants.
threats: Localized threats may exist, but on a range-wide scale no major threats are known.
population:
This species is represented by a large number of subpopulations and locations.

Total adult population size is unknown but relatively large.

Trend over the past 10 years or three generations is uncertain but likely relatively stable or slowly declining.
range: Arctic and Atlantic drainages across Canada and Alaska and south to New Jersey; Pacific coast of Alaska; Great Lakes basin; Eurasia (Page and Burr 1991). North American and Palearctic populations were regarded as specifically distinct by Haglund et al. (1992).
conservationActions: Currently, this species is of relatively low conservation concern and does not require significant additional protection or major management, monitoring, or research action.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern in view of the large extent of occurrence, large number of subpopulations, large population size, and lack of major threats. Trend over the past 10 years or three generations is uncertain but likely to be relatively stable, or the species may be declining but not fast enough to qualify for any of the threatened categories under Criterion A (reduction in population size).
habitat: Shallow coastal waters, bays, estuaries, or lower reaches of rivers in salinities of 0-34 ppt; most commonly on sand bottom; ranges to depths of about 90 m. Adults usually inhabit lower estuaries; young found in fresh water in rivers and smaller streams, and in upper and lower estuaries. Most spawning probably occurs in bays and estuaries with relatively stable salinities (Morrow 1980). Hatchlings move into fresh water in spring, move down into estuaries in summer.
threats: Localized threats may exist, but on a range-wide scale no major threats are known.
population:
This species is represented by a large number of subpopulations and locations.

Total adult population size is unknown but relatively large.

Trend over the past 10 years or three generations is uncertain but likely to be relatively stable or slowly declining.
range: Range extends from San Quintin Bay, Baja California, northward to Kodiak Island and west to Izembek Lagoon, on the southeastern Bering Sea coast of Alaska.
conservationActions: Currently, this species is of relatively low conservation concern and does not require significant additional protection or major management, monitoring, or research action.

rationale: Lagocephalus lagocephalus is found in the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans, in tropical and subtropical waters. It has been reported to depths of 1,000 m. It appears to be abundant in some parts of its range. This species is primarily oceanic, but may occasionally enter estuaries. There are no confirmed species-specific threats to L. lagocephalus. Its distribution overlaps with marine protected areas. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Lagocephalus lagocephalus is a benthopelagic, oceanodromous species that occurs in subtropical waters between depths of 10 to 1,000 m, but is usually found between 10 and 100 m (Palomares et al. 1989, Anon 2001, Shipp 2002, Riede 2004). It is primarily oceanic, but may occasionally enter estuaries (Eschmeyer et al. 1983, Smith and Heemstra 1986, Schneider 1990). This species feeds on crustaceans and squids (Tortonese 1986). Maximum total length for this species is 61.0 cm male/unsexed (Eschmeyer et al. 1983), maximum published weight is 3.2 kg (IGFA 2001).

Puffers of the genus Lagocephalus are globally distributed in warm shallow waters, however classification at the species level in Lagocephalus has not yet been studied in depth, causing confusion in the status of several species including L. cheesemanii, L. gloveri, L. spadiceus and L. wheeleri (Matsuura et al. 2011).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats: This species is taken as bycatch and incidental catch throughout its range. In the Persian Gulf, this species is taken as bycatch in the shrimping industry. It is also taken as bycatch in long-line fisheries (Pajuelo et al. 2010).
population:
Juveniles are commonly collected by trawl surveys conducted in western Hong Kong waters (M. Liu pers. comm. 2011). Specimens of L. lagocephalus appear to be common in museum collections, however, it is important to note that many specimens are identified at the subspecies level. Lagocephalus lagocephalus is well represented in collections worldwide, having 133 occurrences (FishNet2 retrieved 13 March 2014).

There are no other species-specific data concerning the population of L. lagocephalus in the Gulf of Mexico.
range:
Lagocephalus lagocephalus is found in the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans, in tropical and subtropical waters. In the western Atlantic, it is found in Newfoundland, Canada and southward to Brazil (Figueiredo and Menezes 2000). In the eastern Atlantic, it is found from Orkney Island and the Azores and southward to South Africa (but very rare in the north), it is also in the Mediterranean (Tortonese 1986). In the eastern Pacific, this species occurs from southern California to Chile (Accessed through the Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.org, 2014-05-27).

The western Pacific/Indo-Pacific populations of this species were previously considered a subspecies Lagocephalus lagocephalus oceanicus, while those in the Atlantic were previously considered the subspecies Lagocephalus lagocephalus lagocephalus. Individuals have been collected from depths of 476 m.
useTrade: There is little species-specific use and trade information for L. lagocephalus. In the Persian Gulf, Lagocephalus lagocephalus is of commercial importance to the fisheries industry as a gamefish (Froese and Pauly 2011). Lagocephalus lagocephalus is harvested by small-scale artisanal fisheries in parts of its range (Denadai et al. 2012). In Senegal, this species and Lagocephalus laevigatus are the most commonly consumed tetraodontids in households, and are often prepared in rice-based dishes (Fall et al. 2013).
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for Lagocephalus lagocephalus. There are several marine protected areas within its wide distribution.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This epi- to mesopelagic species is found in the open ocean and over continental shelves and slopes (Moteki and Nagasawa 1998). Its maximum total length is 50 cm (Thompson 2002).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: This species is considered to be uncommon to rare (Paulin 1981, Stewart et al. 2015).
range: This species has a circumglobal anti-equatorial distribution in temperate latitudes between 70°N to 40°S (Mundy 2005). In the eastern Pacific, it occurs from Kodiak Island, Alaska in the USA to southern California (Kells et al. 2016) and off Chile (Last and Moteki 1999). In the western Pacific, it occurs from Japan, Taiwan, the Philippines, southern Australia and New Zealand (Mundy 2005). It also occurs on the Hancock Seamount north of Hawaii (Mundy 2005). In the Indian Ocean, it occurs off South Africa and Madagascar (Last and Moteki 1999, Fricke et al. 2018). In the eastern Atlantic, it occurs off Iceland and northern Norway to Madeira (Bañón et al. 2016) and a record west of the Cape Verde Islands (FishNet2 database accessed October 2018). In the western Atlantic, it occurs from northeastern Canada to south Florida in the USA. Its depth range is 0-1,000 metres (Stewart et al. 2015, Kells et al. 2016).
useTrade: This species is not directly targeted, but is occasionally taken as bycatch in longline and vertical linefisheries in the western central Atlantic (Thompson 2002) and the Hawaii-based pelagic longline fishery for swordfish and tuna (Patrick et al. 2010). It also comprises a very small portion of the bycatch in the pelagic fleet from the European Union targeting Trachurus murphyi (Corten and Janusz 2011). It is also taken in gill nets and bottom trawls in the eastern Pacific (Kells et al. 2016).
conservationActions: Taractes asper is a highly migratory species that is included in Annex I of the 1982 Convention on the Law of the Sea created by the United Nations Convention of the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). Responsibility is given to coastal states to determine the proper management and use of fishery resources within their national jurisdiction (the territorial sea, which can extend up to 12 nautical miles offshore). Under Annex I, coastal states and other states that fish where there is a presence of highly migratory species are to ensure the conservation and optimum utilization of listed species (Garcia 1994, Malak et al. 2011).

rationale: Arctozenus risso is a wide-ranging species, is not utilized and has no known major threats. Therefore, A. risso is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Arctozenus risso is oceanic, epipelagic to bathypelagic, and feeds on fishes and shrimps. It occurs singly or in small schools (Post 1984). It is hermaphroditic and oviparous with planktonic larvae (Richards 2006). It spawns at continental slopes and oceanic banks (Cherel and Duhamel 2003). The maximum total length (TL) is 31 cm (Thompson 2002).
threats: There are no known major threats to Arctozenus risso. However, it is caught as bycatch in deep-water fisheries in some areas.
population: Population information is very limited for Arctozenus risso.
range: This species occurs from the Arctic to Antarctic. In the northeastern Pacific, it is found from British Columbia, Canada south to Guadalupe Island, Mexico. In the southeastern Pacific, it occurs in Chile. In the western Atlantic, it occurs from Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada south to Georgia, Florida, the Bahamas, and the Lesser Antilles (Richards 2006). Specifically in the Greater Caribbean, it occurs from southeastern Florida, Northwest Providence Channel (the Bahamas) and the Lesser Antilles. In the eastern Atlantic, it is known from Norway to Portugal. In the northwestern Pacific, it occurs in Iwate, Japan south to the Philippines. In the southwestern Pacific, it is known from New South Wales, Australia to Tasmania (Distribution inferred from records of A. risso on Fishnet2.net, 2012). It is found at depths between zero to 2,000 m (Richards 2006).
useTrade: Arctozenus risso is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Arctozenus risso.

rationale: The Cape Fathead occurs circumglobal in tropical and temperate waters of all oceans. It is not common and life history information is very limited. This species is used in minor commercial fisheries and is a good quality fish. It is mostly a deep-dwelling species. It is captured incidentally and utilized, but this is not considered a significant threat. It is listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Cubiceps capensis can reach 100 cm in length and feeds primarily on salps (Gorelova et al. 1994, Haedrich 2002). Juveniles tend to occur in uppers surface waters while adults occur in deep water (Haedrich 2002). It is thought to be a pelagic, mesopelagic and epibenthic deep-water fish of warm and temperate seas. Often this fish is known to frequent submarine canyons by day, but are thought to come towards the surface at night (Haedrich 1990).

Larvae occur in plankton. Juveniles and mature fish often associate with loose but usually very large schools, frequently associating with a pelagic medusa or floating object like boxes or barrels (Haedrich 2002).

They most commonly feed on jelly fish, crustaceans, salps and small fishes (Haedrich 2002).
threats: There is no special fishery for ruffs anywhere in the western central Atlantic, but specimens are caught occasionally by sports fishermen and are highly esteemed for food in some places (Haedrich 2002). However, there are only minor fisheries that actively fish for this species, and separate catch rate statistics for this species are not available. There are no other known threats towards this species.
population: Although it is circumglobal in all tropical and subtropical waters of all oceans, it is rarely seen (Haedrich 2002). This species is known to be rare (Ahlstrom et al. 1976). There are 52 occurrence records and 14 museum records (lots typically contain single specimens, although some have up to four) for C. capensis (Froese and Pauly 2011, www.fishnet2.net 2012). There are limited data on the population structure and density of this fish.
range: Cubiceps capensis is circumglobal in tropical and temperate seas from 40°N to 35°S (Haedrich 2002, Haedrich in press). In the South Pacific, C. capensis is a temperate water species (Ahlstrom et al. 1976). In the eastern Atlantic, this species occur off South Africa as well as in the tropical Pacific (Butler 1979). It is also known from the Mediterranean with a few sightings reported (Heemstra 1995). It is generally a pelagic-oceanic species (Reide 2004) but has been found as deep as 140 m (Parin and Piotrovsky 2004).
useTrade: There is no fishery for Nomeidae species in the western central Atlantic (Haedrich 2002). Cubiceps capensis is caught occasionally by sports fishermen, is used in minor commercial fishing and is an excellent food fish (Froese and Pauly 2011).
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation efforts in place for Cubiceps capensis.

rationale: Holtbyrnia innesi occurs in the temperate and tropical Atlantic and Pacific. It is a bathypelagic species but has been reported to occur at depths of 100 m to 1,500 m (Quero et al. 1990). Current threats to this species are unknown. This species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: The maximum length for Holtbyrnia innesi is 24 cm standard length (Carter 2002).
threats: Current threats to Holtbyrnia innesi are unknown.
population: There are 47 occurrence and five museum records for Holtbyrnia innesi (Froese and Pauly 2011, Fishnet2 2012).
range:
Holtbyrnia innesi occurs in temperate and tropical Atlantic and Pacific (Carter 2002). This species has been recorded from 32°02'N, 78°59'W in the western North Atlantic, and 4°43'S, 26°39'W and 5°58'S, 26°52'W in the tropical Atlantic. This species has been reported in coastal west Africa in the Gulf of Guinea and Angola (Froese and Pauly 2011). There are also reports of this species from the southeastern Atlantic to Angola (Sazonov and Trunov 1978), off Peru in the eastern South Pacific (Sazonov 1976), the Bering Sea and the central North Pacific (Matsui and Rosenblatt 1987), as well as the northeastern and northwestern Pacific. This species has also been reported from the Gulf of Mexico (Texas Cooperative Wildlife Collection (TCWC) - Ichthyology Specimens, Tulane University Museum of Natural History - Royal D. Suttkus Fish Collection- www.fishnet2.net, 2012). It has been found at 58°N, which is the northernmost record of a platytroctid in the Pacific (Matsui and Rosenblatt 1987). 

The depth range for this species is 100-1,500 m (Quero et al. 1990).
useTrade: Platytroctids are of little importance to fisheries (Bianchi et al. 1999).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts in place for Holtbyrnia innesi.

rationale: Bathophilus brevis is found in the tropical to temperate Atlantic and central Pacific. This species is not utilized and there are no known major threats. There are no conservation actions in place for this species. More research is needed regarding the population size and trend, habitats, ecology, life history, use/trade and threats for B. brevis. It is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: More data are currently needed regarding the life history of this species. Bathophilus brevis is a meso- to bathypelagic species (Moore et al. 2003).
threats: There are no known species-specific threats faced by Bathophilus brevis. More research is needed to verify that there are no threats.
population: It is not known whether there is substantial immigration/emigration from outside the Eastern Central Atlantic that will significantly affect subpopulations in the region.
range: In the Atlantic Ocean, Bathophilus brevis is found in the tropical to temperate waters (Harold in press). It the western Atlantic, it is found from northern Florida to Cape Hatteras (United States of America) and to Bermuda, as well as one specimen being found between Toms and Hudson Canyons in the western Atlantic (Moore et al. 2003). In the eastern Atlantic, this species is known from the Canary Islands and south of the Azores (MCZ and NHM London museum and occurrence records), as well as from Gambia and Cape Verde south to off eastern Brazil and Ascension Island and to Namibia and South Africa (Gibbs and Barnett 1990). In the Pacific Ocean, this species is known from Hawaii (Mundy 2005, NMNH Smithsonian museum records) and the California Current Region (Moser 1996) as well as off Chile (Pequeño 1989). The depth preference for B. brevis is from 75 to 1,650 m (Mundy 2005).
useTrade: There is currently no information regarding the use and/or trade of Bathophilus brevis. More research is needed to determine its commercial value to humans.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Bathophilus brevis. More research is needed regarding the population size and trend, habitats, ecology, life history, uses/trade and threats for B. brevis.

rationale: This species is circum-globally distributed. There is no use and trade information available for this species. This species is caught as bycatch in several fisheries; however, this is not a major threat. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: The diet of Chauliodus sloani seems to consist only of fishes (Appelbaum 1982) and it feeds mainly on myctophids (Scott and Scott 1988). It is a prey item of the commercially important Orange Roughy (Williams et al. 2001). The maximum standard length 35.0 cm (SL; Masuda et al. 1984). It is oviparous (Scott and Scott 1988).
threats: This species is caught as bycatch of deep-sea shrimp trawlers off the southwest coast of India (Pillai et al. 2009). Chauliodus sloani is also sometimes caught as bycatch in the Chilean crustacean trawl fishery (Queirolo et al. 2011). In the Balearic Islands in the western Mediterranean, C. sloani is caught as bycatch and discarded from deep-sea crustacean fisheries (Moranta et al. 2000).
population: There is no population information.
range:
This fish has a circumglobal range. It mainly occurs in warm and temperate areas, but with several distribution gaps in the southern central Atlantic, northern Indian Ocean, eastern Pacific north of the equator, western Mediterranean, South China Sea and East China Sea (Jawad et al. 2013). It is also found on the western Gulf of Mexico (Sutton and Hopkins 1996), north central Gulf of Mexico (Ross et al. 2010), the coast of Somalia (Butler et al. 2001), western Mediterranean (Whitehead et al. 1984), Sedlo Seamount in the northeast central Atlantic Ocean (Menezes et al. 2012) and Columbian Caribbean Sea (Paramo et al. 2012). One specimen was observed during a remotely operated underwater vehicle (ROV) dive off of Grand Banks, Newfoundland (Baker et al. 2012). It can also be found North Carolina and Virginia continental slopes (Gartner et al. 2008), the Scotian Shelf off of Canada (Shackell and Frank 2003), Arabian Sea coasts of Oman (Jawad et al. 2013), South China Sea (Randall and Lim 2000), around Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands (Suntsov and Domokos 2013) and the southern coast of Tasmania (Williams et al. 2001).

This species is bathypelagic, with a depth range of 200-4,700 m (Yang et al. 1996). It is most commonly found at 494-1,000 m (Shinohara et al. 1994). In the Ionian Sea, the species occurs at depths of  473-1,192 m (Mytilineou et al. 2005). In the Sargasso Sea, the species is found at around 1,000 m depth (Sutton et al. 2010). In the Columbian Caribbean Sea it is found at depths from 396-430 m (Paramo et al. 2012).
useTrade: Chauliodus sloani is not currently utilized as a commercial species.
conservationActions: There are currently no active efforts to conserve or protect this species.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This mesopelagic species migrates vertically to near the surface at night (Sutton and Hopkins 1996). Its maximum length is 21 cm (Harold 2016).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: This species is absent or rare in central water masses at latitudes between approximately 20°-30°N or S (Clarke 2000). It is rare in New Zealand waters (Kenaley and Stewart 2015).
range: This species has been recorded from widely scattered localities in subtropical to temperate waters of the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, including the Gulf of Mexico (Sutton and Hopkins 1996), eastern Australia and the Tasman Sea (OZAM database accessed August 2018), the Colville Ridge north of New Zealand (Kenaley and Stewart 2015, Harold 2016), the Hawaiian Islands (Mundy 2005) and the Canary Islands (Weinerroither et al. 2009). Specimens have been collected at depths between 0-1,300 metres (T. Harold and R. Milligan pers. comm. 2018).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: Malacosteus niger is a circumglobal species, inhabiting all waters from tropical to subarctic. There is no use and trade information available for this species. There are no species-specific threats to this species. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Malacosteus niger exhibits unique ecological characteristics in comparison with other Stomiiformes. It is believed to be the only member of the family that does not undergo diel, vertical migrations, and only occasionally moves up the water column into the lower epipelagic zone (Clarke 1974, Kenaley 2007).

Diet analysis of M. niger indicates that copepods comprise a major component of this species' diet, with only a small amount of other micronekton components. Copepods account for 83% of prey numbers and 47% of prey biomass, as indicated by intestinal contents of samples taken (Sutton and Hopkins 1996). These data are singular in that Malacosteus niger represents an extreme departure in stomiid feeding. This species has the largest gape of any stomiid (Sutton unpublished data), and lacks gill rakers as an adult, indicating that larger, micronekton would more probably be the preferred dietary choice for this species. The large gape and lack of gillrakers as an adult while feeding on copepods may indicate a secondary reversion to planktivory (Sutton and Hopkins 1996). This seeming discrepancy is explained in that the ingestion of copepods provides M. niger with the raw material needed for long-wave visual sensitivity, while at mesopelagic depths, eliminating the need to undergo DVM (Douglas et al. 1999). Kenaley and Sutton (unpublished data) posed that when the nutritional state of an individual deteriorates after prolonged "snacking'' on copepods, it may be stimulated to revert to piscivory and utilize this stealthy visual mechanism in the epipelagic zone where high densities of teleost prey aggregate on a diel cycle.

In a study conducted in 1970-1971 near the island of Oahu, Hawaii, it was determined that M. niger shows no seasonality in reproduction. Possibly the larvae of M. niger, which exhibit no seasonality, either hatch at a larger size or live at greater depths than those of the seasonal species and thus the former's spawning is not timed to any seasonal fluctuations in food concentration or size distribution in the upper layers (Clarke 1974).
threats: There are no known threats towards this species.
population: There are 500 records of this specimen in 453 geocodes. The largest number of specimens taken in a single lot was 22, which was collected off Newfoundland near the Grand Banks in 1968 (Fishnet2 2013). In a study conducted around the seamounts of the Azores archipelago in 2002, 9.7x10-5 percent of the total haul was M. niger (Melo and Menezes). In 1974, this species was considered to be "fairly abundant" in a study conducted near Oahu, Hawaii in 1970-1971 (Clarke 1974).
range: Malacosteus niger is a circumglobal species, inhabiting all waters from tropical to subarctic (Harold 1999). Specifically, it is found from Arctic latitudes at 66°N. to approximately 30°S. in the southern hemisphere. It is not known to occur in the Mediterranean Sea (Kenaley 2007). This species is widely distributed in the Eastern Central Atlantic (OBIS 2014).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are currently no know conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is mesopelagic (Mundy 2005). The largest specimen measured 23 cm standard length (Harold 2016). This species is probably a vertical migrator (T. Harold and R. Milligan pers. comm. 2018).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: Population data are limited for this species. There are 44 occurrence records of this species, with most lots containing between 1-4 individuals in the FishNet2 database (accessed September 2018); however, one collection taken from Suriname in 1969 contains 14 individuals, and one collection taken from French Guiana in 1969 contains 11 individuals.
range: This species has a circumglobal distribution in the tropical and subtropical waters (Mundy 2005). It is known from the Gulf of Mexico, Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans (Mundy 2005). In the eastern Atlantic, it is known from the Azores, Portugal and Spain to Western Sahara, and the Mid-Atlantic Ridge (Gibbs and Barnett 1990, Sutton et al. 2008). In the western Atlantic, it occurs in the Gulf of Mexico (McEachran and Fechhelm 1998) and the Caribbean Sea to Suriname (Regan and Trewavas 1930, Uyeno et al. 1983, Gibbs and Barnett 1990). In the Indian Ocean, it is known from Indonesia (Gloerfelt-Tarp and Kailola 1984, Mundy 2005), and in the Pacific Ocean, it is known from Australia, New Guinea and central Japan east to the Emperor Seamounts (Mundy 2005). Specimens have been taken at depths between 530-945 metres (Uyeno et al. 1983) and from the surface to 800 m (T. Harold and R. Milligan pers. comm. 2018).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This species is found in tropical to temperate zones in the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans. There is no use and trade information available for this species. There are no species-specific threats to this species. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Neonesthes capensis is mesopelagic as an adult. However, some adults have also been associated with benthic environments. Juveniles have been caught at the surface at night. Its diet consists mainly of other mesopelagic fishes and crustaceans (Harold 2002).
threats: There are no known threats towards this species. However, more research on the ecology and life history of this specie is needed in order to be certain that there are not specific threats towards this species.
population: There are 88 records of this species worldwide in 85 geocodes. In 1971, four individuals were taken in one sampling in the Gulf Coast off Louisiana at a depth of 622 m (Fishnet2 Portal 2012).
range: This species is found in tropical to temperate zones in the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans (Harold in press). Neonesthes capensis is found in the eastern Atlantic, from southern Portugal to Mauritania and from Namibia to South Africa. In the western Atlantic, it is found in the waters off the USA southward to the Gulf of Mexico, including the western Caribbean, and from Brazil to Argentina. In the Indian Ocean, it is mostly found around 25°S, It has also been reported in the Arabian Sea. In the Pacific Ocean, it is mostly found south of 25°S. Neonesthes capensis is in the waters near Hawaii, as well as off the western USA (Gibbs 1990).This species of fish is most often found from 70-1,650 m (Mundy 2005). However, N. capensis is most often found deeper than 500 m during the day (Gibbs 1984). In a study published in 2007, it was reported that N. capensis had been found off the coast of Greenland, further to the north than ever reported before in the Atlantic. This northward shift is purportedly due to the warming of the Atlantic waters (Pedchenko and Dolgov 2007).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are currently no known conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: Photonectes margarita is distributed in tropical to temperate North Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific Oceans, as well as from off the Cape Verde Islands and a record from about 17°S and 6°W. There is no use and trade information available for this species. There are no species-specific threats to this species. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: The maximum standard length for this species is 39.6 cm (Gibbs and Barnett 1990). Based on general information on the subfamily Melanostomiinae, the diet probably consists mainly of other mesopelagic fishes and some crustaceans (Harold 2002). This species exhibits vertical migrations (Sutton and Hopkins 1996).
threats: Current threats to Photonectes margarita are unknown.
population: There are 182 museum records in place for Photonectes margarita, all of which consist of three or less individuals (fishnet2 2013). This species has been described as rare (Sutton and Hopkins 1996).
range: Photonectes margarita is distributed in tropical to temperate North Atlantic, Indian and Pacific oceans (Harold in press). In the Eastern Central Atlantic, this species is found from off the Cape Verde Islands and a record from about 17°S and 6°W (Fishnet2 2013).
useTrade: Use and trade information is not available for this species.
conservationActions: There are not any species specific conservation efforts in place for Photonectes margarita. However, the distribution for this species overlaps with a number of marine protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2014).

rationale: Stomias brevibarbatus occurs from subtropical to temperate waters in the North Atlantic Ocean. There is no use and trade information available for this species. There are no species-specific threats to this species. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: The maximum size for this species is 20 cm. Based on general information on the subfamily Stomiinae, the diet probably consists mainly of other mesopelagic fishes and some crustaceans (Harold in press).
threats: Current threats to Stomias brevibarbatus are unknown.
population: There are 259 museum records for Stomias brevibarbatus with a single record consisting of 27 individuals (Fishnet2 Portal 2013).
range: Stomias brevibarbatus occurs from subtropical to temperate waters in the North Atlantic Ocean (Harold in press), with one record from the Cape Verde Islands in the Eastern Central Atlantic (OBIS 2007). The depth range for this species is zero to 500 m (Scott and Scott 1988).
useTrade: Use and trade information is not available for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation efforts in place for Stomias brevibarbatus. However, the distribution for this species overlaps with a number of marine protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2014).

rationale: Desmodema polystictum is circumglobally distributed in the mesopelagic zone. It is a rare, deep-dwelling species that is not utilized and has no major threats. This species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Desmodema polystictum is a deepsea fish with a maximum size of approximately 100 cm that inhabits the mesopelagic zone. It feeds on pelagic crustaceans, small fishes and squids. The eggs are free-floating, large and red. Juveniles swim at the surface while trailing elongate dorsal and pelvic fin rays that give them the appearance of a jellyfish. Data on the reproduction and habits of this species are limited (Olney in press). Vakily et al. (2002) describe D. polystictum as bathypelagic with a maximum size of 110 cm TL off of West Africa.
threats: There are no known major threats to Desmodema polystictum.
population: Desmodema polystictum is a rarely occurring species (Olney in press).
range:
Desmodema polystictum is distributed circumglobally in tropical and temperate regions in the mesopelagic zone (Olney in press). Vakily et al. (a study by FishBase on West African fishes; 2002) report D. polystictum as distributed off of Senegal, Gambia, Guinea-Bissau, Guinea and Sierra Leone. It also occurs in Angola (Fishnet2 2013).

In the Western North Atlantic it is distributed from southern New England near Wilmington Canyon (38°15'N, 73°42'W) and south of Veatch Canyon (39°13'N, 69°35'W) south to North Carolina, northeastern Florida, the Gulf of Mexico and Cuba (Moore et al. 2003). 

Near Hawaii, this species has been recorded from the Hancock Seamounts. It also ranges in the Indian and Pacific Oceans from zero to 500 m depth (Mundy 2005). It is considered rare off of Japan, but has occurred from Kushiro south to Kochi Prefecture and Yamaguchi Prefecture (Nakabo 2002). It has also been collected off of India (Zacharia and Kannan 2012).
useTrade: Desmodema polystictum is not utilized (Olney in press).
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures for Desmodema polystictum.

rationale: Anoplogaster cornuta is a circumglobally distributed, deep-dwelling, uncommon species with no known threats. It is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Anoplogaster cornuta is a deep-sea species that inhabits the mesopelagic and bathypelagic zones. It has a maximum size of 16 cm SL. Juveniles feed on crustaceans, while adults feed on fishes. This species may swim in small groups at times (Moore in press). Off of Hawaii, this species is found between 135 m to 980 m depth at night and migrates to deeper water between 650 m to 2,915 m during the day (Mundy 2005). It is reportedly a common prey item of the Longnose Lancetfish, Alepisaurus ferox (Fujita and Hattori 1976). Larval size for A. cornuta have been reported as follows: 3.9mm preflexion, 4.7mm to 9.1mm SL postflexion, and a 15.7mm SL juvenile (Konishi 1999).
threats: There are no known major threats to Anoplogaster cornuta.
population: Anoplogaster cornuta is an uncommon deep-sea fish (Moore in press).
range: Anoplogaster cornuta is distributed circumglobally in tropical and temperate regions from 75 m to 5,000 m depth (Moore in press). It is distributed between 46°N and 46°S in all oceans (Maurin and Quero 1982). In the eastern Atlantic, this species is known from Greenland and Iceland south to South Africa. There have also been descriptions from the Faroe Islands east to western Norway. In the Western North Atlantic it is distributed from 640 m to 4,900 m depth, in the New England region as well as from Greenland south to the Caribbean and the Gulf of Mexico (Moore et al. 2003). In the southwestern Pacific this species has been recorded from 500 m to 2,000 m depth off of New Caledonia and New Zealand (Fricke et al. 2011). This species also ranges from Hawaii Island to the Hancock Seamounts from 135 m to 2,915 m depth. Elsewhere, it ranges between 63°N-45°S in the Gulf of Mexico, Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans from 75 m to 4,992 m depth (usually between 135 m to 2,000 m; Mundy 2005). Off of Japan, this species has occurred from Tohoku District and Hokkaido (Nakabo 2002). It has also been recorded from the Sea of Okhotsk, in southeastern Sakhalin, Russia at 47°37′ N, 144°22′ E (Balanov and Kharin 2009).
useTrade: Anoplogaster cornuta is not utilized (Moore in press).
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures for Anoplogaster cornuta.

rationale: Barbourisia rufa is circumglobally distributed. It is a deep-dwelling, uncommon species that has no major threats. This species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Barbourisa rufa grows to a maximum length of 38 cm but is more commonly found at 30 cm long. Although feeding habits are unknown, they most likely eat crustaceans (Moore in press). Juveniles are mesopelagic. Their larvae measure 3.7–14.1mm NL/SL and notochord flexion occurs between 6.5 and 7.5mm SL (Paxton et al. 2001).
threats: There are no known major threats to Barbourisia rufa.
population: This is a rare deep-sea species, of which more than 60 specimens have been caught (Moore in press) but with little more than 100 specimens identified. Off of the African coast, eight records have occurred from the Canary Islands, as well as a number from western South Africa. It can be assumed that this species has a potentially small population (Paxton in press).
range: Barbourisia rufa can be found from 25° to 35°S off western South Africa and circumglobally, in the Atlantic from 65°N to 35°S, the Indian Ocean from 5° to 20°S, and the Pacific from 50°N to 50°S (Paxton in press, Bianchi et al. 1999). Juveniles are mesopelagic and adults are often benthopelagic (deeper than 1,000 m; Moore in press). Barbourisia rufa is distributed from 300-2,000 m depth off of Africa from the Canary Islands to 5°S, 5°W and 25° to 35°S off western South Africa. Specimens have not been recorded between the Canary Islands and South Africa, but the possibility for their occurrence is likely. In the Western North Atlantic it is distributed from 12-2,000 m depth (mostly greater than 600 m) from Greenland south to northern South America, the Caribbean, and the Gulf of Mexico (Moore et al. 2003). It has also been found in the Indian and Pacific Oceans (Uyeno et al. 1983). In the southwestern Pacific this species has been recorded from 120–2,000 m depth off of New Caledonia (Fricke et al. 2011). This species has been recorded off of Hawaii from 750-800 m depth (Vetter et al. 2010). This species has occurred off of Japan from southeast Hokkaido, the Pacific coast of Tohoku District, Okinawa Trough, and the Kurile Islands (Nakabo 2002).
useTrade: Barbourisia rufa is not utilized (Paxton in press).
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures for Barbourisia rufa.

rationale: Caulophyrne polynema is widely distributed in the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans where it is known from only 14 confirmed specimens. It is a deep-dwelling, meso-bathypelagic, rarely occurring species. It possibly occurs as bycatch in trawl fisheries, but is not utilized and has no major threats.It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Caulophyrne polynema is a deep-sea fish that inhabits the mesopelagic and bathypelagic zones. It exhibits extreme sexual dimorphism. Females have a maximum size of 14.2 cm SL, while males are 1.6 cm SL. Females attract prey with an elongate first dorsal spine that has been modified as a lure. Males have highly developed sensory organs that allow them to find females at which point they will attach themselves to the body as a parasite that eventually becomes incorporated into the female's tissues and blood vessels (Pietsch in press). Vakily et al. (2002) describe C. polynema as bathypelagic with a maximum size of 2 cm SL off of West Africa.
threats: There are no known major threats to Caulophyrne polynema.
population: Caulophyrne polynema is a solitary species that does not occur abundantly (Pietsch in press). There are at least 14 known specimens of this species (Pietsch 2009).
range: Caulophyrne polynema is distributed in the mesopelagic and bathypelagic zones of the eastern Atlantic and northeastern Pacific (Pietsch in press). It is known from widely scattered localities. In the Atlantic it ranges from Florida east to Madeira and south to Cape Verde, The Democratic Republic of the Congo and Namibia as far south as 28 degrees South. It has also been identified from Iceland. In the eastern Pacific it has been collected off of the Hawaiian Islands and southern California and Baja. Specimens were taken by gear fishing between 585-2,000 m depth (Pietsch 2009). The holotype was captured off of Madeira by long line in deep water (Pietsch 2009). This species has been recorded off of Oahu at zero to 1,150 m depth (Mundy 2005). Vakily et al. (a study by FishBase on West African fishes; 2002) reports C. polynema as distributed off the Cape Verde Islands.
useTrade: Caulophyrne polynema is not utilized (Pietsch in press). This species may be caught in trawls off of Namibia (Bianchi et al. 1999).
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures in place for Caulophyrne polynema.

rationale: Ceratias holboelli is circumglobally distributed in meso-bathypelagic zones where it does not occur abundantly. It may occur as bycatch in trawl fisheries, but is not utilized and has no major threats. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Ceratias holboelli is a deep-sea fish that inhabit the mesopelagic and bathypelagic zones. It exhibits extreme sexual dimorphism. Females have a maximum size of 77 cm (SL), while males are 14.5 cm (SL). Females attract prey with an elongate first dorsal spine that has been modified as a lure (Bertelsen 1990). Males have highly developed sensory organs that allow them to find females at which point they will attach themselves to the body as a parasite that eventually becomes incorporated into the female's tissues and blood vessels (Pietsch in press). Females are oviparous and larvae are planktonic (Watson 1996). This species spawns in gelatinous rafts that float to upper water column (zero to 200 m; Pietsch 2009). Information regarding the diet, spawning season, fecundity and early life history is limited for this species.
threats: There are no known major threats to Ceratias holboelli. However, this species may be incidentally and infrequently caught in trawls off of Namibia (Bianchi et al. 1999).
population: Ceratias holboelli is a solitary species that does not occur abundantly (Pietsch in press). There are 161 female specimens and 19 male specimens currently known (Pietsch 2009).
range: Ceratias holboelli is broadly distributed circumglobally in the mesopelagic and bathypelagic zones (Pietsch in press). In the western Atlantic, it is found off Brazil. In the Pacific, it is known from southern Tasmania, New Zealand, New South Wales and the Coral and Celebes seas, the Bismarck Archipelago and Solomon Islands, as well as off Taiwan, Japan, the Bering Sea, Aleutian Islands, Oregon and California, the Hawaiian Islands, and east to the Peru-Chile Trench at 24° S and 72° W. In the Indian Ocean, it is known from Durban, South Africa and the Arabian Sea. It appears to be excluded from the Southern Ocean (Pietsch 2009). In the northeastern Atlantic it ranges from Iceland (about 68° N and south to about 8° S) in the central Atlantic (Pietsch 2009). The depth range can be between 150 and 3,400 m; however, it is most commonly captured between 400 and 2,000 m (Pietsch 2009).
useTrade: Ceratias holboelli is not utilized (Pietsch in press).
conservationActions:
There are no known conservation measures for Ceratias holboelli. Its range intersects with numerous marine protected areas, although because of the depth stratification of this species, it is unknown if it actually resides within the protected area's boundaries. Research into the taxonomy, population size and structure, as well as the early life history of this species, is needed.
.

rationale: Cryptopsaras couesii is circumglobally distributed in meso-bathypelagic zones where it does not occur abundantly. It may occur as bycatch in trawl fisheries, but is not utilized and has no major threats. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Cryptopsaras couesii is a deep-sea fish that inhabit the mesopelagic and bathypelagic zones. It exhibits extreme sexual dimorphism. Females have a maximum size of 35.8 cm SL, while males are 9.9 cm SL. Females attract prey with an elongate first dorsal spine that has been modified as a lure. Males have highly developed sensory organs that allow them to find females at which point they will attach themselves to the body as a parasite that eventually becomes incorporated into the female's tissues and blood vessels (Pietsch in press). Larvae range in size from 2.5-15 mm TL (Pietsch 2009).
threats: There are no known major threats to Cryptopsaras couesii.
population: Cryptopsaras couesii is a solitary species that does not occur abundantly (Pietsch in press). There are 983 female specimens, and 74 parasitic and 100 free-living male specimens currently known (Pietsch 2009).
range: Cryptopsaras couesii is distributed circumglobally in the mesopelagic and bathypelagic zones (Pietsch in press). In the Atlantic it ranges from Iceland and southern Greenland south to the Gulf of Mexico and Caribbean Sea to the African coast including the Central Atlantic Water Mass as far south as the tip of South Africa (40 degrees south). In the Pacific it ranges throughout Indonesian waters, north to Japan, and south to Australia, Tasmania, and New Zealand continuing further east in the central Pacific between 35 degrees North and 30 degrees South, to Hawaii, Washington, Oregon and California, south to Chile. It is known throughout the Indian Ocean mostly the western side, but also Sumatra, Java and western Australia. The depth range is 75-4,000 m, however, most often between 500-1,250 m (Pietsch 2009). On Bonaparte Seamount (15°40'S, 6°55'W, 130 km west of Saint Helena Island), this species was collected from the stomach of a tuna (Edwards 1993). The northernmost occurrence in the western Pacific is the Kuril Islands off Russia (41°05′6′′N–151°03′9′'E; Kharin and Milovankin 2007).
useTrade: Cryptopsaras couesii is not utilized (Pietsch in press). This species may be caught in trawls off of Namibia (Bianchi et al. 1999).
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures for Cryptopsaras couesii.

rationale: Linophryne pennibarbata is widely distributed in both eastern and western coasts of the northern Atlantic, central North Pacific and Hawaii where it occurs in depths from 325-1,500 m. There is limited information on the population status of this species. It is presently known only from 11 museum specimens collected from the Atlantic and central Pacific. In the Eastern Central Atlantic it is known from one record off of Cape Verde. It is a deep-dwelling meso-bathypelagic species that is not utilized and has no major threats. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Females of Linophryne pennibarbata have a maximum size of 4.7 cm SL and males are unknown. Linophrynids are deep-sea anglerfishes that inhabit the mesopelagic and bathypelagic zones. They exhibit extreme sexual dimorphism. Females attract prey with an elongate first dorsal spine that has been modified as a lure. Males have highly developed sensory organs that allow them to find females at which point they will attach themselves to the body as a parasite that eventually becomes incorporated into the female's tissues and blood vessels (Pietsch in press). Vakily et al. (2002) describe L. pennibarbata as bathypelagic with a maximum size of 5 cm SL off of West Africa.
threats: There are no known major threats to Linophryne pennibarbata.
population: Linophryne pennibarbata is known from at least 11 female specimens (Pietsch 2009).
range: Linophryne pennibarbata is known from the western North Atlantic off the coast of Florida from 325-425 m depth. In the eastern North Atlantic it is known from 910-1,500 m depth. In the central North Pacific it is known from 750-1,150 m depth near Hawaii (Pietsch 2009, Mundy 2005). Vakily et al. (a study by FishBase on West African fishes; 2002) report L. pennibarbata as distributed off the Cape Verde Islands. This species does not appear to have been captured off of West Africa.
useTrade: Linophryne pennibarbata and Linophrynids in general are not utilized (Pietsch in press).
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures for Linophryne pennibarbata.

rationale: Melanocetus johnsonii is circumglobally distributed in the meso-bathypelagic zones. It is a rare, deep-dwelling species. It may occur as bycatch in trawl fisheries, but it is not utilized and there are no major threats. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Melanocetus johnsonii females have a maximum size of 15.4 cm SL, while males are up to 2.8 cm (Pietsch 2009). Melanocetids are deep-sea fishes that inhabit the mesopelagic and bathypelagic zones. They exhibit extreme sexual dimorphism. Females attract prey with an elongate first dorsal spine that has been modified as a lure. Males have highly developed sensory organs that allow them to find females at which point they will temporarily attach themselves to the body (Pietsch in press). Vakily et al. (2002) describe M. johnsonii as bathypelagic with a maximum size of 3 cm TL off of West Africa.
threats: There are no known major threats to Melanocetus johnsonii.
population: Melanocetus johnsonii is known from at least 852 female specimens and eight males (Pietsch 2009). Melanocetids are solitary species that do not occur abundantly (Pietsch in press).
range: Melanocetus johnsonii is distributed from the Atlantic, Pacific and Indian Oceans between 66oN and 53oS and it has occurred in nets fishing at zero to 2,100 m depth, but mostly shallower than 1,500 m (Pietsch 2009). Vakily et al. (a study by FishBase on West African fishes; 2002) report M. johnsonii as distributed off the Cape Verde Islands. This species occurred in a trawl survey conducted off the coast of Namibia between the years 1992-1996 (Hamukuaya et al. 2001). In the Western Atlantic it is distributed from 175-2,700 m depth (mostly greater than 2,100 m) from Greenland south to Argentina (Moore et al. 2003). One specimen occurred in Icelandic waters at 62°50’N, 30°35’W (Jonsson and Palsson 1999). Near Hawaii, it is known from Oahu and Johnson Atoll from 600-1,000 m depth (Mundy 2005). This species occurs off of Japan from the Pacific coast of Tohoku District and around Okinotorishima Island (Nakabo 2002).
useTrade: Melanocetus johnsonii is not utilized (Pietsch in press). This species may be caught in trawls off of Namibia (Bianchi et al. 1999).
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures for Melanocetus johnsonii.

rationale: Radiicephalus elongatus is circumglobally distributed in the meso-bathypelagic zone. It is a deep-dwelling, rare species that is not utilized and has no major threats. It is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Radiicephalus elongatus is a deep-sea species that occurs in the mesopelagic and bathypelagic zones. Its length is usually under 80 cm, between 60-75 cm. Data are limited on the reproduction and habits of R. elongatus. It is known to possess a gland that discharges an alarm response black substance (Olney in press). Vakily et al. (2002) describe R. elongatus as bathypelagic with a maximum size of 76 cm TL off of West Africa.
threats: There are no known major threats to Radiicephalus elongatus.
population: Radiicephalus elongatus is a very rarely occurring species. In the eastern Atlantic, it is known only from a few immature specimens caught in research nets (Olney in press).
range: Radiicephalus elongatus is distributed circumglobally in the mesopelagic zone in most oceans (Olney in press). It ranges from the eastern central Atlantic to the western, central and eastern North Pacific oceans from zero to 600 m depth. Vakily et al. (a study by FishBase on West African fishes; 2002) report R. elongatus as distributed off of Mauritania, Senegal, Gambia, Guinea-Bissau, Guinea and Sierra Leone.
useTrade: Radiicephalus elongatus is not utilized (Olney in press).
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures for Radiicephalus elongatus.

rationale: Zu cristatus is circumglobally distributed in the epi-mesopelagic zone in depths from zero to 950 m. It is a rarely occurring, typically deep-dwelling species that is an important prey item for some large pelagic predators. It sometimes occurs as bycatch in longline fisheries, but is not utilized and there are no major threats. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Zu cristatus is an offshore fish with a maximum size of approximately 120 cm SL that inhabits the epipelagic and mesopelagic zone. It feeds on pelagic crustaceans, small fishes and squids. The eggs are free-floating, large and red. Juveniles swim at the surface while trailing elongate dorsal and pelvic fin rays that give them the appearance of a jellyfish. Data on the reproduction and habits of this species are limited (Olney in press, Bianchi et al. 1999). Vakily et al. (2002) describe Z. cristatus as bathypelagic with a maximum size of 118 cm SL off of West Africa. Eggs of this species in ichthyoplankton collections in the Adriatic Sea had a diameter of 1.85-2.1 0mm (Dulcic 2002). Another ichthyoplankton study found eggs of Z. cristatus in the Mid-Atlantic Bight of the western Atlantic which the authors believe were spawned in warm oceanic waters south of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina (Olney and Naplin 1980). It is reportedly a prey item of Sailfish in the southern Gulf of California, Mexico (Rosas-Alayola et al. 2002).
threats: There are no known major threats to Zu cristatus.
population: Zu cristatus is a rarely occurring species (Olney in press).
range:
Zu cristatus is distributed circumglobally in the mesopelagic zone (Olney in press). Vakily et al. (a study by FishBase on West African fishes; 2002) report Z. cristatus as distributed off of Sierra Leone. In tropical to warm temperate waters of the western Atlantic it is distributed from Norfolk Canyon (36°50'N, 73°40'W), south of La Have Basin (40°57'N, 63°35'W), near Alvin Canyon (39°47'N, 70°32'W), and near Bear Seamount south to Florida, the Gulf of Mexico and Cuba (Moore et al. 2003), as well as eastern Brazil and Argentina. 

In the Pacific this species has been recorded from zero to 950 m depth off of New Caledonia (Fricke et al. 2011) and off of Chile (Sielfeld et al. 2010). Near Hawaii, this species has been recorded off of the main Hawaiian Islands and the Hancock Seamounts. 

It is also known from the Mediterranean Sea (Bianco et al. 2006, Bradai and El Ouaer 2012), Indian and Pacific Oceans in the epipelagic zone (Mundy 2005). It is considered rare off of Japan, but has occurred from the mouth of Tokyo Bay south to Osaka Bay, the Ogasawara Islands and Akita Prefecture south to Yamaguchi Prefecture (Nakabo 2002).
useTrade: Zu cristatus is not utilized (Olney in press). This species is uncommonly caught as bycatch in trawl fisheries (Bianchi et al. 1999). It uncommonly occurs as bycatch in the swordfish longline fishery in southern Italy (Cambie et al. 2013).
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures for Zu cristatus.

rationale: This species is circumglobal in tropical and temperate seas and is common and abundant species in many parts of its range. Vinciguerria poweriae is very common in museum collections. There is no use and trade information available for this species. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Vinciguerria poweriae is mesopelagic, with adults and juveniles partake in diel migrations (Badcock 1984). Adult photophore complement attained at ~1.9 cm standard length (SL). The maximum recorded SL is 4.3 cm (Badcock 1984). The diet of Vinciguerria poweriae consists of small crustaceans (Badcock 1984). Peak spawning occurs from the spring and summer (Badcock 1984).
threats: There are no known threats to Vinciguerria poweriae.
population: Vinciguerria poweriae is very common in museum collections (986 lots with most comprising one specimen and a maximum of 71 specimens in one lot; Fishnet2 2013).
range:
Vinciguerria poweriae is circumglobal, in subtropical waters (Badcock 1984). In the eastern central Atlantic, Vinciguerria poweriae occurs from Portugal and the Canary Islands to the Cape Verde Islands, including the Mediterranean (Quero et al. 1990). In the western Atlantic, it is found from Canada, south to the Gulf of Mexico. In the western Pacific, it occurs in Australia and New Zealand, including Tasmania. In the eastern Pacific, it is found at the Seaward edge of the California Current region and Chile. It also occurs in the South China Sea (OBIS 2014).

Vinciguerria poweriae is found from 300-600 m by day and 50-350 m by night (Schaefer et al. 1986).
useTrade: Vinciguerria poweriae is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures for Vinciguerria poweriae.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a meso- to bathypelagic, oceanodromous species (Riede 2004). It undertakes moderate, vertical diurnal migrations, inhabiting shallower waters of between 100-450 m at night and deeper waters of between 800-900 m during the day (Stewart et al. 2015). It feeds on crustaceans and small fishes (Muus and Nielsen 1999). The largest specimen measured 9 cm standard length (Reiner 1996).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: Population data are limited. There are 251 occurrence records of this species in the FishNet2 database (accessed August 2018), over 400 records of this species in OBIS, and over 300 records in GBIF (accessed October 2018).
range: This species is circumglobally distributed between subarctic and subantarctic waters, including tropical areas (Cuvier 1829, Baird 1971, Whitehead et al. 1984, Pequeño 1989, Santos et al. 1997, Porteiro et al. 1999, Castellanos-Galindo et al. 2006, Sanchez et al. 2008, Møller et al. 2010, Fricke et al. 2011, Lima et al. 2011, Chouvelon et al. 2012, Psomadakis et al. 2012, Harold et al. 2015, Bañón et. al. 2016, iDigBio database accessed November 2018). Its presence in the Mediterranean Sea requires further investigation. Specimens have been taken at depths between 100-900 m (Whitehead et al. 1984, Stewart et al. 2015).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: Argyropelecus sladeni is found throughout the Atlantic, Pacific and Indian Oceans. It can be found in abundance in some areas, but more research is needed regarding its current population size and trend. This species is not utilized and there are no known threats. There are no known conservation measures. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Argyropelecus sladeni is a mesopelagic species, found from 100-600 m. During the day, it is found between 350 and 600 m. At night, it is concentrated between 100 and 375 m (Baird 1971). It feeds on copepods (Watson 1996). Argyropelecus sladeni is oviparous, with planktonic eggs and larvae (Watson 1996).
threats: There are no known species-specific threats faced by Argyropelecus sladeni.
population: Argyropelecus sladeni can be found in abundance in areas of its distribution (Baird 1971).
range: In the Atlantic Ocean, Argyropelecus sladeni is found in abundance along the African coast from about 15°S northward into the Gulf of Guinea. There are also museum records from Mauritania, Western Sahara, Morocco and the Azores. It occurs in moderate numbers across the equatorial Atlantic from 5°S to 15°N, and is abundant in the Caribbean in the Venezuelan coast, but is absent in the northern Caribbean. It is also found in the western and northern Gulf of Mexico and straits of Florida, as well as the North Atlantic along the Brazilian coast. In the Pacific Ocean, A. sladeni occurs in large subpopulations in the North Pacific to about 175°W, off of the California coast and off the coast of Chile. It is also found in the  north of New Zealand and south of Hawaii. In the Indian Ocean, A. sladeni is abundant in the northern Indian Ocean to about 15°N, and along the African coast to about 10°S (Baird 1971) as well as off Mozambique, Madagascar and South Africa. Argyropelecus sladeni is found from 100-600 m. During the day, it is found between 350-600 m. At night, it is concentrated between 100-375 m (Baird 1971).
useTrade: There is currently no information regarding the use and/or trade of Argyropelecus sladeni.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures in place for Argyropelecus sladeni. More research is needed regarding its current population size and trend.

rationale: Sternoptyx diaphana is a broadly distributed species, found in the Atlantic Ocean, the southern Caribbean, the Gulf of Mexico, the straits of Florida, the Indian Ocean and the Pacific Ocean. It can be abundant in areas of its distribution. It is not utilized and there are no known threats. There are no conservation measures in place. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Sternoptyx diaphana is a non-migrating mesopelagic species, occurring from 300-1,500 m. In regions with cooler waters, S. diaphana feeds on fewer but larger food items. It has prominent eyes and displays a photophore and pigment pattern that can maximize invisibility in the mesopelagic zone, which may indicate that it is a visually oriented predator (Hopkins and Baird 1973). It feeds primarily on copepods, ostracods and amphipods as juveniles, and amphipods and euphasiids as adults (Hopkins and Baird 1985).
threats: There are no known species-specific threats faced by Sternoptyx diaphana.
population: Sternoptyx diaphana can be abundant in some areas of its range (Baird 1971). More research is needed regarding its current population size and trend. It is not known whether there is substantial immigration/emigration from outside the Eastern Central Atlanticthat will significantly affect subpopulations in the region.
range: Sternoptyx diaphana is a broadly distributed species, being found nearly ubiquitously in all subarctic waters of the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans. In the Atlantic Ocean, S. diaphana has been caught in moderate numbers in the southern Atlantic off the coast of Brazil, from 20°W to the African coast at approximately 35°S, and is abundant in the Gulf of Guinea and tropical regions of the Atlantic. It has also shown abundant numbers in the southern Caribbean, the Gulf of Mexico and the straits of Florida. In the Indian Ocean, S. diaphana is found in small to moderate subpopulations from 5°S to 35°S, as well as south of Java near Borneo, the Banda Sea and between New Guinea and the Solomon Islands. In the Pacific Ocean, S. diaphana is found near the Philippines, along the coast of Japan, in small numbers off the coast of southern California (United States of America), in abundant southeast of Hawaii, and has a large subpopulation that extends across the southern Pacific from Chile to approximately 160°E (Baird 1971). It can be found in waters ranging from 300-1,500 m in depth, but is commonly found in waters between 600-900 m in depth (Hopkins and Baird 1973).
useTrade: There is currently no information regarding the use and/or trade of Sternoptyx diaphana.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures in place for Sternoptyx diaphana. More research is needed regarding its current population size and trend.

rationale: Valenciennellus tripunctulatus is found in the tropical and temperate regions of the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans. There is no use and trade information available for this species. There are no species-specific threats to this species. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Valenciennellus tripunctulatus is a small mesopelagic species, found in abundance at depths of 200-600 m during diel periods. It is a zooplanktivorous fish, feeding primarily on copepods. Analyses show that V. tripunctulatus feeds primarily during the hours of 12:00-22:00. This has been shown to be due to a reduction in available energy based on the size of prey typically consumed by V. tripunctulatus. Most of the prey consumed by V. tripunctulatus is in the 1.0-5.0 mm size range (Hopkins and Baird 1981a,b,c).
threats: There are no known species-specific threats faced by Valenciennellus tripunctulatus.
population: Average population density of Valenciennellus tripuntulatus in the Caribbean was about 5 individuals per 104 x m3 (Hopkins and Baird 1981a).
range: Valenciennellus tripunctulatus is found in the tropical and temperate regions of the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans (Harold 2002). It is found throughout the Gulf of Mexico (Felder et al. 2009). It occurs in the western Atlantic Ocean from Bermuda and the eastern coast of Florida to the Gulf of Mexico and the Virgin Islands, at depths between 100-700 m, most commonly between 351-550 m (McEachran and Fechhelm 1998). This speices is widely distributed in the Eastern Central Atlantic.
useTrade: There is currently no information regarding the use and/or trade of Valanciennellus tripunctulatus.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Valenciennellus tripunctulatus. More research is needed regarding its current population size and trend.

rationale: Poromitra crassiceps has a nearly cosmopolitan distribution. It is a deep-dwelling, bathypelagic, commonly occurring species that is found over the continental slope. There are no known threats. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Poromitra crassiceps is a bathypelagic species that is typically found over slope areas (Garcia and Morgan 2002, Pusch et al. 2004). It is found most abundantly at approximately 800 m depth, with lesser catches by day than by night, suggesting a vertical migration to the depth horizon at night (Willis and Pearcy 1982).
