The species is most commonly found to 27 m depth, but has been noted to occur at over 300 m.
useTrade: There are no records of this species in trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Gasterosteus aculeatus. There are however several subpopulations that are listed in Canada's Species at Risk Act (SARA), which implies full legal protection for those populations. All of these subpopulations are located in British Columbia. Research and monitoring are needed to determine population size and trends across the large range of this species. Within-species diversity is high in this species, and the adaptive radiation exhibited by them warrants protection (Foster et al. 2003).

rationale: Anotopterus pharao is a near global bathypelagic piscivore that is considered antitropical. It has a widespread distribution but little specific population information. It is not utilized but may be caught as bycatch. It has no known threats or protection. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This marine species is bathypelagic, living at depths from 500-2,000 m (Post 1996). It is a carnivore (Radchenko and Semenchenko 1996) and is a considered a key predator of Pacific Salmon (Beamish et al. 1999, Radchenko and Semenchenko 1996). Members of the family Anotopteridae are piscivores. The average length is about 85 cm, with a reported maximum of 146 cm (Beamish et al. 1999). They are thought to be synchronous hermaphrodites (Russell in press).
threats: There are no known major threats to this species.
population: Population information for this species is limited, although it appears to be widespread (www.FishNet2.net, Hubbs et al. 1953, Radchenko and Semenchenko 1996).
range: Anotopterus pharao is an antitropical species found in the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans (Post 1996, Hubbs et al. 1953). It has a near global distribution, with records off Portugal, France, Tanzania, both coasts of the U.S., Australia, Mexico, Antarctica and Japan (www.FishNet2.net). Most species of family Anotopteridae are found north and south of latitude 20º (Russell in press). It is typically found at depths from 500 m to more than 2,000 m (Post 1996).
useTrade: Anotopterus pharao is not used commercially due to its rarity. However, it may be caught as bycatch from deep water trawls (Iwami and Takahashi 1992).
conservationActions: It is possible that this species occurs in a marine protected area throughout its range of distribution. This species has no known protection.

rationale: Caulophryne jordani is circumglobally distributed. There are no known widespread threats, therefore, C. jordani is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Caulophrynidae species are meso- and bathypelagic anglerfishes. Males are smaller and parasitic on the females (Pietsch in press). The maximum recorded size of C. jordani is 21.5 cm (Jónsson and Pálsson 1999).
threats: This is a deep sea species that has no known widespread threats. It is of no economic interest (Pietsch in press).
population: There are no species specific population data available.
range: Caulophryne jordani is a worldwide species found primarily in Eastern Atlantic, Indo-Pacific and Southern Oceans (Pietsch in press). It was collected from 600 to 1,100 m in Icelandic waters (Jónsson and Pálsson 1999).
useTrade: Species of the Caulophrynidae family are of no economic interest (Pietsch in press).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts in place.

rationale: Bathytroctes macrolepis is widespread in the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans. It may be common in parts of its range (although not likely to be abundant), however it is not common in museum collections. There in no available information on the commercial use and/or trade of this species, but it does not appear to be heavily utilized by commercial fisheries. It is not known to face any major threats at this time and may be protected by the numerous marine protected areas within its distribution. Research into all aspects of this specie's biology and ecology is suggested. Bathytroctes macrolepis is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Bathytroctes macrolepis is a marine, benthopelagic to bathypelagic species that occurs between depths of 1,100-3,200 m (Markle and Sazonov 1990), but is most often associated in depths below 1,900 m (Markle and Quero 1986). The maximum standard length (SL) for this species is 32 cm (Markle and Sazonov 1990). The diet, fecundity, spawning patterns and early life history traits are poorly understood for this species. Therefore, further research is required for this species.
threats: There are no known major threats. It is a very deep-dwelling species where anthropogenic influences are thought to be at a minimum currently, but these deep sea ecosystems are at risk of deteriorating due mainly to dumping of solid wastes, biological harvesting and mineral extraction, and climate change, all of which will significantly affect the biota of the deep seas (Ramirez-Llodra et al. 2011).
population: Bathytroctes macrolepis is found in the northeastern Atlantic and surrounding regional waters, and is considered relatively common. A total of 50 specimens of Bathytrocetes macrolepis were caught from two sub-areas on the Mid-Atlantic Ridge (MAR) between the Azores and Iceland as part of the 2004 MAR-ECO expedition (Bergstad et al. 2008). The abundance and biomass of Bathytroctes macrolepis was recorded from a designated southeast station (SE) on the Mid-Atlantic Ridge with five fish km-2 (standard deviation = 10) and 0.02 kg km-2 (standard deviation = 0.05) respectively.  The sweep area was 0.035 km2 with a mean depth of 2,736 m. Trawls at the SE station were conducted on 21 and 22 July 2007 and 10 through 11, 18 August 2009 (Cousins et al. 2013). Bathytroctes macrolepis is not common or abundant in museum collections.
range: Bathytroctes macrolepis is a circum-global species that occurs in the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans (Sazonov 1999). In the northeastern Atlantic region, this species is found off of Ireland to the Azores (Markle and Sazonov 1999). Bathytroctes macrolepis is found in tropical and temperate waters (Carter and Hartel 2002). It has a depth range of 1,100-3,200 m but is usually found below 1,900 m (Markle and Sazonov 1990).
useTrade: Information regarding the use and/or trade of this species is not available. There is no known interest in commercial fisheries for this species (Carter and Hartel 2002).
conservationActions: There are no known, species-specific conservation measures in place for Bathytroctes macrolepis. Though this species may have access to numerous marine protected areas (MPAs) due to its wide distribution, deep-water marine protected areas are likely to be of limited effectiveness (Bailey et al. 2009, Davies et al. 2007, Howell 2010). Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

rationale: Melanolagus bericoides is widely distributed in the tropical and subtropical Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian Oceans. It is a bathypelagic species, typically found at depths greater than 1,000 m. There are no known major threats to this species. Therefore, Melanolagus bericoides is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Melanolagus bericoides is a meso to bathypelagic species, typically found singly or in small groups (Cohen 1984, 1990). The maximum size of this fish has been measured at 20.0 cm standard length (SL) (Cohen 1990). It is known to participate in diel migrations (Mundy 2005). It feeds on plankton (Cohen 1984). This species is oviparous with planktonic eggs and pelagic larvae (Moser and Ahlstrom 1996). The spawning season, fecundity and early life history traits of this species are poorly understood.
threats: There are no known major threats for this species.
population: Melanolagus bericoides is rare off the southwestern coast of Greenland but relatively common elsewhere in its range (Moller et al. 2010).
range: Melanolagus bericoides occurs in the tropical and subtropical Atlantic, Pacific and Indian Oceans, widely distributed in tropical and subtropical waters (Cohen 1984). In the northeastern Atlantic and surrounding regional waters, it has been collected off of Portugal, Madeira and the Azores (Carneiro et al. 2014). Specimens have also been identified from southern Iceland and from off western Greenland. It is generally associated with depths between zero and 1,130 m (Mundy 2005) but is generally found deeper (1,700 m) in the northern portion of its range (Moller et al. 2010).
useTrade: This species is of no interest to fisheries.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for Melanolagus bericoides. There are a few marine protected areas in its range, but it is not known if Melanolagus bericoides is found within them. Research into the population trends and size, ecology and early life history traits, and possible threats is needed for this species.

rationale: Caulophryne pelagica has been found between 954 and 2,500 metres in the eastern Atlantic Ocean, Indo-Pacific Ocean and the Southern Ocean. The males attach themselves to the females and becomes a parasite; little else can be said about the population, habitat and ecology. This species is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Females of the family Caulophrynidae passively attract prey through a luring device on their dorsal-fin spine (Pietsch in press). Males of the family Caulophrynidae actively seek mates by using highly developed sense organs. After finding a mate, they attach themselves to the female and become parasitic (Pietsch in press). The maximum size of a female specimen is 18.3 cm and of a male specimen is 1.6 cm (Pietsch in press).
threats: There are no species-specific threats.
population: There is no information about the population.
range: Caulophryne pelagica is found in meso- and bathylpelagic waters in the eastern Atlantic Ocean, Indo-Pacific Ocean and the Southern Ocean (Pietsch in press) as well as the eastern Pacific. It has been found between 954 and 2,500 metres.
useTrade: This species is not of economic value.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts in place.

rationale: Cetostoma regani has been found circumglobally between 100 and 3,700 metres deep. Due to only a few specimens caught, little can be said about the population. There are no species-specific threats. This species is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The largest female was 25 cm standard length but it is most commonly found to be 19 cm long. The smallest found was 4 cm long. Males were found to range between 3.4 and 4.1 cm (Moore in press). Females from the Cetomimidae family have been found to eat crustaceans, while males do not eat after transformation (Moore in press).
threats: There are no species-specific threats.
population: There have been 150 females found and seven males (Moore in press).
range: This species can be found circumglobally (50°N to 40°S) apart from the South Pacific Ocean, where it is found to 15ºS (Moore in press). It has been found between zero and 3,700 metres deep. The shallower depths were found at night, often with smaller specimens.
useTrade: This is not a commercially important species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts.

rationale: Ditropichthys storeri is found circumglobally between 45°N and 45°S between 650 and 5,000 metres deep. Due to only a few females having been recorded, little can be said about the population, habitats and ecology. There are no species-specific threats. This species is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The largest female found was 13 cm long but is more commonly found at 10 cm long. The smallest specimen found was 2.5 cm. Females from the Cetomimidae family have been found to eat crustaceans, while males do not eat after transformation (Moore in press).
threats: There are no species-specific threats.
population: There have been 100 females found and no males (Moore in press).
range: Ditropichthys storeri is found circumglobally between 45° N and S (Moore in press). Smaller specimens of this species can be found as shallow as 650 metres deep while the larger specimens can be found as deep as 5,000 metres.
useTrade: This is not a commercially important species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts.

rationale: Gyrinomimus myersi has been found circumglobally, between 2,200 and 2,350 metres. Due to few recorded specimens, little can be said about the population. There are no species specific threats. This species is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The largest female found was 30 cm standard length but they are more commonly found around 16.5 cm (Moore in press). Females from the Cetomimidae family have been found to eat crustaceans, while males do not eat after transformation (Moore in press).
threats: There are no species-specific threats.
population: There have been 20 females found and no males (Moore in press).
range: Gyrinomimus myersi has been found circumglobally, between 2,200 and 2,350 metres. This species has been found in the Atlantic between 55°N to 20° S, tropically in the central Indian Ocean and Pacific Ocean between 40° to 20° N (Moore in press). There are also museum specimens from off eastern Australia.
useTrade: This is not a commercially important species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts.

rationale: Chiasmodon subniger is a meso- to bathylpelagic species that occurs in the Pacific Ocean. Current threats to this species are unknown and information about the biology of this species is limited. Some records of this species are questionable. This species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Chiasmodon subniger is a meso- to bathylpelagic species with a maximum recorded size of 33 cm TL (Smith in press).
threats: Major threats to this species are unknown.
population: Chiasmodon subniger larvae had a count of 16 occurrences taken in Bongo net tows on CalCOFI cruises in 2007 in the Southern California Bight (Charter et al. 2011). Additional population information is not available.
range: Chiasmodon subniger occurs in the Eastern Pacific Ocean to the west of Hawaii (Melo 2009, Prokofiev and Kukuev 2009). There are a few scattered records in the Atlantic Ocean. The depth range of this species is between 245 to 4,568 m (Melo et al. 2009).
useTrade: The meso- to bathypelagic species of the family Chiasmontidae are caught occasionally in deep midwater trawls (Smith in press).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts in place for this species. There is a need for additional information about the biology of this species.

rationale: Dysalotus oligoscolus occurs worldwide in all major oceans to at least 1,500 m. Current threats to this species are unknown. Information about the population and biology of this species are limited. This species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Dysalotus oligoscolus is a meso- to bathypelagic species that can attain 33 cm TL (Smith in press).
threats: Current threats to this species are unknown.
population: Population information is not available for this species.
range: Dysalotus oligoscolus is a circumglobal tropical to subtropical species that can occurs at depths to at least 1,500 m (Johnson and Keene 1990, Smith in press).
useTrade: The meso- to bathypelagic species of the family Chiasmontidae are caught occasionally in deep midwater trawls (Smith in press). No use or trade information is known.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts in place for this species.

rationale: Kali kerberti is a widely distributed species that can occur to over 3,000 m depth. Current threats to this species are unknown. Information about the population size and biology of this species are limited. However, given its large distribution and deep water habitat, there are not likely to be any major threats. It is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: The maximum recorded size for this species is 19.3 cm SL (Melo 2008). Additional information about the habitats and ecology of this species is limited. Species of the family Chiasmontidae are meso- to bathypelagic fishes with most broadly distributed in multiple oceans (Smith in prep).
threats: Current threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no population information for this species.
range: Kali kerberti occurs in the Atlantic from 38°N to 21°S with some specimens being described as being from 49° N, 27°N to 33°S in the Pacific and some individuals being described as being identified as far North as 38°. There is a single record in the western Indian Ocean. The depth range for this species is 200–4,465 m (Melo 2008). It is circumglobal in tropical to warm temperate seas.
useTrade: Chiasmontids are occasionally collected in deep midwater trawls (Smith in prep).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts in place for this species. Additional information about the population size/trend and biology of this species is needed.

rationale: Cyema atrum is widely distributed in all oceans. This species is more common than the other species in the family Cyematidae. In the northeastern Atlantic Ocean, it is known from the coast of Portugal to the Azores and Madeira, and appears to be rare. There are no known major threats; therefore, C. atrum is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Cyema atrum is a marine bathypelagic species with a depth range from 1,500-5,100 m (Saldanha 1990). Little is known about its ecology, but it is carnivorous and has a distinct leptocephalus larva (Saldanha and Bauchot 1986). The maximum length is 15 cm.
threats: There are no known species-specific threats. It is only seen seldomly in deep-towed mid water trawls.
population: Cyema atrum is more common than the other species in the family Cyematidae (Smith 1989). However, it appears to be rare in the north Atlantic Ocean; it is very rare off the southeastern coast of Greenland (Moller et al. 2010) and known from only one specimen off the Azores (Santos et al. 1997).
range: Cyema atrum is circumglobal in all oceans. In the AtlanticOcean, it occurs from off southwestern Greenland (Nielsen and Bertelsen 1992, Møller et al. 2010) and at the southern boundary of the Irminger Sea (Poulsen 2015) and from off the coast of Portugal and Gibraltar to the Azores and Madeira and south to South Africa (Carneiro et al. 2014). In the western Atlantic, this species is found from off Canada south to Bermuda, Brazil and Argentina (MCZ occurrence records), but it is not found in the Gulf of Mexico, the Caribbean Sea or the Saragossa Sea. In the In the Indo-Pacific, this species is found, from Somalia and in the central Indian Ocean as well off Australia (Paxton et al. 1989) and New Zealand (Paulin et al. 1989) as well as off southern Japan (National Museum of Nature and Science, Japan). In the Eastern Pacific, it is found from British Columbia (Hanke et al. 2014) and Oregon, USA south to Panama (Charter 1996) and Chile (Pequeno 1989). It has not been recorded from the Mediterranean (Saldanha and Bauchot 1986). It is typically found at depths of 1,500 to 5,100 m (Saldanha and Bauchot 1986).
useTrade: This species is of no interest to fisheries.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Gigantactis vanhoeffeni is circumglobally distributed in temperate and tropical waters with specimens found off Cape Verde and off southern Greenland. It is a meso-bathypelagic species, residing between 300 m and 5,300 m. Little is known about its population or ecology. There are no known major threats. Due to limited information, G. vanhoeffeni is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The Gigantactinidae are known for their extreme sexual dimorphism. Males of the Gigantactinidae family are characterized by their small size. They are considered a dwarf male family with a maximum size of 2.2 cm, while the females are significantly larger than the males with the ability to reach 43.5 cm in size (Pietsch in press). In the Gigantactinidae family males are known to attach to the females by using pincer-like denticles. In this particular family males do not permanently attach and are only attached for a small period of time (Pietsch 2005).
threats: There are no known species-specific threats for Gigantactis vanhoeffeni.
population: There is little to no known information on the population.
range: Gigantactis vanhoeffeni is a meso-bathypelagic anglerfish (Pietsch in press) distributed circumglobally in temperate and tropical seas. It is recorded off Cape Verde in the Eastern Central Atlantic and there is one record off southern Greenland (Anderson et al. 2001). Gigantactis vanhoeffeni resides in depths between 300 m and 5,300 m.
useTrade: There are no known uses of Gigantactis vanhoeffeni.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts in place for Gigantactis vanhoeffeni.

rationale: Cyclothone acclinidens is a circumglobal meso-bathypelagic fish in depths ranging from 300–1,200 m. Species of the Gonostomatid genus Cyclothone, are very abundant and widespread, and are numerically dominant in the meso-and bathypelagic zones in all major oceans. In midwater trawls at depths greater than 300 m, adults are frequently collected. This species is not utilized and has no known threats. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Cyclothone acclinidens is a mesopelagic fish that feeds on herbivorous species such as copepods (DeWitt and Cailliet 1972). The maximum recorded length for this species is 6.5 cm SL (Gon 1990). This species is often observed floating motionless and nearly vertical (Smith and Laver 1981).  Species in this family can exhibit sexual dimorphism or hermaphroditism (Harold in press). Adults are found from 300-1,200 m and post-larvae at zero to 70 m (Babcock 1984).
threats: There are no major, species-specific threats documented for C. acclinidens. It is caught as bycatch in parts of its range and competes for resources with various species of shrimp, showing no niche differentiation within their shared midwater habitat (Hopkins and Sutton 1998).
population: Species of the Gonostomatid genus Cyclothone, of which C. acclinidens is one of the most abundant and wide spread, are numerically dominant in the meso-and bathypelagic zones in all major oceans. In midwater trawls at depths greater than 300 m, adults are routinely collected (Smith and Laver 1981). Over the course of eight months, samples collected weekly from six sampling stations off the Canary Islands showed C. acclinidens as representing 0.16% of all collected larvae (Moyano et al. 2009). Cyclothone species are very common in the open ocean (Kobylianski pers. comm. 2013).
range: Cyclothone acclinidens is a circumglobal meso to bathypelagic fish. It is found from about 30°S to 60°N in all oceans. In Atlantic waters, it is found in depths ranging from 300–1,200 m (Moore et al. 2003). It is most prevalent in tropical to temperate waters (Badcock 1984). This species occurs throughout European waters including the Canary Islands (Badcock 1984) and the Azores (Arruda 1997, Santos et al. 1997).
useTrade: Cyclothone acclinidens is not utilized (Nevenzel and Menon 1980).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts in place for C. acclinidens. However, this species has a circumglobal range that overlaps with numerous Marine Protected Areas (World Database of Protected Areas, 2014).

rationale: Coryphaenoides armatus is a common species in the bathypelagic of the most ocean basins on the abyssal plain. It lives at depths too great to be of commercial interest, and there are no known major known threats. Therefore, C. armatus is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Coryphaenoides armatus is a deep-slope, upper continental rise species found between 2,000 m and 4,700 m. The diet of C. armatus changes ontogenetically, from benthic invertebrates (especially crustaceans and holothuroids) when young to mesopelagic and bathypelagic fish, sea urchins and cephalopods as adults (Cohen et al. 1990). Examination of the stomach contents of C. armatus collected by trawling at depths below 2,600 m in Hudson Canyon provided evidence that a major portion of the diet comes from the deep mesopelagic and bathypelagic regions. The largest C. armatus collected by trawling at depths below 2,600 m in Hudson Canyon in 1973 was 102 cm total length (Haedrich and Henderson 1974). It has been suggested that C. armatus is semelparous, as few ripe females and no spent individuals have been collected (Stein and Pearcy 1982, Drazen 2001).
threats: Coryphaenoides armatus is not a commercially targeted species, however it is taken as bycatch in deepwater fisheries (Priede et al. 2010). This is not thought to be a major threat.
population: The estimated combined abundance of Coryphaenoides armatus and C. yaquinae increased by 275% (from an annual average abundance of 7.5 ind/ha in 1989 to 28.1 ind/ha in 2004) via towed cameras between 1989 and 2004 at approximately 4,100 m depth at Station M (Bailey et al. 2006). Station M is located in the abyssal northeast Pacific about 220 km west of Point Conception, California. The abundance was not reported by species, so it is unclear whether the increase is attributable to C. armatus. Coryphaenoides armatus was the most abundant macrourid sampled by long-line in the Mid-Atlantic ridge (Fossen et al. 2008).
range: Coryphaenoides armatus is common to the deep waters of most oceans, between 2,000-4,700 m (Cohen et al. 1990). It is likely more widely distributed than currently known.
useTrade: Coryphaenoides armatus is large and taken in moderate numbers by oceanographic research vessels, but lives at depths too great to be of commercial potential (Cohen et al. 1990).
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation initiatives.

rationale: Mesobius berryi is distributed along the Mid-Atlantic Ridge north and south of Ascension Island. It is also known from tropical and subtropical eastern and central Pacific and Indian Oceans. It is found to depths of 2,700 m. There is little species-specific population or threat information for this species. It is not utilized. Mesobius berryi is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Mesobius berryi is a meso-, bath- and bethopelagic species which is known from depths of up to 2,700 m.
threats: There are no known species-specific threats to M. berryi.
population: There is little species-specific population information available for M. berryi.
range: Mesobius berryi is distributed along the Mid-Atlantic Ridge north and south of Ascension Island. It is also known from tropical and subtropical eastern and central Pacific and Indian Oceans (Hubbs and Iwamoto 1977). It is known from depths of up to 2,700 m.
useTrade: Mesobius berryi is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for M. berryi.

rationale: Melamphaes longivelis occurs in tropical and temperate waters of the Atlantic Ocean. This species is found between 45°S and 60°N in the Atlantic and Pacific Ocean. They can be found in North and South Atlantic, throughout Indonesia, and tropical and subtropical western and central Pacific. There is little known about the population. There are no species-specific threats. This species is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Melamphaidae eat gelatinous organisms and small crustaceans (Moore in press).
threats: There are no species-specific threats but it can get caught in deepwater trawls.
population: There is no information about the population.
range: Melamphaes longivelis occurs in tropical and temperate waters of the Atlantic Ocean. This species is found between 45°S and 60°N in the Atlantic and Pacific Ocean, young are taken in waters as shallow as 150 m (Ebeling and Weed 1963).They can be found in North and South Atlantic, throughout Indonesia, and tropical and subtropical western and central Pacific (Kotlyar 2004). This species is associated with depths of between zero and 1,500 m.
useTrade: There are no species-specific fisheries.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts in place.

rationale: Melamphaes polylepis is found in tropical waters worldwide in depths between 200 and 2,000 metres. Little is known about the population. There are no species-specific threats but it can be caught as by-catch in trawls. This species is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Species of the Melamphaidae family eat gelatinous organisms and small crustaceans (Moore in press). Kotlyar (2011) sampled for M. polylepis by using open-mouth nets at depths of zero to 4,228 metres. Juveniles often are found deeper than 200-300 metres. The largest specimen found was 6.8 cm including previously sampled specimens.
threats: There are no species-specific threats but it may be caught in deep-water trawls.
population: There is no information about the population.
range: Melamphaes polylepis is found in tropical waters worldwide (Moore in press). This species is found between 55ºN and 11ºS in the Atlantic and Pacific Ocean. Young are taken in waters as shallow as 150 m (Ebling 1962) but juveniles often are found deeper than 200-300 m. Fish of the Melamphaidae family are found in depths between 200 and 2,000 metres (Moore in press). Kotlyar (2011) sampled for M. polylepis by using open-mouth nets at depths of zero to 4,228 metres.
useTrade: This species is not targeted by any fisheries but may get caught in deep-water trawls.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts in place.

rationale: Loweina rara is distributed between diagonal 36°N /32°N and about 5°N, and in the eastern sector between 8°S and 26°S. However, one record has been recorded from 36°S in the Atlantic Ocean; two regions probably linked in Gulf of Guinea via Equatorial Countercurrent system. Also, it is known from cooler tropical-subtropical waters of the western Atlantic (23°N–43°N), but is absent in the Gulf of Mexico, Caribbean, and South Sargasso Sea, and central South Atlantic. It occurs in the Indian Ocean (01°N–34°S) and in the Pacific off New South Wales (Australia) and New Zealand, and in eastern sector between 42°N and 29°S. It is a mesopelagic species, residing at depths from the surface to 1,000 m. Little is known about its population or ecology. There are no known major threats. Therefore, L. rara is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Loweina rara sexually matures once it reaches 2.8 cm in size, and can have a maximum size of 4.5 cm (Hulley and Paxton in press). Species of this family are known to exhibit diel vertical migration (Vipin et al. 2012). Females of the Myctophidae family are oviparous, and both sexes are non-guarding pelagic spawners with low reproductive rates (Catul et al. 2011). Predators of the family Mycophidae include various species of fish, squid, notothenioids, seabirds and mammals. Mycophidae prey primarily on  these particular species of copepods: Calanus propinquus, Calanus simillimus, Calanvides acutus, Rhincalanus gigas and Metridia gerlachei. Mycophidae also feed on amphipods and euphausiids (Kozlov 1995). Species of the family Myctophidae have photophores. They are thought to exhibit and detect blue/green colour bioluminescence. Although species in this family do not produce longwave bioluminescence (red light), they are thought to be more sensitive in its detection due to the large amount of their red light producing predators. Compared to other mesopelagic teleosts, the Myctophidea family wavelengths of maximum absorption fall within a small range of 480-492 nm. Their could be multiple reasons for the evolutionary development of photophores from being able to see at deeper depths, attracting mates, or finding predators (Turner et al. 2009). Lanternfish from the Myctophidae family use counter-illumination to regulate the brightness of their photophores for camouflage. Photophores are arranged differently for every species, and for males and females indicating a potential role in communication and mating (Catul et al. 2011).
threats: There are no known threats for loweina rara.
population: Little is known about the population of loweina rara at this time.
range: Loweina rara is distributed between diagonal 36°N /32°N and about 5°N, and in the eastern sector between 8°S and 26°S. However, one record has been recorded from 36°S in the Atlantic Ocean; two regions probably linked in Gulf of Guinea via Equatorial Countercurrent system. Also, it is known from cooler tropical-subtropical waters of the western Atlantic (23°N–43°N), but is absent in the Gulf of Mexico, Caribbean, and South Sargasso Sea, and central South Atlantic. It occurs in the Indian Ocean (01°N–34°S) and in the Pacific off New South Wales (Australia) and New Zealand, and in eastern sector between 42°N and 29°S. It is located in depths from just below the surface to as deep as 1,000 m. Daily depth ranges from 550-1,050 m, and nightly depths from just below the surface to 200 meters (Hulley and Paxton in press).
useTrade: In general, species of this family can be used for the production of seasoning, feed for cultured fish, surimi, cosmetic oil, fish meal and fish oil (Vipin et al. 2012). It is not known if this species is used.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation efforts are in place for loweina rara.

rationale: Nemichthys scolopaceus is widely distributed. Although this species is uncommon, it is a deep-water species that is not targeted in commercial fisheries and is only rarely caught as bycatch. Due to its expansive range it is likely that several subpopulations live within marine protected areas. It is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Nemichthys scolopaceus is a pelagic (Larsen 1973) to bathypelagic species (Coad and Reist 2004) with a depth range from the surface to 2,000 m in the Mediterranean (Nielsen 1984) and down to 3,656 m in the Atlantic (Coad and Reist 2004). Leptocephali (6-15 mm) are abundant between February and April and spawning occurs on both sides of thermal fronts throughout the west subtropical convergence zone of Sargasso Sea (Wippelhauser et al. 1996, Castonguay 1987). Larger specimens up to 8 cm exhibit diurnal migration (Castonguay and McCleave 1987). Nemichthys scolopaceus probably spawns around New Caledonia (Castle 1966). Nemichthys scolopaceus is semelparous species and exhibits sexual dimorphism. The diet of N. scolopaceus primarily consists of crustaceans, especially decapods and euphasids (Karmovskaya 1982, Smith 1989). The maximum length for this species is 130 cm (Muus and Nielsen 1999).
threats: Nemichthys scolopaceus is not a commercially fished species in Europe and no major threats have been identified for this species. However, bycatch is a potential threat (Emma pers. comm. 2013).
population: Nemichthys scolopaceus is not a common species (Larsen 1973). In the eastern Ionian Sea Nemichthys scolopaceus has a frequency of occurrence of 7.7% out of 13 hauls and abundance of 0.1 (N/h) (Mytilineou 2005). In south Sardinian waters it has a frequency of occurrence of 4% with a abundance of 0.02% (Follesa et al. 2011). This species is seldom collected in the Mediterranean, but as it is a deep-water species, it may be more common than the paucity of its records suggests.
range:
Nemichthys scolopaceus is a circumglobal species occurring in tropical and temperate seas.

In European waters and the Mediterranean, this species ranges from the United Kingdom and the Iberian Coast (Monteiro 2001, Serrano 2011) to the Azores and Canary Islands (Menezes et al. 2012, Porteiro et al. 2010, Sutton et al. 2008) and from Iceland (Larsen 1973, Byrkjedal et al. 2004, Krefft 1976). It is regularly found in the Skagerrak (Muus 1999). In the Mediterranean Sea (Quignard and Tomasini 2000), this species occurs in the southern Aegean Sea, particularly in Marmaris coast (Bilecenoglu et al. 2006). It is common in the Ligurian sea, off Algerian and north Sicilian coasts, in the Strait of Messina, in southern Sardinian waters and in eastern Ionian Sea (Mytilineou et al. 2005) and the Antalya Bay in southern Turkey (Gökoglu et al. 2009, Filiz et al. 2007). 

In the western Atlantic, this species is found from Nova Scotia, Canada and northern Gulf of Mexico south to Brazil, including the Caribbean Sea. In the western Pacific, it is found off Japan south to southern Australia and the Arafura Sea, and in the eastern Pacific, from Alaska south to Chile. This species is also found throughout the Indian Ocean.

Nemichthys scolopaceus is found at depths from the surface to depths of 2,000 m in the Mediterranean (Nielsen 1984) and 3,656 m in the Atlantic Ocean (Karmovskaya 1982, Smith 1989, Coad and Reist 2004).
useTrade: Nemichthys scolopaceus is not a commercially exploited species in Europe; however, it is caught as bycatch (Karmovskaya 1982, Smith 1989).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Nemichthys scolopaceus. In European waters, trawling is banned below 1,000 m which may afford some protection to N. scolopaceus. This species may be present in marine protected areas (MPAs) that occur within its distribution (World Database of Protected Areas 2010). In the Turkish checklist for marine fish this species was assessed as Data Deficient (Fricke et al. 2007). There is a need for further research about the biology and population trends of this species.

rationale: Chaenophryne draco has a worldwide distribution and it is a meso- and bathypelagic species which has been recorded at depths ranging from 350 to 1,750 m. There is little species-specific population information available for C. draco, although this species is abundant in museum collections. There are no known species-specific threats or conservation measures, and therefore this species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Chaenophryne draco is a meso- and bathypelagic species, and is known from only female specimens with the largest known female is 12.3 cm SL (Pietsch in press).
threats: There are no known species-specific threats to C. draco.
population: There is little species-specific population information available for C. draco. This species is abundant in museum collections, where it is represented by 170 lots (FishNet2 2014).
range: Chaenophryne draco has a worldwide distribution and has been recorded at depths ranging from 350 to 1,750 m (Mundy 2005).
useTrade: There is no use and trade information available for C. draco, although it is unlikely to be utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. draco.

rationale: Dolopichthys longicornis is known from tropical and temperate waters worldwide. It is commonly found in the tropical to temperate waters of the North Atlantic and northern Pacific, as well as in the southeastern Atlantic. This species is not utilized and is not currently facing any known threats. Therefore, D. longicornis is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Members of the Oneirodidae family are solitary meso- to bathypelagic anglerfish. Extreme sexual dimorphism exists between males and females. However, male D. longicornis do not become parasitic on the female as seen in other anglerfish species. Rather, they temporarily attach themselves with the aid of tooth-bearing denticles found on the tips of their jaws (Pietsch in press).
threats: There are currently no known threats facing D. longicornis.
population: There is no information available regarding the population status of D. longicornis.
range: Dolopichthys longicornis is found in the tropical to temperate waters of the North Atlantic and northern Pacific, as well as in the southeastern Atlantic, and it is probably distributed throughout all temperate and tropical waters of all oceans (Bertelsen 1990). It is known in tropical and temperate waters worldwide (Pietsch in press). This species has been found at depths 1,375-2,200 m (Pietsch 2009).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are currently no conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: Leptacanthichthys gracilispinis is found in the Northern Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, and it is found to depths of 2,000 m. There is no species-specific use and trade information available, there are no known species-specific threats, and there are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for L. gracilispinis. It is therefore assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The largest known female specimens are 10.3 cm SL, and the largest known male specimens are 0.8 cm (Pietsch in press).
threats: There are no known species-specific threats.
population: There is little species-specific population information available for L. gracilspinis. It is represented by 12 lots (FishNet2 database searched June 2014).
range: Leptacanthichthys gracilispinis is found in the Northern Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, and is found to depths of 2,000 m (Scott and Scott 1988).
useTrade: There is no use and trade information available for this species, and it is unlikely to be utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: Pentherichthys atratus is found in the Atlantic, Pacific and Indian Oceans. It has been collected at depths of less than 1,400 m. There is little species-specific population information available for P. stratus and there are no known species-specific threats, or species-specific conservation measures. Pentherichthys stratus is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species has been collected at depths of no more than 1,400 m. Females reach a maximum known size of 11.9 cm, and males reach a maximum of 1.4 cm.
threats: There are no species-specific threats to P. atratus.
population: Pentherichthys atratus is represented by 11 lots in museum collections and it has been collected to depths of 1,400 m (FishNet2 database searched June 2014).
range: Pentherichthys atratus is found in the Atlantic, Pacific and Indian Oceans and has been collected at depths of less than 1,400 m (FishNet2 database searched June 2014).
useTrade: There is no use and trade information available for this species, although it is not likely to be utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for P. atratus.

rationale: Spectrunculus grandis is a circumglobal species, inhabiting tropical and temperate waters of all of the major oceans of the world. It is sometimes taken in small numbers as bycatch in trawl industries, but it is not thought to adversely affect the population of the species. There are no other major threats to the species, as it inhabits very deep depths. There are not any specific conservation measures in place for Spectrunculus grandis, but marine protected areas are numerous throughout its range. Therefore, Spectrunculus grandis is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Spectrunculus grandis is a marine, bathydemersal fish that is common over most of its range. It has been recorded at 127 cm, maximum length (Nielsen et al. 1999). Spectrunculus grandis consumes gastropods, crustaceans, polychaete remains and detritus (Uiblein et al. 2008). It is oviparous, with oval, pelagic eggs floating in gelatinous mass (Breder and Rosen 1966). However, the larvae are epipelagic (Ambrose 1996). Little else is known about the habitat, reproduction, spawning, fecundity or other ecological aspects of this fish.
threats: Spectrunculus grandis is sometimes taken in bottom trawls, especially as bycatch. There are no species-specific landing rates reported, but it is not thought that the small-scale harvesting (Uiblein et al. 2008) of this species poses any threat at this time.
population: Spectrunculus grandis is quite common throughout most of its range (Uiblein et al. 2008). Along the Rockall Trough and Porcupine Segbight, Spectrunculus grandis is consistently in the top ten most abundant species in trawls over 2,000 m (Gordon et al. 1996). Spectrunculus grandis was also found to be one of the more common deep sea demersal scavenging fishes in the northeast Atlantic (Henriques et al. 2002, King et al. 2006). In the northeastern Pacific, Spectrunculus grandis appears to be less common than in other parts of its distribution (Bailey et al. 2006).
range: Spectrunculus grandis is a circumglobal species, inhabiting tropical and temperate waters of all of the major oceans of the world (Nielsen et al. 1999, Uiblein et al. 2008). In the eastern Pacific, it has been found from Canada and Alaska south to Argentina. In the western Pacific, from off New Zealand to Japan. In the western Atlantic, it has been found from Canada southward to southern Brazil, and in the eastern Atlantic, from northern Ireland and Scotland south to South Africa. In the northeastern Atlantic and adjacent regional waters, it is only found as far north as the Rockall and the Porcupine Abyssal Plain (Henriques et al. 2002). It is also found off of Portugal, Madeira and the Azores (Carneiro et al. 2014). It is associated with depths from 800 and 4,300 m (Nielsen and Hureau 1980, Bianchi et al. 1999). It is most often encountered at depths ranging from 2,000 to 3,000 m (Mundy 2005).
useTrade: Spectrunculus grandis is of minor commercial interest. It is sometimes caught in bottom trawls (Bianchi et al. 1999) and it is sometimes taken as bycatch in deep water trawls (Uiblein et al. 2008). There are no specific landings reports for Spectrunculus grandis, but it is not taken in large numbers (Uiblein et al. 2008). It is most often taken with vertical bottom and deep water horizontal long-lines (Menezes et al. 2012).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Spectrunculus grandis, but it range overlaps with many marine protected areas (MPAs). It remains unknown how effective MPAs are for deep-sea fauna (Davies et al. 2007, Howell 2010). Research into all areas of population size and trend, the ecology and early life history traits, as well as potential threats, is suggested for this species.

rationale: Maulisia argipalla is circumglobally distributed between 850-1,000 m. There is little known about this species population, habitats and ecology. There are no species-specific threats. This species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Maulisia argipalla is a mesopelagic species, typically found at 850-1,000 m (Quero et al. 1990). The maximum reported size is 19 cm (SL; Quero et al. 1990). Little else is known about its habitats or ecology.
threats: There are no known major threats to Maulisia argipalla.
population: This species is thought to be widespread but appears to be rare.
range: Maulisia argipalla is circum-globally distributed except for polar waters (Quero et al. 1990). In the northeastern Atlantic Ocean, Maulisia argipalla is known from the Azores and Madeira (Carneiro et al. 2014). The depth distribution of Maulisia argipalla is 850-1,000 m (Quero et al. 1990). It is also found in the northeastern Pacific off the coast of North America and Canada. Sys Taxa and the Natural History Museum of London have records of this species from south of Cape Verde to about 7°N. There are two museum specimens of this species from Japan, as well as from off Oregon and California in the United States.
useTrade: Maulisia argipalla is not utilized at present.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Rondeletia loricata is a circumglobal deep-sea species, excluding the Gulf of Mexico, Caribbean and far western North Atlantic. It is relatively uncommon and little is known about its population status, habitats or ecology. There are no known major threats to R. loricata, and its habitat is unlikely to be impacted by anthropogenic threats. Therefore, R. loricata is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Rondeletia loricata is a mesopelagic to bathypelagic species, found to 1,400 m depth. There is only limited evidence for diel vertical migrations, but larvae and small juveniles are typically found in the upper 200 m (Paxton in press). The maximum reported size is 11.0 cm, but individuals are more common to 9.0 cm (Paxton in press).
threats: There are no known threats to R. loricata.
population: Rondeletia loricata is a rare, meso- to bathy-pelagic species, with over 150 specimens known (Paxton in press).
range: Rondeletia loricata is circumglobally distributed in tropical to temperate seas, except for the Gulf of Mexico, Caribbean and far western central Atlantic (Paxton in press). It is known to 1,400 m, but larvae and juveniles are typically found in the upper 200 m (Paxton in press). It has been reported from Iceland (Jonsson 1992), the Indian Ocean between 20°N and 39°S, the Pacific Ocean between 45°N and 42°S, the South China Sea and East China Sea (Paxton and Blake 1990).
useTrade: Rondeletia loricata is of no commercial importance and is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This species is known from the tropical eastern Atlantic and has been recorded to depths of 600 to 2,000 m. This species appears to be somewhat rarely collected and there are no known species-specific threats to D. danae. There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for D. danae, therefore it is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Dolopichthys danae is known from only female specimens, rhe largest known female specimen is 11.5 cm (SL).
threats: There are no known species-specific threats to D. danae.
population: This species is somewhat rare, a search of museum collection databases revealed three lots (FishNet2 database searched June 2014).
range: This species is known from the tropical eastern Atlantic and has been recorded to depths of 600-2,000 m (Pietsch 2009, Pietsch in press). There is a single record from the northeastern Pacific that belongs to Oregon State University, but there are no other records of this species in the Pacific Ocean. It is known from both sides of the North Atlantic between 30-40°N and the type locality at 8°N 44°W. There are NHM London records of this species from off northeastern Brazil, the central Atlantic and from off Western Sahara to Senegal.
useTrade: There is no use and trade information available for this species, although it is unlikely to be utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for D. danae.

rationale: Scopeloberyx robustus can be found in tropical and subtropical waters. There can be little said about the population, habitats and ecology. This species does not have any species-specific threats but can be caught as by-catch in deep water trawls. This species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Species of Melamphaidae eat gelatinous organisms and small crustaceans (Moore in press).
threats: This species is not commercially important but it can be caught in deep-water trawls.
population: There is no information about the population.
range: Scopeloberyx robustus can be found in tropical and subtropical (and temperate) waters of all oceans besides the Arctic and Mediterranean Sea (Moore in press). Scopeloberyx robustus can be found at depths between zero and 4,740 m and is bathypelagic. Adults are typically found below 500 metres.
useTrade: This is not a commercially important species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts in place.

rationale: Syngnathus leptorhynchus is listed as Least Concern based on its large geographic range, lack of direct threats, and various studies reporting the species as common. Habitat degradation of eelgrass (Zostera marina) ecosystems, in which S. leptorhynchus spends much of its life, could produce future concern should habitat quality and quantity decrease. Continued monitoring of eelgrass habitats is necessary to understand changes in the range and populations of S. leptorhynchus.
habitat:
Syngnathus leptorhynchus is found at depths to 150 metres in near-shore eelgrass (Zostera marina) beds, in which it spends much of its life cycle (de Graaf 2006). It has also been documented over sand and pebble substrates (R. Pollom pers. ob.), and has been found between habitat patches, indicating mobility and dispersal between suitable habitat locations. Zostera marina is the most widely distributed seagrass throughout temperate waters in the Pacific (and Atlantic) oceans in the northern hemisphere.

This species can be used as an indicator species for monitoring eelgrass habitats because of its dependency on these habitats and its important role in the biomass (as a common resident) and functional ecology (as an important role in the production of organic detritus) of eelgrass beds (Fritzsche 1980, de Graaf 2006).

This species feeds on small crustaceans and other zooplankton. As with most other members of the Syngnathidae, S. leptorhynchus relies on stealth and camouflage to catch unsuspecting prey (Flammang et al. 2009). Several studies have reported parasites in these fish, including Gyrodactilids (Cone et al. 2013) and nematodes (Moravec et al. 2001), though it is not clear how prevalent they are, whether they are causing a decline in fitness, or how they affect S. leptorhynchus populations.

The reproductive strategy of S. leptorhynchus is polygyny, in which males mate with multiple females (Wilson 2009). The species lives 1-2 years, and can have up to 12 broods of several hundred young.
threats:
Syngnathus leptorhynchus is affected by habitat loss due to coastal development and sedimentation. There is suspected eelgrass loss across its range, significantly so in two of the coast’s largest estuaries, Puget Sound and San Francisco Bay, both home to S. leptorhynchus (Green and Short 2003). Eelgrass habitats are also naturally fragmented in distribution and have shown increasing fragmentation due to human activities. The fragmented nature of eelgrass habitat may affect local abundance and dispersal of S. leptorhynchus. Various studies have demonstrated declines in pipefish abundance with changes in water temperature, increased levels of pollution, and decreased area of eelgrass habitat (Fritzsche 1980, de Graaf 2006). In Barkley Sound, British Columbia, S. leptorhynchus was found to be absent or in low abundance in eelgrass habitats where visibility was reduced due to high levels of suspended sediments. Visibility is important for successful foraging as pipefish will sit and wait for passing prey. A decreased visibility will affect this success, and therefore this species is likely vulnerable to coastal land-use practices that increase erosion (de Graaf 2006).

In addition to these threats to eelgrass systems, an invasive species (Zostera japonica) has established itself throughout most of the range of S. leptorhynchus. Although not predicted to directly compete with native Z. marina, it's unclear whether the ecosystem shifts associated with this invasive seagrass will have effects on either Z. marina habitat cover or Syngnathus leptorhynchus populations (Harrison and Bigley 1982; J. B. Marliave, Vancouver Aquarium, pers. comm).

Overall, eelgrass habitat loss is not considered to be a large enough threat to S. leptorhynchus to warrant a threatened status, as Z. marina is currently listed as Least Concern itself (Short et al. 2010). The species is also capable of utilizing areas with pebble or cobble substrate, but more research into how the species uses different habitat types throughout its life cycle is needed.
population: While exact population numbers for Syngnathus leptorhynchus are unknown, studies have reported the species as being locally common in some areas. The species has been reported as abundant in eelgrass beds sampled throughout Barkley Sound, southwestern Vancouver Island, British Columbia (n=30-50 at each of 17 study sites) (de Graaf 2006). They were also found to be the most abundant species collected in a study in Humboldt Bay, northern California (n=3,654 of 15,935 fish caught of 12 species; 22.4% of all fish caught) (Lomeli 2011). Further research is needed to determine abundances throughout the species range.
range: Syngnathus leptorhynchus has the northernmost and one of the widest distributions of any Syngnathus species (Orsi et al. 1991). It is found in the coastal waters of the Eastern Pacific ocean, from Prince William Sound, Alaska, USA to Bahia Santa Maria, Baja California, Mexico.
useTrade: This species is not known from trade.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures in place for this species. The range of the species does overlap with multiple protected areas.

rationale: Valenciennea wardii is recorded from the Indo-Pacific. It is relatively rare but has a broad distribution. It is sometimes found in the aquarium trade, however, this is not thought to be a major threat. There are no other major threats known, and the species likely occurs in marine protected areas in parts of its range. The species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This burrowing, microinvertivore forms mating pairs to produce benthic egg clutches (Brendl and Bellwood 2014). It is usually found in pairs above silty-sandy areas of shallow lagoon reefs and also inhabits coastal bays and inner reefs usually on silty slopes (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001, Allen and Erdmann 2012). The maximum recorded length is 12.3 cm total length (Allen and Erdmann 2012).
threats: No major threats are known for V. wardii. The species is infrequently collected for the aquarium trade; however, this is unlikely to be a major threat to it.
population: Population data are limited for V. wardii. The species is relatively rare (H. Larson pers. comm. 2015). Hoese and Larson (1994) report this species to be extremely rare.
range: Valenciennea wardii is known from widely scattered localities in the Indo-West Pacific, ranging from the Red Sea and Tanzania (Zanzibar) to Maldives, Thailand, Myanmar, East China Sea, Indonesia (West Papua), Philippines, Vietnam and Malaysia, north to Japan (Ryukyu Islands and Suzaki, south to Australia (western Australia and Great Barrier Reef) and New Caledonia (Hoese and Larson 1994, Allen and Erdmann 2012). It inhabits depths of between 12 and 35 m (Allen and Erdmann 2012).
useTrade: This species is collected for the aquarium trade; although it is rarely seen (Saltcorner 2016).
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place for V. wardii. The species' range overlaps with some marine protected areas (IUCN and UNEP 2014), for example the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park in Australia.

rationale: Brown Catshark (Apristurus brunneus) is a little-known deepwater catshark from the outer continental shelf and upper slope of the Eastern Pacific, known from depths of 33-1,298 meters. This species is oviparous with an egg incubation period of possibly two years or more. Size at 50% maturity is reported to be 514 mm total length for males, and 501 mm total length for females, however maturity varied by latitude in females with those at lower latitudes reaching maturity more quickly than those at higher latitudes. Although this catshark is reported to be a relatively common bycatch in deepwater trawl fisheries, insufficient catch and biological information are available to assess its extinction risk  beyond Data Deficient. Species-specific monitoring of catches should be undertaken.
habitat:
Brown Catshark is a little-known demersal and mid-water deepwater shark that occurs on the outer continental shelf and upper slope from depths of 33-1,298 m. It inhabits cold water (5-8°C), and thus tends to occur shallower in the northern parts of its range (i.e., 137-360 m off British Columbia; Castro 2011) and deeper in southern parts of its range (i.e., 656-932 m off southern California; Roedel 1951).

Reproduction is oviparous with a single egg at a time per oviduct and an incubation period of possibly two or more years (Flammang 2005). Egg cases are about 5 cm long and 2.5 cm wide, with long tendrils that are probably used to attach them to hard substrates and/or biogenic structures. Within the Monterey Bay Canyon possible nursery grounds were identified to be locations at the shelf-slope break, upper continental slope, high vertical relief with rugose substrate, and circulation water currents (Flammang et al. 2011). In Canadian waters females carry egg cases from February to August, but are usually gravid in all months in the southern regions (Flammang et al. 2008, Ebert et al. 2013). Size at hatching is estimated to be 7 cm (Clemens and Wilby 1946). Size at 50% maturity is reported to be 514 mm total length (TL) in males, and 501 mm TL in females, however maturity varied by latitude in females with those at lower latitudes reaching maturity more quickly than those at higher latitudes (Flammang et al. 2008).
threats: Brown Catshark is commonly taken as bycatch in deepwater trawl fisheries. Deepwater fisheries have expanded at an annual rate of 62.5 m depth per decade from 1950-2004 (Watson and Morato 2013). If they continue to expand the impact on this species should be assessed. Species-specific identification is often challenging due to the soft bodies of these sharks, which are often damaged during the fishing process (Castro 2011).
population: This catshark is considered abundant from British Columbia, Canada to northern and southern California (Roedel 1951, Cross 1988, Castro 2011).
range: Brown Catshark is found in the eastern Pacific Ocean from southern Alaska (Wilson and Hughes 1978) to southern California (Roedel and Ripley 1950) and the Gulf of California (Taylor 1972). It is also found in Central and South America in Panama, Ecuador, Peru, and Chile (Andrade and Pequeno 2008, Ebert et al. 2013, Bustamante et al. 2014).
useTrade: This species is not known to be utilized.
conservationActions: There are no management measures currently in place for this species.

rationale:
The Filetail Catshark (Parmaturus xaniurus) is an eastern Pacific endemic deepwater catshark ranging from Washington (USA) to the Gulf of California (Mexico). Adults are epibenthic and found near areas of rocky vertical relief over soft mud bottoms on the outer continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 91 to 1,251 m, juveniles are mesopelagic, found around 500 m off the bottom in waters over 1,000 m deep. This oviparous species deposits eggcases throughout the year with concentrated reproductive output July through September. This catshark is not targeted by commercial fisheries or utilized for human consumption, but is known to be incidental catch in longline and bottom trawl fisheries, although no species-specific data are available.

While no species-specific management plans have been put in place, along the west coast of the United States a groundfish management plan has been implemented, and in northern and central California bottom trawl vessels have become reduced and restricted due to the development of marine protected areas. In Mexico, no management exists, however this species was assumed to be outside of the reach of artisanal gillnet and trawl fisheries. Given that groundfish fisheries within at least half of the distribution of this catshark are under management (along the west coast of the United States), that this species was among the most common chondrichthyan caught during west coast trawl surveys between 2003 and 2011, and that this species appears to be out of artisanal trawl and gillnet reach in Mexico, the Filetail Catshark is assessed as Least Concern. However, there is an urgent need for species-specific data to confirm this status, and once such data become available, this species should be reassessed as a priority.
habitat:
Adults are epibenthic and usually found near areas of rocky vertical relief over soft mud bottoms on the outer continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 91 to 1,251 m; juveniles (<32 cm total length (TL)) are mesopelagic, found up to around 500 m off the bottom in waters over 1,000 m deep (Lee 1969, Ebeling et al. 1970, Cross 1988, Ebert 2003).

This is an oviparous species, producing one egg case per oviduct at a time. Females deposit egg cases throughout the year with the greatest oviposition occurring July through September (Cross 1988, Flammang 2005), thus indicating relatively high fecundity, although gestation may take up to 24 months. These sharks show site-fidelity in their egg case deposition sites, and these sites are in different locations than where the adults are typically found. The egg case nursery areas are found between 300 and 400 m depths at the shelf-slope break and upper continental slope with high vertical relief, rocky substrate, and circulating currents (Flammang et al. 2011). Males mature between 37.5 to 45 cm TL and females at 42.5-50 cm TL (Cross 1988; Ebert et al. 2013). Hatchlings are 7-9 cm TL (Ebert 2003). This species reaches a maximum of 61 cm TL (Cross 1988, Flammang 2005).
threats:
This species is not presently targeted by commercial fisheries or utilized for human consumption, but is caught as incidental catch in sablefish trap, longline and bottom trawl fisheries. Specific catch data are not available.

Trawl fisheries have operated between 20-2,000 m depth, which is throughout the depth range of this species. However, adults primarily inhabit areas of rocky vertical relief (mostly in depths of 300 to 600 m) which act as a natural refuge from trawl fisheries. This is also true for egg cases, which are often deposited in rocky environments. Egg cases of the Filetail Catshark are susceptible to predation by Thornyhead Rockfishes (Sebastolobus spp.), sea stars, and boring gastropods. The longline fisheries in the range of this species generally operate anywhere from 50 to 550 m. Longlines are laid over the rocky areas and are far more likely to catch adults of this species on a regular basis, as well as juveniles (which use the midwater area as a nursery). Purse seines targeting the market squid Loligo opalescens operate in midwater environments within the range of this species, and while they have the potential to impact the Filetail Catshark, there are no reports of bycatch of this species in this fishery.

In Mexico, artisanal trawl and gillnet fisheries did not encounter the Filetail Catshark when surveys were conducted in fishing communities along the coast of mainland Sonora from 1998 to 1999. The authors considered this species to be outside of the reach of these fisheries (Bizzarro et al. 2009a). However, little information is known and the situation in Mexico needs to be monitored.

In the United States, fishing pressure is thought to be unlikely to increase in the near future. Most of the trawling operations along the west coast of the United States are becoming more limited and are heavily restricted. As long as there are limits on rockfish fisheries, there will be limited groundfishing in these waters.
population: Nothing is known on the abundance or population structure of this species, but it is reported to be fairly common (Ebert 2003). This species was one of the most commonly encountered cartilaginous fishes during the standardized, annual West Coast Groundfish Bottom Trawl Survey (ranges from Cape Flattery, Washington to the U.S.-Mexico border) from 2003 to 2011 (Keller et al. 2014)
range: The Filetail Catshark ranges from Washington, U.S.A. (Flammang et al. 2008) to Baja California Sur, Mexico and the Gulf of California (Gilbert 1892).
useTrade: This species is not known to be utilized.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. While there is a need for species-specific bycatch data from fisheries, catsharks are notoriously difficult to identify and misidentification is common.

On the United States west coast (Washington, Oregon and California), groundfisheries are managed by a federal Groundfish Fishery Management Plan. Although this species is not a focal species of the plan, and no species-specific on the Filetail Catshark will be collected, other chondrichthyans are being managed under this program. Additionally, in California, a network of 29 marine protected areas (MPAs) were implemented in 2007 under California's Marine Life Protection Act, representing approximately 204 square miles (~18%) of state waters in the central coast region (California Department of Fish and Wildlife 2015). Due to these MPAs, most trawlers are restricted to operating in deeper waters, and only in central and northern California. As a result, fishing effort in the California trawl fishery has been reduced, and catches of this species have also likely been reduced (D. Ebert pers. obs. 2007).

No species-specific conservation measures exist for this species in Mexico. The absence of this species in artisanal fishing surveys (Bizzarro et al. 2009a,b) suggests that this species is likely beyond the reach of these fisheries in the waters surrounding Baja California Sur.

rationale:
Leopard Shark (Triakis semifasciata) is one of the most common nearshore sharks along the Pacific coast of North America, ranging from Washington to Mazatlan, Mexico, including the Gulf of California. They appear to exhibit limited long distance movement, and as a result it is thought that the population consists of three regional population clusters in northern California, southern California and Mexico with limited genetic exchange.

In California, where nearly all of the U.S. harvest occurs, the Leopard Shark is taken primarily by recreational anglers, although it is also caught incidentally in commercial fisheries. The species has also been harvested for the cold-water aquarium trade and has been highly prized for its distinctive markings and hardiness. Due to its rather limited geographical range and limited exchange among regional stocks, resident stocks near large population centres may be particularly vulnerable to heavy localized fishing pressure. However, this species does not appear to be at risk judging by the combined landings in relation to previously calculated estimates of fishing mortality and exploitation rates. Additionally, current conservation and regulatory actions enacted by the California Department of Fish and Wildlife appear to have reduced these rates and have contributed significantly toward protecting this species from excessive harvesting in recent years and there is evidence that the leopard shark population has been increasing as a result of these management actions.

Little is known of the biology, historical population abundance and full extent of harvest of this species in Mexican waters, but it is estimated to be less than one percent of the Pacific Ocean catch off Baja California and rarely caught in the Gulf of California. As a result of the success of the conservation measures taken in the U.S. and the lack of a significant fishery in Mexican waters, this species is assessed as Least Concern. However, due to the fact that this species is endemic to this region, is subjected to recreational fishing and bycatch pressures (albeit regulated in the U.S.), is susceptible to overfishing due to its life history characteristics (slow growing, long lived, late maturing, low productivity), and is impacted by habitat loss and degradation, it is important to continue managing and monitoring the species to ensure the health of the species.
habitat:
Leopard Shark is a temperate shark of both inshore and offshore continental littoral waters, generally found on or near the bottom in shallow water from the intertidal to 20 m depth, although they have been found as deep as 156 m (Ebert 2003, Love 2011). This species is generally found over soft bottom habitats and around rocky reefs and kelp forests (Ebert 2003). Leopard sharks are relatively eurythermal and euryhaline species, but their distribution is known to be influenced by temperature, salinity, and dissolved oxygen levels (Hopkins and Cech 2003, Hight and Lowe 2007, Carlisle and Starr 2009, Dowd et al. 2010, Nosal et al. 2014). In their survey of Pacific coast estuaries, Emmet et al. (1991) reported that Leopard Shark of all age classes are commonly found in bays and estuaries between San Pedro Bay in Southern California and Humboldt Bay in Northern California, although they are particularly abundant in Elkhorn Slough, San Francisco Bay, Tomales Bay and Humboldt Bay. In southern California, they are known to form large aggregations in San Diego and the Channel Islands (Manley 1995, Hight and Lowe 2007, Nosal et al. 2013a, 2014).

Leopard Shark are seasonally abundant in bays and estuaries (such as Elkhorn Slough, Humboldt Bay, Tomales Bay, Bodega Bay, and San Francisco Bay) during the spring and summer, then during the winter they often move out of the bays to coastal waters as salinity and temperature decrease (Hopkins and Cech 2003, Carlisle and Starr 2009). In San Francisco Bay the population is mainly resident but about 10% move out of the bay in fall and winter (Smith and Abramson 1990). Leopard shark movements in bays and estuaries are strongly influenced by the tidal cycle. Leopard sharks will swim with tidal currents to reduce energetic costs associated with swimming as well as to facilitate foraging over a larger area (Ackerman et al. 2000, Carlisle et al. 2010). During incoming tides they move into shallow mudflats to forage and retreat to deeper water as the tide goes out (Ackerman et al. 2000, Carlisle and Starr 2009, Carlisle and Starr 2010). In exposed coastlines, tides have been shown to drive leopard shark movement between sand flats and rocky reefs (Nosal et al. 2013a). Leopard sharks have been reported to be more active at night (Manley 1995, Ackerman et al. 2000, Carlisle et al. 2010, Nosal et al. 2013a) as their rates of movement are generally higher at night. Manley (1995) reported that acoustically tagged leopard sharks at Santa Catalina Island, California, were more active at night, possibly related to foraging.

Leopard Shark appear to exhibit limited long distance movements, although they are capable of moving relatively large distances rapidly. One shark acoustically tagged at Catalina Island was detected seven days later along the mainland coast, a movement of approximately 105 km through deep water, after which it returned to Catalina Island (Hight and Lowe 2007). There have been several instances of sharks travelling ~100 km distance between Monterey Bay and San Francisco Bay and one shark tagged in San Francisco Bay was recaptured ~600 km away in Santa Monica Bay in southern California 10 years later, but in general, large scale movements appear to be limited (Smith 2001). This is supported by studies that have demonstrated that there is limited genetic exchange between Leopard Shark along different parts of the coast (Lewallen et al. 2007, Barker et al. 2015) and studies that have shown a high degree of site fidelity and potential natal philopatry, with many individuals consistently returning to particular locations (Lewallen et al. 2007, Carlisle and Starr 2009, Nosal et al. 2014, Barker et al. 2015).

Leopard sharks are viviparous, without a yolk sac placenta, and the female produces from 7 to 36 offspring in an annual reproductive cycle. Gestation time is 10-12 months, and size at birth is 17 to 25 cm total length (TL; Ackerman 1971, Kusher et al. 1992, Smith 2001). Age at maturity for females is between 10 and 15 years and 105 to 135 cm TL. Males mature between 7 and 13 years and at 100 to 105 cm TL. The maximum size is 198 cm TL with reports of sharks up to 213 cm TL (Miller and Lea 1972, Feder et al. 1974, Kusher et al. 1992, Smith et al. 2003). Maximum age is at least 25 years, but is estimated to be about 30 years with an estimated generation time of 18.5 years (Cortes 2002).

Pregnant females are believed to exhibit behavioural thermoregulation and aggregate in shallow warm habitats, likely to accelerate embryonic development (Hight and Lowe 2007, Nosal et al. 2013a, 2014). Bays and estuaries appear to be important nursery areas, particularly in central and northern California. Reported nursery areas include Humboldt Bay, San Francisco Bay, Tomales Bay, Bodega Bay, Elkhorn Slough, San Diego Bay and Catalina Harbor (Eigenmann 1891, Bane and Bane 1971, Talent 1985, Smith 2001, Ebert 2003, Carlisle et al. 2007), although Emmet et al. (1991) also reported the presence of juveniles in Morro Bay, Santa Monica Bay, and San Pedro Bay. In central and northern California, parturition appears to occur from March through September, with a peak in April and May (Ackerman 1971, Talent 1985, Smith and Abramson 1990, Ebert and Ebert 2005). In southern California pupping is believed to occur around May and June, although it has been reported to occur as late as September in San Diego Bay (Eigenmann 1891, Smith 2005). Mating is believed to occur shortly after pupping (Ackerman 1971, Talent 1985, Ebert 2003) and has only been observed once in the wild, in the shallow surf zone in La Jolla (Smith 2005). Females may mate with multiple males with as many as 36% of litters having multiple paternity (Nosal et al. 2013b).

Females generally give birth in shallow protected habitats, often over sand or mudflats (Love 2011). In central and northern California, neonates and juveniles are often found in more sheltered, shallow, inshore areas such as bays, mudflats, and tidal creeks (Barry and Cailliet 1983, Carlisle and Starr 2009). In Humboldt and San Francisco Bay, females have been observed releasing their young in beds of eel grass (Ebert 2003, Ebert and Ebert 2005). In southern California pupping and nursery areas are generally thought to be in the surf zone and sheltered coves of more open coast habitats (Smith 2001, Ebert 2003, Hight and Lowe 2007, Nosal et al. 2013). Leopard sharks have been observed giving birth in Catalina Harbor over sandy bottom in water as shallow as 1 m, with pups found in water only 0.3 m deep (Smith 2001).
threats:
Leopard Sharks appear to be primarily caught in Californian waters. The commercial and recreational catch of leopard sharks in the extreme northerly part of its range in Oregon is thought to be negligible (Emmett et al. 1991, Pacific Fisheries Information Network (PacFIN), Recreational Fisheries Information Network (RecFIN)).

In California, where nearly all of the U.S. harvest occurs, the leopard shark is taken primarily by recreational anglers. The recreational leopard shark catch is much more extensive than the commercial catch for this species. Leopard sharks have been recreationally harvested by angling with baited hooks from piers, jetties, beaches, banks and skiffs, bow fishing in shallow waters, and spearfishing by divers. Estimated recreational landings in California between 1980 and 1995, for years when data were collected, averaged over 138 metric tons (mt) annually. After a peak in 1987 of around 546 mt, recreational landings declined and from the mid 1990’s to 2006 remained relatively lower and stable at around 46 mt (PacFIN, Smith and Horeczko 2006). Since 2006, recreational catch has decreased from prior levels (RecFIN).

Commercially, leopard sharks are taken incidentally in gillnet, longline and trawl fisheries although there is a small targeted hook-and-line fishery in San Francisco Bay (Smith and Horeczko 2006).
