The catches of "Sei" Whales recorded off Angola, the Congo, Gabon, and countries in the Gulf of Guinea in the 20th century were probably mainly Bryde's Whales (Weir 2010). Platform-of-opportunity surveys of cetaceans in these waters during 2004-09 resulted in only one Sei Whale sighting out of over 3,000 cetacean sightings, including 88 sightings of Brydes Whales (Weir 2011). Catches off western South Africa (Saldanha Bay) and eastern South Africa (Durban) peaked in spring and autumn, and are suggestive of populations on migration routes (Horwood 1987). One specimen is known from the northwest cost of Java, Indonesia (Flower 1865). The overall winter distribution in the Southern Hemisphere remains poorly known, but winter sightings of Sei Whales including newborns close to the Vitória-Trindade Seamount Chain in Brazil suggest that Trindade Island and Martin Vaz Archipelago may represent a wintering ground for this species (Heissler et al. 2016).
useTrade: Commercial hunting of Sei Whales ceased in the late 20th century, but catches under Special Permit resumed in the North Pacific in 2004 at the level of 100 per year (increased to 134 per year in 2017; IWC 2018b). The products are sold on Japanese domestic markets. The catches are listed on the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) Trade Database as Introduction from the Sea because they are taken in international waters (CITES 2017a).
conservationActions: Sei Whales have been specifically protected from commercial whaling by the IWC since 1975 in the North Pacific and 1979 in the Southern Hemisphere. They have also been protected by the general moratorium on commercial whaling since 1986, although this does not cover catches taken under scientific permit. This species is included in CITES Appendix I although Iceland has held a reservation against this listing since 2000. Japan has no reservation on the Appendix I listing for North Pacific Sei Whales, and the continued catches are currently the subject of a compliance investigation by the CITES Secretariat (CITES 2017b). The species is listed on Appendix II of the Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals.

rationale: Atractoscion nobilis is relatively widespread in the Eastern Pacific from Alaska to the Gulf of California. This species has been historically over-fished. The population in the United States is still low relative to historical levels but has increased over the past 30 years due to fishery regulations and a captive breeding program. While management efforts have aided in the recovery of this species, on-going monitoring shows that the species' recovery remains dependent on these conservation efforts. Given the on-going population recovery and its widespread range, this species is listed as Least Concern. Additional survey work and continued monitoring of this species is required, especially for the disjunct subpopulation in the Gulf of California whose status is unknown, but suspected to be in serious decline from over-fishing.
habitat: This demersal fish often occurs in schools over rocky and sandy bottoms, near kelp forests to depths of 120 m and can be found in the surf zone, with young fish found in bays and along sandy beaches (Eschmeyer et al. 1983, Hervas et al. 2010). Adults occur in schools but also as solitary individuals and older juveniles concentrate in shallow areas close to the surf zone (Romo-Curiel et al. 2015). This species feeds on fishes, squids, and crayfish (Hart 1973). Spawning occurs nearshore in spring and summer with a peak in June (Donohoe 1997) and forms spawning aggregations in shallow coastal waters (Aablers and Sepulveda 2012). The maximum recorded length for this species is 160 cm. Males attain sexual maturity at about 42 cm standard length (SL) and females around 54 cm SL (Clark 1930). This species can live to at least 28 years of age (Romo-Curiel et al. 2015). The estimated median mortality rate for wild individuals is 16.5 year-1(Lorenzen 2006).
threats: This species has been historically over-fished throughout its distribution. Its population has declined since the early part of this century, corresponding to a decline in landings since the late 1920s. Its range is now probably reduced as few are found regularly north of Point Conception, in northern California. In addition to over-fishing, pollution and habitat destruction have probably contributed to this long-term population decline and range reduction. The subpopulation within the Gulf of California, from approximately Guaymas northward, appears to be completely disjunct and is still heavily fished by gillnet. No population data exists but the species in this region is suspected to be in serious decline.
population:
This species was previously an important fishery species and was moderately exploited in California causing population decline. The population of this species off the coast of California appears to have increased over the past two decades due to improved management efforts (Leung and Allen 2016). Combined commercial and recreational landings increased slightly from 342 t in 2008 to 364 t in 2010 (California Cooperative Fisheries Investigations 1999, 2011). The stock of this species off California is estimated to be at 27% of its unfished level. The Pacific Fishery Management Council policy recommends a biomass target of at least 40% with a minimum threshold of 25%, below which a stock is considered overfished (Valero and Waterhouse 2016). Total recreational and commercial harvest for the 2016-2017 season was about 198 t, equivalent to 33% of the total allowable catch (Department of Fish and Wildlife 2018). Commercial landings for the 2015-2016 and 2016-2017 seasons were 27% and 24% less, respectively than the previous 5-season running averages, meeting the overfished criterion for the commercial fishery. CPUE for juvenile recruit decreased in 2017 by 17% from the previous 5-year average (Department of Fish and Wildlife 2018). 

There is a single breeding population of A. nobilis that is centred off Baja California, Mexico (Moser et al. 1983, Vojkovich and Reed 1983). Annual catches of this species in the Gulf of California declined from more than 110 t in 2001 to fewer than 15 t in 2007. Catches subsequently increased to a peak in 2013, dropped dramatically in 2014 and increased to 2013-levels in 2015 with no significant trends observed in CPUE between 2001 and 2015 (Cota-Nieto et al. 2018).
range: This species is endemic to the Eastern Pacific, and is found from Juneau, Alaska south to Magdalena Bay, Baja California, Mexico (Thomas 1968, Hervas et al. 2010). This species occurs from the surf zone to 245 m depth (Donohoe 1997, Romo-Curiel et al. 2015, Aalbers and Sepulved 2015).
useTrade: This is an important commercial and recreational species in the United States and Mexico. Fisheries and various regulations (gear restrictions, bag limits, closed seasons, minimum size limits etc) have been in place in the U.S. since the 1930s with the fishery in Mexican waters established since the 1950s (Vojkovich and Reed 1983). Up until 1982, this species comprised as much as 89% of the annual catch landed by the U.S. commercial fleet (CalCOFI 2009). Populations are recovering due to fishery regulations along the coast of California that have placed restrictions on recreational fisheries and banned further commercial catch of this species (gill nets are prohibited). No population information exists for the subpopulation in the Gulf of California, but it is suspected to be in decline due to continued intensive fishing with gill nets.
conservationActions:
There is a captive breeding program in California for this species, and numerous fishery regulations now in place to help restore this species population, including restrictions on recreational fisheries and further commercial catch of this species (gill nets are prohibited). In March 2004, legislation was enacted to prohibit increased fishing production of the species (Legislation number: NOM-009-PESC-1993). Research is needed to determine the status of the subpopulation of this species in the Gulf of California. Mexico does not have a specific management strategy for A. nobilis but is management by non species-specific regulations (Romo-Curiel et al. 2015). There are currently a number of regulations in place for this species including a minimum landing size of 71 cm TL, bag limits, gear restriction, and closure during the spawning season (mid March to mid June) (Kent et al. 1995, Hervas et al. 2010). 

The large numbers of small individuals of this species caught in recent years suggests that the warm water period beginning with the 1982-1983 El Niño event helped to increase young fish survival. Young fish surveys conducted in southern California as part of Ocean Resources Enhancement and Hatchery Program (OREHP), showed a dramatic increase in the number of fish taken in research gillnet sets. During research work in 1997 over 600 juvenile fish were captured, in 1998 approximately 700 individuals were taken, and in 1999 slightly over 1,300 juveniles were captured. from 1986 to 2006, over 1.13 million cultured individuals of A. nobilis were released on to coastal waters off southern California (Hervas et al. 2010). Anecdotal evidence from commercial and sport fishers also suggests a dramatic increase in juvenile A. nobilis; however, it is unknown whether this increase in juveniles will subsequently enhance the adult spawning population (Vojkovich and Crooke 2001).

rationale: This species is relatively widespread in the Eastern Pacific, and is common in at least some parts of its range. However, it is threatened by intensive fisheries in the southern part of its range. More information is needed to determine the impact of gill-netting and shimp trawling on this species' population, especially in the Gulf of California. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This demersal species is often found in caves and crevices of exposed coasts and open bays in California to depths of 100 m. The disjunct subpopulation in the northern Gulf of California occurs on sandy/muddy bottoms. This species can live to at least 21 years old. This species spawns in late spring and summer (Miller et al. 2008). Maximum recorded length is 42 cm total length.
threats: The disjunct subpopulation in the northern Gulf of California is likely in decline due to capture as by-catch in shrimp trawl fisheries and probably gillnet fisheries.
population: This species is moderately common through most of its range, except for in the northern Gulf of California where it is uncommon perhaps due to the shrimp fishery. Peak CPUE was reported to occur along the Palos Verdes Peninsula with annual gillnet the highest in 2000. The highest abundance of this species was recorded in 1997 (Miller et al. 2008).
range: This species is endemic to the Eastern Pacific, and is found from California to southern Baja and the northern Gulf of California. This occurs from 3-100 m depth.
useTrade: This species is likely caught as bycatch in the Gulf of California.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures for this species. More research is needed to determine the impact of fisheries on its population, especially in the Gulf of California.

rationale: Genyonemus lineatus occurs from British Colombia, Canada south to Baja California Sur, Mexico. This species is a component of commercial and recreational fisheries in parts of its range. Recent landings data show dramatic declines but these may be attributed to a decrease in desirability of this species. This species often occurs in the vicinity of wastewater effluent pipes and is known to contain high levels of PCBs and DDTs in its flesh. While these contaminants probably impact reproductive potential, there is no indication of global population decline at this time. It is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species occurs in turbid waters, coastal waters and bays over mud and sand bottoms or in mid-water (Walker 2019) to 183 m depth (Wolfe and Lowe 2015). It is primarily a benthic feeder with their diet consisting of smaller fish, and epibenthic and benthic invertebrates including polychaetes, clams, shrimp and crabs (Meador et al. 2005). This species spawns from November to April with peak spawning occurring in February and March. It is a batch spawner with females releasing batches of 800 to 37,200 eggs, depending on the female size and age. Females spawn on average from 18 to 24 times during the year. This species can live to 12 year of age and has a maximum recorded length of 41 cm (Walker 2019).
threats: Genyonemus lineatus often inhabits nearshore areas in the vicinity of wastewater discharge pipes and are also known for containing high levels of PCBs and DDTs. Adults exposed to such pollutants show impaired reproduction and liver disease (Malins et al. 1987, Cross and Hose 1988).
population: Genyonemus lineatus is considered common and abundant (Moore 2001). The Californian landing of this species has declined from 75 t to 15 t in two decades (California Department of Fish and Game/ NOAA Fisheries Service 2009). While landings have declined dramatically, this may be attributed to the decreased desirably of the species. This species is very abundant on the Mexican coast (H. Espinosa pers. comm 2020).
range: Genyonemus lineatus is distributed from Barkley Sound in British Columbia, Canada to Bahia Magdalena, Baja California Sur, Mexico (Walker 2019). The depth range for this species is 0-183 m (Wolfe and Lowe 2015).
useTrade: Genyonemus lineatus is targeted in commercial and sport fisheries and is sold often sold fresh in markets in California and Mexico. It is taken with hook and line, gill nets, purse seines, trawl nets, and long lines. More recently, this species is considered to be undesirable because of concern regarding toxin levels in the flesh (Walker 2019). This is a low demand species (H. Espinosa pers. comm. 2020).
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation effort in place.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This bathydemersal species has a maximum standard length of 57.5 cm  (Uiblein et al. 2008).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: Population data are limited for this species. It is known from at least 45 specimens (Uiblein et al. 2008).
range: This species is distributed in the North Atlantic from the Mid-Atlantic Ridge and the United Kingdom south to the Azores (Uiblein et al. 2008, Carneiro et al. 2014). A single specimen was identified off British Columbia, Canada (Uiblein et al. 2008, Hanke et al. 2015). Its depth range is 1,772 to 3,677 metres (Uiblein et al. 2008).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This bathydemersal species inhabits bathyal to abyssal environments and has a maximum standard length of 12.6 cm (Nielsen 2018).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: Population data are limited for this species, it is known from at least 19 specimens (Nielsen 2018).
range: This species is distributed in the North Atlantic and northeastern and southwestern Pacific Oceans. It is known from at least 19 widely scattered localities, including southwest of Ireland, off Brittany, France, southwest of Madeira, the Azores, the northeastern Gulf of Mexico (McEachran and Fechhelm 1998), the Solomon Sea, the Kermadec Trench in the Southeast Pacific, the Hikurangi and Bellona Troughs off New Zealand, the Gulf of Panama, northern Chile and the Northeast Pacific. Its depth range is 1,169 - 5,440 metres (Nielsen 2018).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern in view of the large extent of occurrence, large number of subpopulations, large population size, and lack of major threats. Trend over the past 10 years or three generations is uncertain but likely to be relatively stable, or the species may be declining but not fast enough to qualify for any of the threatened categories under Criterion A (reduction in population size). Landlocked populations in Sweden, central Finland and Karelia (Russian Federation/Finland) are locally threatened.
habitat: Salt, brackish, and fresh shallow, cold coastal waters from 20 m to intertidal zone; estuaries; coastal rivers as far as 200 km from sea; resident "relics" in some lakes (most abundant at depths below 75 m in Great Lakes). Adults are benthic. Eggs are laid in deep water in a depression constructed on the bottom. Larvae are pelagic.
threats: Localized threats may exist, but on a range-wide scale no major threats are known.
population:
This species is common and is represented by a large number of subpopulations and locations. Total adult population size is unknown but relatively large.

See Houston (1990) for status in Canada.
range: Circumpolar; from Barents Sea to Bering Sea in Palearctic, Alaska to Labrador, and James Bay to Ellesmere Island in Nearctic, and Greenland.
conservationActions: Currently, this species is of relatively low conservation concern and does not require significant additional protection or major management, monitoring, or research action.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This benthopelagic species inhabits the lower continental slope to abyssal environments. Its maximum standard length is 14 cm (Nielsen et al 1999; 2019, Mundy et al. 2018).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: Population data are limited. The species is only known from nine specimens collected in 1965, 1970, 1971, 1981, 1995 and 2017 (Nielsen and Eagle 1974, Okiyama and Kato 1997, Nielsen et al. 2019).
range: This species has been recorded in the northeastern Pacific 700 kilometres off Oregon, U.S.A and in the southwestern Pacific from the Tasman Sea between Lord Howe Island and Norfolk Island, as well as from the Great Australian Bight off South Australia (Nielsen and Eagle 1974; Okiyama and Kato 1997; Nielsen et al. 1999, 2015, 2019). Specimens have been taken at depths between 3,334-4,750 metres (Nielsen and Eagle 1974, Nielsen et al. 2019).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This widely distributed, demersal species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This cryptic, demersal species is primarily confined to coastal margins and is associated with rocky bottoms, where it inhabits caves and crevices (Pietsch and Orr 2015). The maximum standard length is 46 cm (Nielsen et al. 1999).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: This species is relatively rare in the Oregon upwelling zone (Brodeur et al. 2008), but is relatively common in other parts of its range (Nielsen et al. 1999).
range: This species is distributed in the eastern Pacific from Petersburg, Alaska south to northern Baja California, Mexico (Eschmeyer and Herald 1983, Nielsen et al. 1999, Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Page et al. 2013, Pietsch and Orr 2015). Its depth range is 3-256 metres, but usually occurs deeper than 15 m (Nielsen et al. 1999, Pietsch and Orr 2015).
useTrade: This species is not utilized, but it is taken as bycatch in Spot Prawn traps off British Columbia (Favaro et al. 2010). Its flesh is considered sweet and fine-textured, but is rarely available in market (Lamb and Edgell 1986).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Juveniles of the species inhabit the mesopelagic zone, while adults are bathydemersal (Gibbs 1991, Nielsen et al. 1999). It reaches sexual maturity around 5 cm standard length (Gibbs 1991). This species is ovovivparous with planktonic larvae (Ambrose 1996). The maximum standard length is 15.7 cm (Kong et al. 1988).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: This species is reportedly "locally abundant" off central California (Gibbs 1991) and in other parts of its range (Nielsen et al. 1999).
range: This species is distributed in the eastern Pacific from northern Oregon in the United States to northern Baja California, Mexico. It has also been reported from the Gulf of Panama and Chile (Gilbert 1890, Pequeño 1989, Gibbs 1991, Chirichigno and Vélez 1998, Nielsen et al. 1999, Prokofiev 2005, Castellanos-Galindo et al. 2006). Specimens have been taken at depths between 325-1,000 metres (Gibbs 1991, Nielsen et al. 1999), with juveniles mostly at depths between 325-600 m (Nielsen et al. 1999).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This mesopelagic species likely undergoes diel vertical migrations (Baird 1971). It primarily consumes copepods and crustaceans (Collard 1970). In the Gulf of California, its spawning season occurs year-round with peak activity occurring from Autumn to Spring (Funes-Rodríguez et al. 2011). The maximum standard length is 7.6 cm (Kells et al. 2016).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: This species is common and abundant in parts of its range; there are over 1,000 museum records in the iDigBio database (accessed April 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the eastern Pacific from Hawaii to Oregon in the U.S. south to central Chile (Harold 1993, Sielfeld and Kawaguchi 2004, Castellanos-Galindo et al. 2006, Coad 2013, Kells et al. 2016). Records in the Indian, western and central Pacific and Atlantic Oceans (Moore et al. 2002, iDigBio database accessed April 2019) require verification. It inhabits mesopelagic depths and is most abundant at 400 metres (Baird 1971).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This meso- and benthopelagic species undergoes diel vertical migrations (Moser 1996). It predominantly feeds on crustaceans (Fitch and Lavenberg 1968). It most probably spawns in Spring, and is oviparous, with planktonic eggs and larvae (Moser 1996). The largest specimen measured 23 cm total length (Eschmeyer et al. 1983). Its maximum reported age is seven years (Fitch and Lavenberg 1968).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: Population data are limited. There are 245 museum records of this species in the FishNet2 database (accessed April 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the eastern North Pacific from the Bering Sea and Alaska south to Baja California, Mexico (Matarese et al. 1989, McAllister 1990, Sheiko and Fedorov 2000, Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Parin et al. 2014). There is evidence of this species in the Bering Sea, but access to the locality data is limited. Specimens have been taken at depths between 0-1,219 metres (Sheiko and Fedorov 2000).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This meso- and benthopelagic species conducts diel vertical migrations (Parin and Borodulina 1994, Parin and Borodulina 2003, Mundy 2005). The largest specimen measured 11.4 cm standard length (Parin and Borodulina 1994).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: Population data are limited. This species is known from at least 25 specimens (Parin and Borodulina 1994).
range: This species is distributed in the western and central North Pacific transition zone from Japan, the Kyushu-Palau Ridge and adjacent waters to the Emperor Seamounts and the Hawaiian Ridge and slightly eastward between 20°-38°N (Parin and Borodulina 1994, 2003; Nakabo 2002; Shinohara et al. 2005; Mundy 2005; Ivanov and Sukhanov 2015). A record from Taiwan (iDigBio database accessed April 2019) requires verification. Specimens have been collected at depths between 35-500 metres (Mundy 2005).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This benthopelagic species inhabits abyssal depths (Fujii et al. 2010). Its maximum standard length is 27.5 cm (Nielsen and Merrett 2000).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: This species is known from at least 19 specimens (Orr et al. 2005).
range: This species is distributed in the North Pacific from the Ogasawara Islands of Japan to the Kuril Islands, the Sea of Okhotsk, the Bering Sea to Midway Island and Vancouver, Canada (Nielsen and Merrett 2000, Orr et al. 2005, Mundy 2005, Hanke et al. 2015). Specimens have been collected in nets fishing between 0 to 6,930 metres, but it is suspected the species does not occur as deep as 6,930 m (Fujii et al. 2010).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation actions.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a mainly mesopelagic species, but can also occur in the bathypelagic zone (Matarese et al. 1989). The largest specimen measured 16 cm total length (Eschmeyer et al. 1983).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: Population data are limited. There are 309 museum records of this species in the iDigBio database (accessed April 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the northeastern Pacific from Alaska (U.S.) and British Columbia (Canada), including the Gulf of Alaska, to Baja California, Mexico (Matarese et al. 1989, McAllister 1990, Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Castellanos-Galindo et al. 2006). Records from further south (iDigBio database accessed April 2019) require verification. Specimens have been taken at mainly mesopelagic depths and bathypelagic to about 1,800 metres (FishNet2 database accessed July 2019).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This meso- to upper bathypelagic species has a maximum standard length of 29 cm (Childress et al. 1980, Castellanos-Galindo et al. 2006).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: There are 190 museum records of this species in the iDigBio database (accessed March 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the central and eastern Pacific from Oregon in the USA to central Chile and well offshore towards French Polynesia (Pequeno 1989, Castellanos-Galindo et al. 2006, iDigBio database accessed March 2019). It inhabits mesopelagic and upper bathypelagic depths from 500 to 1,800 metres (Janssens et al. 2000, Castellanos-Galindo et al. 2006).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation actions.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species is common and abundant in parts of its range. There are no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a mesopelagic species. Spawning occurs year-round, but increases during late autumn and winter (Doyle 1992). Its maximum total length is 29.3 cm (Orlov and Binohlan 2009).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: This species is relatively abundant off Oregon (Bosley et al. 2004) and in the Bering Sea (Orlov and Binohlan 2009), and likely elsewhere in its range. There are over 1,700 museum records of this species in the FishNet2 database (accessed March 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the northern Pacific from Japan to the Bering Sea, Canada, the USA south to the Gulf of California, Mexico (Doyle 1992, Nakabo 2002, Parin et al. 2014, Pietsch and Orr 2015, iDigBio database accessed March 2019). It inhabits mesopelagic depths to about 800 metres (FishNet2 database accessed July 2019).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation actions.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species is common and abundant in parts of its range. There are no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This meso- to bathypelagic species inhabits continental slopes, open ocean and seamounts (Miya and Nemoto 1987, Mundy 2005, Shao et al. 2008, Chen et al. 2012). Its diet consists mainly of copepods and ostracods (Gordon et al. 1985). It is an iteroparous and protandrous species with a protracted spawning season from early spring to late autumn (May to November) (Miya and Nemoto 1987; 1991). Sex change occurs around 3-3.5 cm standard length (Miya and Nemoto 1987). Sexual maturity is reached at age 3 and 2.2 cm for males and ≤ age 4 and 3.9 cm for females (Miya and Nemoto 1985; 1991). The maximum standard length is 6.2 cm (Nazarkin 2015).
threats: <span id="docs-internal-guid-b572902d-7fff-6a30-a704-57f40dc88b10">There are no known major threats.
population: This is a common and abundant midwater species north of 45°N (Beamish et al. 1999). In the western North Pacific, it ranks high in both abundance and biomass (Miya and Nemoto 1987, Miya et al. 1995). It is one of the most dominant mesopelagic species of Sagami Bay, Japan (Miya and Nemoto 1985, Sassa and Kawaguchi 2006).
range: This species is distributed in the Pacific from the South China Sea, Taiwan, and Japan to the Bering Sea, the Hawaiian Islands, Alaska, USA south to Baja California, Mexico (Gordon et al. 1985, Randall and Lim 2000, Mundy 2005, Sassa and Kawaguchi 2006, Shao et al. 2008, Shinohara et al. 2009, Chen et al. 2012). It has also been recorded off western Panama (Castellanos-Galindo et al. 2006). Records from the Atlantic, Indian Ocean and South Pacific (iDigBio database accessed July 2019) require verification. Its depth range is 300-2,400 metres (Miya and Nemoto 1987, Mundy 2005).
useTrade: <span id="docs-internal-guid-0687bafd-7fff-9c2f-abe4-e332c96876ec">This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: <span id="docs-internal-guid-4497cb44-7fff-92ce-90c0-f1e7c86c5c74">There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species is common and abundant in parts of its range. There are no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This meso- to bathypelagic species inhabits canyons (Widder et al. 1989, Rodriguez-Grańa and Castro 2003, Mundy 2005, Jiménez-Rosenberg et al. 2007). It possibly undergoes diel vertical migrations (A. Harold pers. comm. 2019). Its diet consists of copepods and ostracods (DeWitt and Cailliet 1972). Spawning occurs year-round with peak activity from summer to autumn (Funes-Rodríguez et al. 2006, Funes-Rodríguez et al. 2011). The maximum standard length is 3.6 cm (Davison et al. 2015).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: This is an abundant species off Oregon (Davison et al. 2015) and California in the U.S. (Lara-Lopez et al. 2012).
range: This species is distributed in the central and eastern Pacific from Micronesia and Vanuatu to the Hawaiian Islands and the Aleutian Islands of Alaska in the U.S. south to central Chile (Widder et al. 1989, Beamish et al. 1999, Sandknop et al. 2000, Rodriguez-Grańa and Castro 2003, Mundy 2005, Castellanos-Galindo et al. 2006, Jiménez-Rosenberg et al. 2007). Records from Indonesia and the Indian Ocean (iDigBio database accessed July 2019) require verification. Specimens have been collected at fishing depths between 16-4,938 metres, but the species typically occurs between 200-800 m (Mundy 2005).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This mesopelagic species has a maximum standard length of 5.8 cm (Matarese et al. 1989, Mundy 2005, Kells et al. 2016). It reaches sexual maturity at approximately one year and 3 cm length (Prosch 1991).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: There are over 600 museum records of this species in the FishNet2 database (accessed April 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the Pacific from the Hawaiian Islands to the Brooks Peninsula of British Columbia, Canada south to central Chile (Matarese et al. 1989, Mundy 2005, Kells et al. 2016). This species has been stated to be an east Pacific endemic, but its occurrence in the west Pacific and Indian Ocean are questionable (iDigBio database accessed April 2019). Its depth range is 52-914 metres (Kells et al. 2016).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species is common and abundant in parts of its range. There are no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This bathydemersal to benthopelagic species inhabits the continental slope (Cruz-Acevedo et al. 2018). The maximum standard length is about 24.4 cm (iDigBio database accessed June 2019).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: This species is common and abundant off Peru (Kameya et al. 2003).
range: This species occurs in the eastern Pacific from Oregon and Acapulco, Mexico to central Peru (Nielsen et al. 1999, Robertson et al. 2017, iDigBio database accessed June 2019). Its depth range is 780-1,865 metres (Robertson et al. 2017).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation actions.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a mesopelagic species. The largest known specimen has a standard length of 11.3 cm (Gomon and Gibbs 1975, Mundy 2005).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: This species is only known from six specimens collected in 1965, 1968, 1970, 1980 and 1989 (Gomon and Gibbs 1975, iDigBio database accessed March 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the central North Pacific transition zone between 20° and 35°N, from 150° to 175°E and 142° to 154°W (Japan to the Emperor Seamounts). Specimens have been collected at mesopelagic depths to 450 metres (Gomon and Gibbs 1975).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation actions.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This mesopelagic species likely undergoes diel vertical migrations (Harold 1999, Mundy 2005). Its diet consists mainly of zooplankton, especially crustaceans (Harold 1999). The largest specimen measured 13 cm standard length (Masuda et al. 1984).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: Population data are limited. There are 29 museum records of this species in the iDigBio database (accessed April 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the North Pacific Transition zone from the northern Philippines to Japan and the Emperor Seamounts to British Columbia, Canada and California in the U.S. (Masuda et al. 1984, McAllister 1990, Shinohara et al. 1996, Mundy 2005, Parin et al. 2014). Records from New Caledonia (iDigBio database accessed July 2019) require verification. It inhabits mesopelagic depths to at least 1,000 metres (FishNet2 database accessed July 2019).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This meso- to bathypelagic species has a maximum length of 36 cm (Fitch and Lavenberg 1968).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: Population data are limited for this species, but it is common in museum collections (FishNet2 database accessed April 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the eastern Pacific from Oregon in the U.S. to southern Peru (FishNet2 database accessed April 2019). Records from Japan, China and the south central Atlantic (Nakabo 2002, FishNet2 and iDigBio databases accessed April 2019) require verification. It does not occur in Hawaiian waters (Mundy 2005). It is known to occur to a maximum depth of 1,200 metres (FishNet2 database accessed January 2019).
useTrade: This species is not utilized, but it can be easily taken in midwater trawls as bycatch (Fitch and Lavenberg 1968).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: <span id="docs-internal-guid-bf07a2b8-7fff-ebf5-99c2-186f9edf4b07">This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: <span id="docs-internal-guid-43929843-7fff-6971-8c88-e1c2dce7918b">This meso- to bathypelagic species has a maximum standard length of 9.1 cm. Adults occur deeper than 200 metres (Kotlyar 2011).
threats: <span id="docs-internal-guid-508ea8b6-7fff-ae79-bb05-b0a3cbc4e510">There are no known major threats.
population: <span id="docs-internal-guid-f3ae471f-7fff-4b77-f294-5935358bd204">This species is common in parts of its range (Kotlyar 2011).
range: <span id="docs-internal-guid-82b3b822-7fff-273f-cd68-fdbc332b26ae">This species is distributed in the subarctic to boreal North Pacific between 56°N-29°N or from Hokkaido, Japan to the Bering Sea, Hancock Seamount on the northern Hawaiian Ridge and Alaska south to central Baja California, Mexico (Mundy 2005, Kotlyar 2011). Records from further south in the central and eastern Pacific (iDigBio database accessed May 2019) require verification. Its depth range is 50-3,400 metres (Kotlyar 2011).
useTrade: <span id="docs-internal-guid-f0ce1b36-7fff-8aba-7ece-dbeec5527fb4">This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: <span id="docs-internal-guid-d69e9df6-7fff-cc70-2d0c-860f93bbd2a8">There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: <span id="docs-internal-guid-50c0c705-7fff-dad1-8a17-fba4c2bd26a4">This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: <span id="docs-internal-guid-b5bec431-7fff-da4f-72e9-689b4fb962fd">This meso- to bathypelagic species has a maximum known standard length of 4.9 cm. Adults occur deeper than 200 metres (Kotlyar 2015).
threats: <span id="docs-internal-guid-354b0738-7fff-12bf-f1eb-55a409383d8b">There are no known major threats.
population: <span id="docs-internal-guid-7707391f-7fff-b71d-efb1-4e7dac08b8a7">Population data are limited. There are 233 museum records of this species in the iDigBio database (accessed May 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the northeastern Pacific from northern California in the U.S. to Baja California Sur, Mexico and westwards to 140° W (Kotlyar 2015, iDigBio database accessed May 2019). Its depth range is 0-860 metres, but it probably occurs deeper (Kotlyar 2015).
useTrade: <span id="docs-internal-guid-c82c8a98-7fff-f890-0a86-39dad0c5ae52">This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: <span id="docs-internal-guid-71bc4532-7fff-3906-2e9d-c0eea35df799">There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This species has an extremely large range, and hence does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the range size criterion (Extent of Occurrence <20,000 km<sup>2</sup> combined with a declining or fluctuating range size, habitat extent/quality, or population size and a small number of locations or severe fragmentation). The population trend is inferred to be stable, and so it does not approach the threshold for Vulnerable under the population trend criterion (>30% decline over ten years or three generations). The population size is very large, and hence does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population size criterion (<10,000 mature individuals with a continuing decline estimated to be >10% in ten years or three generations, or with a specified population structure). For these reasons the species is evaluated as Least Concern.
population: The population is estimated to number 120,000-130,000 individuals (Wetlands International 2018). This roughly equates to 80,000-90,000 mature individuals.

rationale: <span id="docs-internal-guid-9a1a8282-7fff-cf7a-0c51-88255e839b72">This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: <span id="docs-internal-guid-c1597d14-7fff-1cb3-a5f9-52f09247d033">This meso- to bathypelagic species has a maximum standard length of 40.8 cm (Pietsch 2009).
threats: <span id="docs-internal-guid-29569bc0-7fff-6acf-3817-e1743a62efdb">There are no known major threats.
population: <span id="docs-internal-guid-87197166-7fff-b4d1-fea7-c934336d7451">This species is only known from 11 specimens (Pietsch 2009).
range: <span id="docs-internal-guid-7bbd245a-7fff-49fd-ee3a-87b6121a5c4b">This species is distributed in the southeastern Indian Ocean and the Pacific from the Sea of Japan, the East China Sea, the Hawaiian Islands, South Australia and northern Oregon and southern California in the USA to Guadalupe Island, Mexico (Pietsch 2009). Its depth range is 0-1,850 metres (Mundy 2005).
useTrade: <span id="docs-internal-guid-2412117b-7fff-da68-b245-5e30b4d6c642">This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: <span id="docs-internal-guid-3728a04c-7fff-9be4-7fb0-5f8f1e1599ee">There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: <span id="docs-internal-guid-1040bb05-7fff-2f17-0955-c5ce7038ac10">This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: <span id="docs-internal-guid-0e1398a8-7fff-ad9b-503a-95ff8c9b5147">This meso- to bathypelagic species has a maximum standard length of 31 cm (Pietsch 2009).
threats: <span id="docs-internal-guid-605ea463-7fff-e7a9-cdba-be92c2ff48ad">There are no known major threats.
population: <span id="docs-internal-guid-0cb16492-7fff-8221-9378-64286677ff2b">This species is only known from 12 female specimens (Pietsch 2009); therefore, its population status is unknown.
range: <span id="docs-internal-guid-2c240cf7-7fff-57d2-893d-c9d8ff4bd311">This species is known from six widely scattered localities in the eastern Pacific from the Hawaiian Islands to Oregon and California in the U.S. south to about 15 degrees South off Peru (Pietsch 2009). Its depths of capture ranges from 0 to 1,175 metres (Mundy 2005, Pietsch 2009).
useTrade: <span id="docs-internal-guid-bc61c5ed-7fff-ce83-fe4e-ef7b5fc194f6">This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: <span id="docs-internal-guid-1248103b-7fff-0c0c-25e5-3e2f081e0fec">There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: <span id="docs-internal-guid-a1ef74c2-7fff-f332-5b04-31f38aee99f9">This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: <span id="docs-internal-guid-246bf2a4-7fff-7a62-3830-4a4db39a190e">This meso- to bathypelagic species has a maximum standard length of 7.1 cm for females and 1.7 cm for males (Pietsch 2002, 2005, Mundy 2005, Stewart and Pietsch 2015).
threats: <span id="docs-internal-guid-47ab3529-7fff-b20c-8624-deeb581c048b">There are no known major threats.
population: <span id="docs-internal-guid-d6e0ee49-7fff-618e-5fe0-4643847f767b">This species is known from at least 27 female specimens (Pietsch 2009).
range: <span id="docs-internal-guid-60a1e4cd-7fff-43a0-8b3a-525379154202">The species is circumglobally distributed. In the Atlantic, it occurs from the Gulf of Mexico, Caribbean Sea and off Florida to central waters at about 29° N, 38° S to Cape Town, South Africa. It is found in the Indian Ocean between 18° to 38° S and in the Pacific from 29° N to 43° S including the Banda Sea, north to the Kuril Islands of Japan south to Western Australia, New South Wales and Tasmania and east to the Hawaiian Islands and southern Chile at 36° S (Mundy 2005, Pietsch 2009, Nakabo 2013, Stewart and Pietsch 2015, OZCAM database accessed August 2018). The depths of capture ranges from 0 to 2,250 metres (Mundy 2005, Stewart and Pietsch 2015).
useTrade: <span id="docs-internal-guid-2cd93f73-7fff-99f2-cb59-c953ba2f186a">This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: <span id="docs-internal-guid-d381f3a2-7fff-d4a8-808e-a22b00accf91">There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: <span id="docs-internal-guid-7359d267-7fff-84c6-5e5f-a3807ff7215c">This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This mesopelagic species prefers cold-temperate waters (Reyes-Bonilla et al. 2010). The maximum standard length is 10.1 cm for females and 1.1 cm for males (Beamish et al. 1999, Pietsch 2009). The male specimen was collected attached to a female, indicating sexual parasitism occurs. It appears to be a relatively shallow-living species compared to others in this group of fishes, as most of the specimen were collected in midwater trawls with maximum depths of either 923 or 679 metres (Pietsch 2009).
threats: <span id="docs-internal-guid-9bb36b87-7fff-44ec-5560-0af092dba6f5">There are no known major threats.
population: <span id="docs-internal-guid-d2117d71-7fff-ae18-24f5-3a3d9c982db1">This species is known from at least 34 female specimens (Pietsch 2009).
range: <span id="docs-internal-guid-a666c4ef-7fff-520a-56ce-46cff73314b4">This species is distributed in the North Pacific from Japan, the Bering Sea to the Gulf of California, Mexico between 24° and 60°N. There is a single record in the central equatorial Pacific at 0°N, 152°W. This species has been collected in midwater trawls fishing between depths of 0-1,160 metres (Pietsch 2009).
useTrade: <span id="docs-internal-guid-ac3897cf-7fff-28cd-2995-3219215b0a21">This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: <span id="docs-internal-guid-0ce80e9b-7fff-5fdd-cbc4-7cf6d7c82293">There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: <span id="docs-internal-guid-97adfb21-7fff-8fdd-694c-7752af030a52">This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This bathypelagic species has a maximum standard length of 10.2 cm (Pietsch 2009). Eggs and larvae are pelagic, descending into deeper waters after metamorphosis (Matarese et al. 1989).
threats: <span id="docs-internal-guid-94d8619e-7fff-4a08-ee08-79814605a299">There are no known major threats.
population: <span id="docs-internal-guid-1f9a1b96-7fff-f21f-6a03-5a7e00112e50">This species is known from at least 49 specimens (Pietsch 2009).
range: This species is distributed in the eastern Pacific from about 46°N, 125°W near British Columbia, Canada south to Peru (Castellanos-Galindo et al. 2006, Pietsch 2009, Reyes-Bonilla et al. 2010, Weil et al. 2014). A few specimens tentatively identified as this species have been recorded off Sumatra and Java, Indonesia and Hawaii (Hsuan-Ching et al. 2016). Its depth range is 300-1,000 metres, but primarily occurs deeper than 450 m (Pietsch 2009).
useTrade: <span id="docs-internal-guid-f8a378c6-7fff-27c3-a511-e8362b2f3b77">This species is not utilized.

rationale: <span id="docs-internal-guid-6f5995c9-7fff-f95f-2ca1-44aabee2551f">This widely distributed, deep-living species is common in parts of its range. There are no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: <span id="docs-internal-guid-39a5f282-7fff-62fa-cce7-da8148bd25fb">This meso- to bathypelagic species has a maximum standard length of 23 cm. It inhabits a water temperature range from 1.75° to 3.45°C (Orlov and Tokranov 2005).
threats: <span id="docs-internal-guid-a466e418-7fff-a732-34b8-1499ffe421c4">There are no known major threats.
population: There are at least 115 known female specimens of this species (Pietsch 2009), and it is considered common off the Kamchatka Peninsula (Orlov and Tokranov 2005, Parin et al. 2014).
range: This species is distributed in the north Pacific (Parin et al. 2014) including Japan and the Sea of Okhotsk off Russia south to 38°S, the Bering Sea to Canada and the western USA to 42°S (Matarese et al. 1989, Parin et al. 2014). The depths of capture ranges from 0 to over 1,310 metres with most specimens collected between 600 and 850 m (Nakabo 2002, Pietsch 2009).

rationale: <span id="docs-internal-guid-856c5b9e-7fff-8171-e038-1c2f6b05bcd4">This widely distributed, deep-living species is common in parts of its range. There are no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: <span id="docs-internal-guid-989bc9a8-7fff-f26b-1742-3d6429dbe5f8">This meso- to bathypelagic species inhabits continental slopes and seamounts (Hughes 1981, Orlov and Tokranov 2005). The maximum total length is 21 cm (Orlov and Tokranov 2005).
threats: <span id="docs-internal-guid-e2c07476-7fff-2b59-a6b3-8d17ae40f1e9">There are no known major threats.
population: <span id="docs-internal-guid-23435ee9-7fff-d495-972a-7de73a885e01">This species is common off the Kuril Islands and southeastern Kamchatka, Russia (Orlov and Tokranov 2005).
range: This species is distributed throughout the North Pacific from Japan (Pietsch 2009, Shinohara et al. 2009), the Sea of Okhotsk, Kuril Islands and southeastern Kamchatka, Russia (Orlov and Tokranov 2005) east to the Gulf of Alaska, Canada to central California in the U.S. (Matarese et al. 1989, Pietsch 2009, Weil et al. 2015, Stephens et al. 2016). Its depth range is 300-1,250 metres (Orlov and Tokranov 2005, Pietsch 2009).

habitat: <span id="docs-internal-guid-83b26851-7fff-0877-a9f7-4287ed5bc0cd">This bathypelagic species has a maximum standard length of 12.1 cm (Kotlyar 2009).

population: <span id="docs-internal-guid-3b685d89-7fff-f27e-45e7-24417fd489cd">Population data are limited. This species is known from at least 10 specimens (Kotlyar 2009).
range: This species is distributed in the North Pacific from southern Japan to the Kamchatka Peninsula to the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands of Alaska south to southern California in the United States. Specimens have been taken at depths between 0-3,263 metres (Kotlyar 2009).

range: <span id="docs-internal-guid-4c8d84d9-7fff-1f79-03e2-eaddc3f615dc">This species is distributed in the North Pacific from northeastern Japan to the Kuril Islands and Gulf of Alaska south to northern California in the United States (Kotlyar 2008, iDigBio database accessed May 2019). Its depth range is 0-8,000 metres (Kotlyar 2008).

Little is known on its distribution, population, ecology and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: <span id="docs-internal-guid-310f0a3d-7fff-814f-65c3-596b3694db63">This mesopelagic species has a maximum standard length of 9.4 cm (Kotlyar 2008).

range: This species is only known from two localities in the northeastern Pacific off southern Alaska in the United States and Haida Gwaii, Canada. It is possible that other records identified as Poromitra crassiceps should be attributed to this species. Specimens have been captured at depths between 708-886 metres (Kotlyar 2008).

habitat: <span id="docs-internal-guid-27f9a516-7fff-a3d4-da5d-005910708553">This bathypelagic species has a maximum standard length of 10.4 cm (Kotlyar 2004).

range: <span id="docs-internal-guid-6b9342c4-7fff-6de9-f851-3c5df3646ae9">This species is distributed in northern Pacific from the Ryukyu Islands of Japan to the Kuril Islands, the Sea of Okhotsk and Bering Sea to the Aleutian Islands of Alaska (Kotlyar 2004). One record was taken from a remote locality about halfway between Hawaii and Washington State in the U.S. (FishNet2 database accessed December 2019). Its depth range is 0-7,190 metres (Kotlyar 2004).

habitat: <span id="docs-internal-guid-e6a98c8b-7fff-110a-f02a-70f81d86f710">This meso- to bathypelagic species has a maximum standard length of 4.9 cm (Peden and Jamieson 1988).
threats: <span id="docs-internal-guid-f029dc01-7fff-443f-d6f5-8037232d8783">There are no known major threats.
population: <span id="docs-internal-guid-72a44598-7fff-e5d9-4d06-b2a1499653e9">Population data are limited. There are over 700 museum records of this species in the iDigBio database (accessed May 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the eastern Pacific between 48°N-25°S, from Washington in the United States to Valparaiso, Chile and westward to 160°W (Ebeling and Weed 1963, Peden and Jamieson 1988, Pequeño 1989, Kotlyar 2004, Fourriére et al. 2016, iDigBio database accessed May 2019). It has been captured in open nets fishing as deep as 675 metres (Peden and Jamieson 1988), but it probably occurs deeper to 1,000 or 2,000 m similar to other Scopelogadus species (J. Moore pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: <span id="docs-internal-guid-e6138a68-7fff-2ef8-b3a1-070b8b308f69">This species is not utilized.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species is common and abundant in parts of its range. There are no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This mesopelagic species inhabits continental shelves and slopes as well as seamounts (Mundy 2005, Sassa and Kawaguchi 2006, Sassa and Konishi 2015, Wang et al. 2017, Chen et al. 2008). Its diet consists of copepods and crustaceans (Gordon et al. 1985, Uchikawa et al. 2001). It is a protandrous species that reaches sexual maturity at 8 cm (Miya and Nemoto 1987, Miya et al. 1995, Salvanes and Kristoffersen 2001, Sadovy de Mitcheson and Liu 2008). The maximum standard length is 15.6 cm (Tatsuta et al. 2014).
threats: <span id="docs-internal-guid-cdc43ef3-7fff-bb59-b4ee-31fe4572ea08">There are no known major threats.
population: This is one of the most abundant and common mesopelagic species in the North Pacific (Beamish et al. 1999, Lee and Kim 2013). It is one of the most dominant mesopelagic species of Sagami Bay, Japan (Sassa and Kawaguchi 2006). Off Taiwan, it is abundant between the autumn and winter months (Hsieh et al. 2011).
range: This species is distributed in the Pacific from the northern Philippines to the Kamchatka Peninsula, the Bering Sea to the Aleutian Islands of Alaska (USA), Hawaii, the Hancock Seamounts to off northern California in the U.S. (Gordon et al. 1985, Beamish et al. 1999, Randall and Lim 2000, Mundy 2005, Sassa and Kawaguchi 2006, Shinohara et al. 2009, Lee and Kim 2013, Tatsuta et al. 2014, Ivanov and Sukhanov 2015, Wang et al. 2017, Nakae et al. 2018). Records in the South Pacific (iDigBio database accessed July 2019) require verification. Its depth range is mesopelagic to possibly over 1,000 metres (FishNet2 database accessed July 2019).
useTrade: <span id="docs-internal-guid-cab683b1-7fff-a4e0-2ef5-01d828b1b379">This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: <span id="docs-internal-guid-95b223dc-7fff-e33d-3aee-5ee63e1f1adb">There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a mesopelagic species (Shinohara et al. 1996). The largest specimen has a standard length of 36 cm (Masuda et al. 1984).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: Population data are limited. There are 63 museum records of this species in the iDigBio database (accessed September 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the North Pacific transition zone from Sagami Bay, Japan to the southern Kuril Islands to the Emperor Seamounts to the eastern Pacific in the United States from Washington to southern California (Shinohara et al. 2001, Nakabo 2002, Mundy 2005, Parin et al. 2014, iDigBio database accessed September 2019). Records from southeastern Australia (iDigBio database accessed September 2019) require verification. Specimens have been taken at depths between 60-1,366 metres (Shinohara et al. 2001).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a meso- to bathypelagic species (Robertson et al. 2017). It feeds mainly on crustaceans and lanternfishes (Fitch and Lavenberg 1968). It is oviparous, with planktonic eggs and larvae (Moser 1996). Its maximum total length is 25 cm (Eschmeyer et al. 1983).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: Population data are limited. There are about 1,300 museum records of this species in the iDigBio database (accessed April 2019).
range: This eastern Pacific species occurs from northern California in the USA to northern Chile, including the Galapagos Islands (Gibbs 1969, Nalbant and Mayer 1971, Nakamura et al. 1986, Pequeño 1989, Fourriére et al. 2016, Robertson et al. 2017, iDigBio database accessed April 2019). Specimens have been taken at depths between 100-1,500 metres, but typically deeper than 300 m (Eschmeyer et al. 1983, Robertson et al. 2017).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species is common and abundant in parts of its range. There are no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a meso- to bathypelagic species (Shinohara et al. 1994). It spawns in the transitional waters of the northern Pacific, and individuals do not migrate far from their spawning areas (Il'inskiy et al. 1995). This species reaches sexual maturity at approximately 29 cm (Fisher and Pearcy 1983). Its diet consists mainly of other mesopelagic nekton, with smaller individuals feeding on zooplankton and larger specimens feeding on other fishes. The maximum standard length is 41 cm (Il'inskiy et al. 1995).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: In a survey conducted in the northern Pacific between 1987 and 1995, this species was considered common and abundant in the southern Kuril Islands region, especially in the summer (Il'inskiy et al. 1995). It is considered one of four most abundant mesopelagic fishes in the upper 200 metres at night off the continental slope of the northwestern USA (Fisher and Pearcy 1983). It was considered rare in the Pacific waters off Kamchatka and in the Bering Sea, and is most common in the eastern Pacific. It is not particularly abundant north of 45˚N (Il'inskiy et al. 1995).
range: This species inhabits the subarctic and transitional waters of the North Pacific ranging from the Oyashio Current and transitional waters off northern Japan to the California Current region, including the Kamchatka and Kuril Islands, the Bering Sea and Gulf of Alaska to Baja California, Mexico. Reports from Chile require verification (Eschmeyer et al. 1983; Matarese et al. 1989; Pequeño 1989; McAllister 1990; Shinohara et al. 1994, 1996; Il'inskiy et al. 1995; Moser 1996; Mecklenburg et al. 2002; Nakabo 2002; Page et al. 2013; Parin et al. 2014; Kells et al. 2016; iDigBio database accessed April 2019). Specimens have been taken at depths between 30-2,000 metres (Shinohara et al. 1994).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This widely distributed species is closely associated with Giant Kelp, but can also occur in habitats including eelgrass and surfgrass, and occasionally over boulders and sand channels. It is common and locally abundant in parts of its range. The species' close association with kelp in addition to its limited dispersal due to viviparity make impacts from kelp loss likely. Declines in kelp biomass have been directly observed in several parts of its range, including declines off Vancouver since about 2009 and severe declines in Northern California since about 2011. The primary driver of this decline is warming waters due to climate change, both natural and anthropogenic-influenced. Overgrazing by abnormally large populations of sea urchin is also a significant stressor. The impact of these declines on the global population of this species is poorly understood due to the lack of direct population studies, but some research is currently underway. At least one localized experimental study observed recruitment and density declines of this species following kelp removal. Due to the documented declines in kelp within this species' range, which has a close association with kelp for habitat and food, but high level of uncertainty regarding the impact of this potential major threat, Brachyistius frenatus is listed as Data Deficient. This species should be reassessed upon availability of data regarding its' population status.
habitat:
This species inhabits kelp forests and is closely associated with Giant Kelp species, especially Macrocystis pyrifera (Hubbs and Hubbs 1954). It is also often quite abundant among eelgrass and surfgrass, and occasionally over boulders and even sand channels (M. Love pers. comm. 2019). Juveniles tend to aggregate in schools directly below the kelp canopy, while older individuals are less gregarious and more uniformly distributed along the kelp columns to the bottom (Anderson 1994, Hobson and Chess 2001). This species plays an important role in the maintenance of its habitat because it feeds on small, mobile invertebrates on and around kelp (Davenport and Anderson 2007). 

This species gives birth to live young. During the Fall, between September and December, adults mate and females store the sperm in their ovarian cavity for several months. Fertilization, maturation and hatching takes place in the ovarian cavity, and from June to August, embryos are born as juveniles. Its fecundity is lower than most oviparous teleosts, but relatively large compared to other surfperches, where it produces 2-50 young (Baltz 1984, Wang 1986). It attains sexual maturity within one year of age, longevity is no more than 2 or 3 years (Hubbs and Hubbs 1954, Anderson 1994, Wang 1986) and generation length is approximately one year (Tocts et al. 2016). Its maximum total length is 21 cm (Hobson and Chess 2001).
threats: This species is probably impacted by declines in kelp, which is caused primarily by anomalous warm water events influenced by both natural and anthropogenic-driven climate change, including especially a marine heatwave that occurred between 2013-2016 (Catton et al. 2016, Bell et al. 2018, Starko et al. 2019). A secondary stressor includes overgrazing of the kelp by abnormally large Purple Sea Urchin (Strongylocentrotus purpuratus) populations, which was predicated by the loss of their sea star predator via disease (Catton et al. 2016, Starko et al. 2019). A harmful algal bloom that occurred off Sonoma in 2011 was an additional stressor leading to declines in Northern California (Catton et al. 2016). The species' close association with kelp in addition to its limited dispersal due to viviparity make impacts from kelp loss likely (J. Toy pers. comm. 2019).
population:
This species is common and locally abundant in parts of its range (Hubbs and Hubbs 1954). An experimental removal study of Giant Kelp (Macrocystis pyrifera) conducted at three sites off Santa Catalina Island, California recorded a significant decline in both recruitment and density of Kelp Perch (Brachyistius frenatus). In live-bearing species such as this, losses in the adult population reduces its ability to quickly recover even when kelp has recovered (O’Connor and Anderson 2010). Studies are currently underway to elaborate its current population status, including a full-genome analysis of genetic diversity across its range (J. Toy pers. comm. 2019). 

Kelp has declined in a large part of this species' range. Off Vancouver, Canada, kelp cover and diversity has declined over time (as compared to abundance in 1993-1995), with the most significant decline occurring between 2009 and 2017. Kelp abundance in the Southern California Bight is stable or has slightly increased (Krumhansl et al. 2016), but severe declines have been documented in Northern California in recent years (Catton et al. 2016). Kelp abundance in California naturally fluctuates on a decadal-scale per the North Pacific Gyre Oscillation as well as periodic El Niño events, but is also probably impacted by anthropogenic-driven climate change at some level. Giant Kelp canopy biomass from San Francisco to San Diego increased on average over the past 34 years, but recent large-scale warming events such as the 2014 North Pacific warming event and the 2015–2016 El Niño have caused the biomass trends to decline (Bell et al. 2018). The impact from a reduction in kelp density on the population of Brachyistius frenatus is poorly understood (M. Love pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the eastern Pacific from Sitka, Alaska to Turtle Bay, Baja California, Mexico (Wang 1986, Kells et al. 2016). Its depth range is 0-76 metres, but it frequently occurs shallower than 3 m (Stephens et al. 1984, Pietsch and Orr 2015).
useTrade: <span id="docs-internal-guid-fe2e746a-7fff-4000-754d-fcf65b95c4e6">This species is occasionally found in the international aquarium trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures. It has been recorded at the Cabrillo National Monument in San Diego, California, the San-Diego-La Jolla Ecological Reserve, the Drakes Estero State Marine Conservation Area and the Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary (Craig and Pondella 2005, Hastings and Dayton 2006, NOAA 2008). There are long-term programs in place to monitor trends in kelp abundance and ecosystem trends off California (Catton et al. 2016, Bell et al. 2018).

rationale: <span id="docs-internal-guid-a6756679-7fff-d366-e2af-19019d8d6557">This widely distributed species inhabits nearshore rocky areas and kelp beds. It is abundant in parts if its range. It is taken in recreational fisheries, but this is not expected to be driving global-level declines at this time. There are no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species occurs in brackish waters to the intertidal zone on rocky substrate, kelp beds and occasionally in sandy surf areas (Kells et al. 2016). Its maximum total length is 38 cm (Eschmeyer et al. 1983). This is a live-bearing species that gives birth to large, well-developed young (Holbrook et al. 1990). At peak fecundity, females produced 46 embryos. It reaches sexual maturity at 3 years (Gnose 1967) and longevity is 10 years (Shanks and Eckert 2005). The estimated generation length, based on age-fecundity relationships, is 7 years (Swedberg 1965).
threats: There are no known major threats. Fishing is not expected to be driving population declines at this time.
population: <span id="docs-internal-guid-cb512973-7fff-4c24-5aab-2e165fc22133">This species is common and abundant through most of its range, including in Yaquina Bay, Oregon (Gnose 1967). There are 496 museum records of this species in the iDigBio database (accessed May 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the eastern Pacific from Klakas Inlet, Alaska in the U.S. to northern Baja California, Mexico. Its depth range is 0-21 metres (Eschmeyer et al. 1983, Kells et al. 2016).
useTrade: This species is frequently taken by recreational hook and line fishers. It is a very minor component of commercial fisheries, and is taken for the aquarium trade in some parts of its range (Gnose 1967, Lane et al. 2002).
conservationActions: The recreational fishery for surfperches in Washington and California is open year-round, and fishers are not permitted to take more than 10 individuals of this species per fisher per day. In Oregon, fishers may not take more than 15 individuals of surfperches per day. It occurs in several marine protected areas that overlap with its range.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This meso- to bathypelagic species has a maximum standard length of 6.2 cm (Johnson 1974).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: Population data are unavailable. There are 43 museum records of this species in the iDigBio database (accessed July 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the central and eastern central north Pacific between 25°-35°N, 125°W-178°E east to the central United States and south to Panama (Johnson 1974, Mundy 2005, Castellanos-Galindo et al. 2006, iDigBio database accessed July 2019). Its depth range is zero to more than 1,000 metres (Mundy 2005).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: Sardinops sagax has a wide anti-tropical distribution with five geographically isolated subpopulations. It is a highly commercial species throughout much of its range and supports some of the largest global fisheries. Data from available assessments (spawning stock biomass, survey catch rates, landings data, etc.) show some indication of decline over the past 10 years (3 generation lengths); however, this species naturally exhibits large and drastic fluctuations which can be attributed to long-term, regional climatic and environmental conditions and therefore, it is difficult to infer declines based on the available time series. Although this species abundance is currently at historic lows in some regions (e.g., the U.S.; southern Africa; and Japan), it appears to be moderately exploited and is well managed throughout its global range. Therefore, Sardinops sagax is globally assessed as Least Concern. However, overall declines in abundance may be exacerbated by heavy fishing pressure during periods of high abundance, which can result in extended periods of low abundance and subsequent range contractions in areas which generally have viable fisheries. This risk, identified over decades of research and monitoring of the world's major S. sagax fisheries, is now well recognized by regulators and managed accordingly, though localized caution is warranted in areas with consistently high fishing pressure.
habitat:
This is a marine, pelagic and migratory species forming large shoals that may spread over several kilometres (Whitehead 1985). Observed variations in the geographical distribution of sardine stocks associated with changes in population size show a similar pattern in all subpopulations (Parrish et al. 1989, Alheit et al. 2009) and are thought to be closely influenced by prevailing winds, currents and local phytoplankton and zooplankton concentrations (Munroe 2016). For example, spawning grounds have been completely abandoned as subpopulations decrease in size, or colonized as the subpopulation size increases, or both (Parrish et al. 1989). Similarly, the diets of all five subpopulations show some variation but are generally similar throughout; this species primarily feeds on zooplankton, mostly small crustaceans (i.e., copepods, ostracods, euphausiids and mysids), but also feeds on mollusc larvae and phytoplankton (i.e., diatoms: Whitehead 1985). Individuals reach maturity between 1 – 2 years of age; it is thought that a majority spawn at age 2 (Whitehead 1985). Spawning changes geographically within and between regions but is generally in the winter and spring months of the geographic region with the period extending into summer months in some regions (e.g., off Australia and New Zealand: Whitehead 1985).

Geographic variations in some biological characteristics have also been observed within and between subpopulations, such as maximum size, longevity and depth, as well as preferred spawning habitat. In general, this species is known to a maximum of 36 cm standard length, but is more commonly found to be about 18 - 25 cm; subpopulations in the eastern Pacific are typically larger than the others (Whitehead 1985). Funamoto (2018) reports the subpopulation in the northwestern Pacific (sometimes referred to as S. melanostictus or S. sagax melanostictus) has a maximum longevity of 7 years; Whitehead (1985) reported the northeastern Pacific subpopulation (sometimes referred to as S. caeruleus or S. sagax caeruleus) has a maximum longevity of about 25 years. This species is known from depths up to 40 – 200 m (Whitehead 1985, Munroe 2016). Available information related to spawning habitat from each geographically separated subpopulation is variable, but suggests that this species uses either inshore (bays and coastal waters) and/or offshore (~ 80 km offshore with depths up to 5,000 m) areas to spawn (Whitehead 1985, Oozeki et al. 2007).

Subpopulation-specific information

The northeastern Pacific subpopulation (sometimes referred to as S. caeruleus or S. sagax caeruleus) has the longest estimated maximum longevity (20 – 25 years) and the largest measured maximum standard length (36 cm), but is usually found to 20 cm SL (Whitehead 1985). This subpopulation mainly matures within 1 - 2 years and breeds in late winter to early summer months (January – June) with peak spawning in April – May (Whitehead 1985). This subpopulation migrates northward during summer months between California and British Columbian waters, and returns southward in autumn and winter months to spawn off the southern California coast (~ 80 km offshore), between the Point of Conception and San Diego (Whitehead 1985), possibly extending to southern Baja, California (Kramer 1970, Parrish et al. 1989). Spawning takes place during the night and individuals produce pelagic eggs (Whitehead 1985).

The southeastern Pacific subpopulation (sometimes referred to as S. sagax sensu stricu or S. sagax sagax) is known to a maximum standard length of 30 cm, but is more commonly found to 20 cm SL (Whitehead 1985). This species can be found down to depths of at least 40 m (Whitehead 1985). It is known to breed twice in one season (at least off Chile), mostly between July – September (Whitehead 1985). The spawning period can extend between February – March, though this is less common (Whitehead 1985). This species forms large schools in the Peru Current (Whitehead 1985). Large southward geographical range shifts of this subpopulation have been observed in association with El Niño event (Parrish et al. 1989). Evidence available from years not affected by El Niño events suggest an abundance of sardines in northern Chile have a seasonal pattern, with peak abundances occurring during the winter spawning season and much lower abundances during summer and fall (Serra and Tsukayama 1988, Parrish et al. 1989).

The northwestern Pacific subpopulation (sometimes referred to as S. melanostictus or S. sagax melanostictus) has a maximum known standard length of 32 cm based on an individual collected from the Shimane Prefecture, Japan (H. Hata pers. comm. 2018), but is more commonly found to 15 – 20 cm SL (Whitehead 1985). Individuals in this region reach maturity at age 2 and breed in winter and spring months from about November to the beginning of May; in the southern portion of the northwestern Pacific range, this species spawns in the earlier months of the spawning period (Whitehead 1985). Peak spawning is thought to take place in February (Oozeki et al. 2007); eggs are most abundant between February and March (Oozeki et al. 2007). Spawning mainly takes place along the Pacific coast of Japan and has been observed inshore in protected bays, in the surface waters of open seas and in offshore waters over bottom depth of up to 5,000 m (Whitehead 1985, Oozeki et al. 2007). This migratory species tends to move northward and inshore in the summer months, returning southward and more offshore in the winter months (Whitehead 1985).

The southeastern Indian and southwestern Pacific subpopulation (sometimes referred to as S. neopilchardus or S. sagax neopilchardus) has a maximum known standard length of 21.3 cm, but is more commonly found to 18 cm SL (Whitehead 1985). This subpopulation reaches maturity between 8 – 13 cm standard length throughout most of its range; individuals off New Zealand are reported to reach maturity at 12 cm SL or above (Whitehead 1985). It is thought that the subpopulation off Australia breeds throughout its entire geographical range, but at different times (Parrish et al. 1989); in the southern parts of its range, spawning takes place in the spring and summer months (September – February), whereas in the northern parts of its range, spawning takes place in the winter months (June – August: Whitehead 1985). In contrast, off New Zealand spawning is concentrated in the area between the North and South Islands (Parrish et al. 1989). This species forms large school at the surface during the spawning periods and when juveniles leave sheltered bays to join adult schools (i.e., southern New South Wales: Whitehead 1985).

The southeastern Atlantic and southwestern Indian subpopulation (sometimes referred to as S. ocellatus or S. sagax ocellatus) is known to maximum standard length of 28 cm, but is more commonly found to 25 cm (Whitehead 1985). This is a highly migratory species (though the northern stock perhaps rarely moves south of the Orange River) that prefers the cooler, coastal waters of the southwestern African shelf (Whitehead 1985). This subpopulation primarily spawns between September – April and is known to breed either offshore (January – March) or inshore (September – December: Munroe 2016).
threats: The larger subpopulations of this species seem to naturally undergo drastic population fluctuations due to inter-annual, annual and long-term climactic changes resulting in large range contractions and expansions over time (Whitehead 1985, Parrish et al. 1989, Alheit et al. 2009). Observed variations in the geographical distribution of subpopulations show a similar pattern in each isolated region where this species has been heavily exploited (Parrish et al. 1989, Barange et al. 2009); overall declines in abundance may be exacerbated by heavy fishing pressure during times of high abundance. Periods of low abundance and subsequent range contractions result in fishery collapse in areas which generally have viable fisheries (Parrish et al. 1989). Given this species has an anti-tropical geographical distribution and prefers cooler waters, a global increase in average sea surface temperature (SST) may result in prolonged or permanent range contractions in all isolated regions, though more research is needed to determine the extent this may affect this species.
population:
Landings of Sardinops sagax are reported to the FAO as three nominal species: S. sagax, which represents subpopulations off Australia, and in the eastern Pacific off the western coasts of North and South America; S. ocellatus, which represents the subpopulation off South Africa; and S. melanostictus, which represents the subpopulation off Japan. Globally, combined landings of the three nominal species average just over 6.5 million tonnes annually between 1950 and 2014 with a peak of 25 million tonnes in 1985 (FAO 2016).
