The Pointhead Flounder (Cleisthenes pinetorum) is the predominant species in flounder fisheries operating off eastern Korea, where it accounts for 58% of the catch. The Roughscale Sole (Clidoderma asperrimum) is one of four other species of Pleuronectidae that constitute the majority of the remainder of the catch (Park et al. 2014). Effort data for the Korean flounder fisheries are not consistently collected, but catches have been trending downwards since the late 1970s (Chae and Pascoe 2005). Though species-specific quantified data (e.g. scientific surveys) are not available, from 2004 to 2007, total flounder catches increased, but then gradually declined by 29% by 2016, and there has been a clear decline in abundance of flounders off the eastern coast (Jeong et al. 2017). Korean market demand for this species increased in the early 2000s (Lim et al. 2012). Though species-specific data are limited, this species has likely declined in abundance in Korean waters (T. Tomiyama pers. comm. 2021).

Japan: This species is rarely observed in Japanese waters of the Sea of Japan (T. Tomiyama pers. comm. 2021). It is common and abundant on the continental slope in the Tohoku area on the Pacific coast of Japan (Hattori et al. 2010). Catches of this species in the offshore trawl fishery that operates in the Tohoku area peaked in 1978, subsequently declined by 95% by the late 1990s, and have remained at a low level since then (Abe et al. 2013, Suzuki et al. 2019). Fishing effort has been in decline since about 2011 and reached a time series low in 2018. Catch per unit effort (CPUE) also declined in southern Tohoku by 90% or more in the 1990s, and the spawning population experienced large-scale declines from the 1970s to the 2000s (Hattori et al. 2008). It has been considered recruitment overfished in the waters off Tohoku (Inagawa et al. 2012). CPUE data are available starting in 1972. CPUE peaked in 1980, then declined by 93% to a time series low in 1998, and has gradually increased since then. As of 2018, however, CPUE remains well below levels observed in the 1970s to early 1980s. Over the past three generations (since about 1983), CPUE declined by 62%. 

China: Species-specific population data are limited for this species in Chinese waters, but declines are suspected to be likely, as fishing effort increased significantly over time. In Chinese coastal waters, overfishing of the flatfish stocks has occurred at least since the 1980s (Dagang et al. 1992, Tian et al. 2008). Most commercial fish stocks, including flatfishes, are heavily overexploited in the Yellow Sea (Xu and Jin 2005). Flatfish stocks in the Bohai Sea have been in decline since the 1960s to at least the 1990s due to overfishing (Shuozeng 1995b). Overfishing, marine pollution, and the destruction of spawning grounds have negatively impacted other pleuronectid species (i.e. Pleuronichthys spp.) in Chinese waters (Zhu et al. 2012). Overfishing in the East China Sea, which is primarily driven by Chinese fishing fleets, has caused steep declines in flatfish stocks since the late 1990s (Aonuma et al. 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the North Pacific Ocean. In the western North Pacific Ocean, it occurs along continental Asia from the East China Sea to the Yellow and Bohai seas and the Sea of Japan to the Tatar Strait. It also occurs off both coasts of Japan (Sea of Japan; and Pacific coast, from Hokkaido to northwestern Kyushu). In the Sea of Okhotsk, it is distributed off the Kuril Islands and southeastern Kamchatka. This species occurs in the Bering Sea north to Cape Navarin and the Commander Islands, and off the Aleutian Islands, Alaska, U.S. Infrequently, it occurs in the Gulf of Alaska and from off British Columbia, Canada south to Mendocino, California, U.S. The depth range is 6-1,900 m, but this species typically occurs between 400-800 m (Clemens and Wilby 1961, Sakamoto 1984, Li and Wang 1995, Shinohara et al. 2011, Nakabo 2013, Abe et al. 2013, Parin et al. 2014, Kells et al. 2016, Orlov and Tokranov 2019).
useTrade: It is an important component of commercial flounder fisheries off eastern Korea (Park et al. 2014) and in the Tohoku area of Japan from Aomori to Ibaraki prefectures (Abe et al. 2013). This species is retained as bycatch in deep commercial trawl fisheries in Russian waters (Tokranov and Orlov 2003, Orlov and Tokranov 2019). In response to increasing demand in Korea, the development of aquaculture production of this species is being explored (Lim et al. 2012).
conservationActions:
In South Korean waters, a fishery-independent scientific bottom trawl survey has been conducted to monitor groundfish populations since 2000 (Hyun and Seo 2018). The Korean government restricts fishing gear and limits the number of fishing vessels in the flounder fisheries (Chae and Pascoe 2005). Korean regulations also currently include fish size limits and net mesh size limits as well as some area restrictions on use of trammel nets (Park et al. 2014). A stock enhancement programme that releases hatchery-bred individuals into the wild is active in Korea, but data are limited on the success of these activities.

Recovery plans for the stock of this species off the Tohoku area on the Pacific coast of Japan were implemented in 2003 to reduce fishing pressure on spawning individuals, including seasonal area closures (Abe et al. 2013). Regular stock assessments are conducted for this species by the Fisheries Agency and Fisheries Research Agency of Japan for the Tohoku stock (Hattori et al. 2010). The stock management goal remains to control/reduce fishing effort, especially during spawning aggregation seasons, to promote stock recovery (Suzuki et al. 2019).

rationale:
This widely distributed, deepwater demersal species is common in parts of its range. Fishing activity is not expected to be driving population declines approaching levels at which the species would qualify even for Near Threatened status at this time. Fishery management plans are in place and enforced in a large proportion of its range. It is listed as Least Concern with a recommendation to conduct research to improve our knowledge on the life history of this species.

The findings and conclusions in this document are those of the authors, and do not necessarily represent the views of the National Marine Fisheries Service.
habitat:
This demersal species occurs on mud substrates on the continental shelf and slope as well as at cold seeps and seamounts (Barry et al. 1996, Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Lundsten et al. 2009, Kells et al. 2016). The maximum standard length is 50 cm (Nakabo 2013).

Biological information is limited for this species (McGilliard et al. 2019). As part of the "other flatfish complex" in the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands, the assumed natural mortality of this species is 0.15 (Wilderbuer and Nichol 2015). Age at first maturity is not known, but the closest related species is Microstomus pacificus. This proxy species has a larger maximum length (76 cm), a maximum observed age of 59 years, an age at first maturity of 12.5 years, and a natural mortality of 0.085 (McGilliard et al. 2019). Based on these data, a generation length of 24 years was estimated for M. pacificus, so it is inferred that the generation length of M. bathybius is less than 24 years. If an age at first maturity of 12 years and a natural mortality of 0.15 is applied to the equation recommended by the IUCN Red List methods: 1/adult mortality + age of first reproduction, the generation length is estimated to be about 19 years. However, additional research on life history parameters is needed to refine this estimate.
threats: Fishing activity is not expected to be driving population declines approaching levels at which the species would qualify even for Near Threatened status at this time.
population:
Russia: This species is naturally rare in Russian waters (Evseenko 2003, Parin et al. 2014, Orlov and Tokranov 2019). According to Russian scientific trawl surveys conducted over the past 42 years (since the late 1970s), this species was only captured 12 times (I. Volvenko pers. comm. 2020).

United States: This species is common in deep slope waters from Washington to southern California (Tolimieri and Levin 2006). In the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands, this species is managed as part of the "other flatfish complex" but composes only a small portion of the catch. It is not targeted in this area but is retained as bycatch in fisheries that target other flatfish species and Pacific Cod. In recent years, the majority of the catch within the "other flatfish complex" is represented by Starry Flounder (Platichthys stellatus) and Rex Sole (Glyptocephalus zachirus), but overall, the exploitation rate has been relatively low since 1997. The stock is considered only lightly exploited with biomass across the complex currently at a relatively high level (Wilderbuer and Nichol 2015). It is relatively common on the Bering Sea slope at depths greater than 400 m. Surveys generally do not extend into the deeper parts of its depth range where it is more abundant, which causes biomass estimates to be highly variable and uncertain (D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020). There is no particular trend in the biomass of this species in the Eastern Bering Sea slope survey from 2002 to 2016 (I. Spies pers. comm. 2020).

In the Gulf of Alaska, this species is managed as part of the "deepwater flatfish complex", which besides this species, is also composed of Greenland Turbot (Reinhardtius hippoglossoides) and Dover Sole (Microstomus pacificus). The Dover Sole (Microstomus pacificus) composes the majority (77%) of the catch. Catch of this species (Deepsea Sole) is low and intermittent with annual catches at less than a ton in most years. According to the most recent assessment of this stock, overfishing is not occurring, and this stock is not overfished nor approaching an overfished condition. Due to the lack of biological information and unreliability of scientific survey data for this species in the Gulf of Alaska, biomass estimates are not available. Fishing intensity has been exceptionally low and annual catches have been well below the total allowable catch limit (TAC) in recent years in part due to a shift in targeting different species (McGilliard et al. 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the North Pacific Ocean from Hokkaido (Japan) to the northern Kuril Islands and southeastern Kamchatka (Russia), the Bering Sea north to Cape Navarin and the Aleutian Islands of Alaska (United States) to northern Baja California, Mexico (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Nakabo 2013, Parin et al. 2014, Kells et al. 2016). Records of Embassichthys sp. (Novikov et al. 1981) from the Emperor Seamounts previously thought to refer to Embassichthys bathybius (now Microstomus bathybius) likely refer to M. shuntovi (Mundy 2005). The depth range is 41-1,800 metres (Hart 1973, Parin et al. 2014, Kells et al. 2016), usually deeper than 730 m off Canada (Hart 1973).
useTrade: This species is not targeted but is sometimes retained as bycatch in commercial demersal fisheries in the United States.
conservationActions: The subpopulation of this species in the United States is monitored through scientific surveys and annual stock assessments. Stocks from Alaska to California in the United States are managed through the Pacific Coast Groundfish Fishery Management Plan, the Gulf of Alaska Groundfish Fishery Management Plan, and the Bering Sea/Aleutian Islands Groundfish Fishery Management Plan. Fishing is regulated through permitting, size limits, daily and total catch limits, seasonal and area fishing closures, gear restrictions, and a trawl catch share programme. Additional research is needed on life history characteristics.

rationale:
This widely distributed, demersal species has an estimated generation length of 11-12 years. It is commercially exploited in a large portion of its range. According to stock assessments and survey data, biomass in the Gulf of Alaska over about the past three generation lengths, or since 1982, fluctuated somewhat, but mostly increased over time. Although, over the past 9-11 years, biomass declined by 22-28%. Biomass in the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands increased overall from 1982 to 2018, but declined by 20% since about 2003 to 2015, or over about the past 12-17 years. Spawning biomass along the U.S. West Coast (Washington to California) has been increasing over nearly three generation lengths, or since the late 1980s. Comprehensive fisheries management is in place in U.S. waters, and conservation measures related to this are expected to remain in place. No major threats are known, and the population is considered well managed; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern with a recommendation to investigate the cause of the recent decline over one past generation length in the Gulf of Alaska and Bering Sea. 

The findings and conclusions in this document are those of the authors, and do not necessarily represent the views of the National Marine Fisheries Service.
habitat:
This demersal species occurs over sandy and muddy bottoms from the surf zone to the continental slope (Mecklenburg et al. 2002). It is a batch spawner with an 8-month spawning season in offshore areas of the Gulf of Alaska. Juveniles settle in nearshore nursery areas on the continental shelf and in bays (Abookire 2006, Abookire and Bailey 2007). The growth rate and female size at maturity varies widely by latitude. This species has a maximum total length of 61 cm (Mecklenburg et al. 2002). 

In the Gulf of Alaska, natural mortality is estimated at 0.17, longevity is about 20 years and length, and age at first sexual maturity is 35.2 cm and 5.7 years (Abookire 2006, McGilliard and Palsson 2017). On the U.S. West Coast (Washington to California), the natural mortality is estimated to be 0.20, age at first maturity is 4 years and longevity is 29 years (Cope et al. 2015). According to work by the Alaska Fisheries Science Center, this species has been aged to a maximum of 49 years (https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/alaska/commercial-fishing/fish-species-maximum-age-data). When applying the equation recommended by the IUCN Red List methods: 1/adult mortality + age of first reproduction, the generation length is estimated to be about 11-12 years.
threats: Fishing activity is not expected to be driving population declines approaching levels at which the species would qualify even for Near Threatened status at this time.
population:
Russia: This species is naturally rare in Russian waters (Parin et al. 2014). It is uncommonly captured in the western Bering Sea, including near the Commander Islands and off southeastern Kamchatka. Individuals in the western part of its range are generally smaller than those in the eastern part (Glubokov et al. 2017). It tends to be more common in Russia in warm water years (Orlov and Tokranov 2007). This species is more common in the eastern Pacific (I. Volvenko pers. comm. 2020).

United States: This species is possibly more abundant in the Gulf of Alaska than it is in the Bering Sea (D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020). In the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands, this species is managed as part of "the other flatfish complex", which besides this species, primarily comprises Starry Flounder (Platichthys stellatus), Longhead Dab (Myzopsetta proboscidea), Dover Sole (Microstomus pacificus) and Butter Sole (Isopsetta isolepis). It is not targeted in this area but is retained as bycatch in fisheries that target other flatfish species and Pacific Cod. In recent years, the majority of the catch within "the other flatfish complex" is represented by Starry Flounder (Platichthys stellatus) and also Rex Sole (Glyptocephalus zachirus), but overall, the exploitation rate has been relatively low since 1997. The stock is considered only lightly exploited with biomass across the complex currently at a relatively high level. Fishery-independent scientific surveys have been conducted annually in the Bering Sea and every 2-3 years off the Aleutian Islands from 1982 to 2018. Across this area, biomass of this species increased from about 9,000 to 15,000 t from 1982 to 2000, increased sharply from 2000 to 2003 to a peak of about 50,000 t and then gradually declined by 20% to about 40,000 t by 2015, or over one past generation (Wilderbuer and Nichol 2015, 2018, 2019).

This species occurs throughout the Gulf of Alaska, but the highest abundance is in the central part. According to the most recent assessment of the Gulf of Alaska stock, overfishing is not occurring, and this stock is not overfished nor approaching an overfished condition. According to stock assessment models for 1982-2019, total biomass fluctuated somewhat with peaks around 120,000 t in the early 1990s and from 2010-2012. Since 2012, biomass trends have been in decline, with 97,967 t estimated for the terminal data year, 2019, which represents a 22% decline over the past 9 years (a little less than one past generation). According to scientific survey data available since 1984, biomass of this species mostly increased over time from about 60,000 t to near 100,000 t, but it declined by 28% from 124,744 t in 2009 to 90,414 t in 2019, or over the past 11 years (one past generation). The next full stock assessment will be published in 2021 (McGilliard and Palsson 2017, 2019). 

This species is relatively common in much of its range, including from the Aleutian Islands to southern California. According to the most recent assessment of the West Coast stock, which includes the states of Washington, Oregon and California, overfishing is not occurring, and this stock is not overfished. Spawning biomass has been increasing since the late-1980s and the exploitation rate of this species has been relatively low in the last few decades (Cope et al. 2015). In this region, specifically the California Current System, recruitment success and the spatial distribution of biomass of this species fluctuates with climate/environmental conditions (Keller et al. 2013).

Canada: This species is common and abundant off British Columbia, Canada (Hart 1973, Workman et al. 2019). It is not directly targeted, and no formal stock assessment has been conducted (Workman et al. 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the North Pacific from the northern Kuril Islands, Navarin Canyon and southeastern Kamchatka in Russia to the northwestern Bering Sea and the Aleutian Islands of Alaska in the United States south to off Cedros Island, central Baja California, Mexico (Hart 1973, Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Orlov et al. 2002, Parin et al. 2014). The depth range is 0-1,143 metres (Orlov et al. 2002, Parin et al. 2014, Kells et al. 2016), but is most abundant between 100-200 m (McGilliard and Palsson 2017).
useTrade: This species is targeted by commercial bottom trawl in the Gulf of Alaska (McGilliard and Palsson 2017). In the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands, it is retained as bycatch in commercial trawl fisheries (Wilderbuer and Nichol 2015). It is also landed by commercial fisheries along the U.S. West Coast from Washington to California (Cope et al. 2015). Hart (1973) noted that off the west coast of Canada, although abundant and of prime quality, Rex Sole is not utilized because of the relatively small size of fish taken in the fisheries and because the thinness of their bodies renders this species undesirable in those fisheries marketing fillets.
conservationActions: The subpopulation of this species in U.S. waters is closely monitored through scientific surveys and annual stock assessments. Stocks in U.S. waters from Alaska to California are managed through the Pacific Coast Groundfish Fishery Management Plan, the Gulf of Alaska Groundfish Fishery Management Plan, and the Bering Sea/Aleutian Islands Groundfish Fishery Management Plan. Fishing is regulated through permitting, size limits, daily and total catch limits, seasonal and area fishing closures, gear restrictions, and a trawl catch share programme. Research is needed on the cause of the recent decline in the Gulf of Alaska and Bering Sea.

rationale:
This widely distributed, demersal species has an estimated generation length of 14-15 years. It is targeted by commercial fisheries throughout a large part of its range. According to stock assessments of this species in US waters, it is not overfished, and overfishing is not occurring. In the eastern Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands, modeled spawning biomass declined by 32% over the past 20 years, or since 1999 (one and a half generations); however, according to scientific surveys, total biomass increased overall over the past 37 years, or since 1982 (about two and a half generations). In the Gulf of Alaska, total biomass fluctuated somewhat over the past 32 years, or since 1984 (two and a half generations), with no clear overall increasing or decreasing trend. Spawning biomass increased overall over the past 49 years, or since 1978 (three generations). In Russian waters, model projections from stock assessments forecasted that it is not in an overfished condition and that biomass fluctuations are likely influenced by natural changes in climate cycles. According to scientific surveys conducted over the past 42 years in Russian waters, the catch per unit effort of this species increased over time; although, there have been some periods of localized decline in the Kamchatka region. It is listed as Least Concern with a recommendation to investigate the cause of the recent spawning stock biomass decline over the past one and a half past generations in the eastern Bering Sea. 

The findings and conclusions in this document are those of the authors, and do not necessarily represent the views of the National Marine Fisheries Service.
habitat:
This demersal species occurs on sandy, muddy and silty bottoms from the intertidal zone to the continental slope. It attains a maximum total length of 56 cm (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Kells et al. 2016). Juveniles inhabit nearshore nursery areas while adults migrate seasonally to near shelf margins in the winter for spawning and to the middle and outer shelf in summer for feeding (Turnock et al. 2017). In Puget Sound, diets include clams, worms and crustaceans (Hart 1973).

According to work by the Alaska Fisheries Science Center, it has been aged to a maximum of 37 years (https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/alaska/commercial-fishing/fish-species-maximum-age-data). The maximum age, according to the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands stock assessment, is 32 years (McGilliard et al. 2018). The natural mortality rate is estimated to be 0.2 (McGilliard et al. 2019). In the Pacific waters off the northern Kurils and southeastern Kamchatka, length at first maturity for males is 22.3 cm and for females is 30.4 cm (Orlov et al. 2010). Age and length at first maturity are 9.7 years and 32 cm in the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands (McGilliard et al. 2018). In the Gulf of Alaska, age and length at first maturity are 8.7 years and 33 cm (Turnock et al. 2017). When applying the equation recommended by the IUCN Red List methods: 1/adult mortality + age of first reproduction, the generation length is estimated to be about 14-15 years.
threats: Fishing activity is not expected to be driving population declines approaching levels at which the species would qualify even for Near Threatened status at this time.
population:
This species has a similar morphology to the Bering Flounder (Hippoglossoides robustus) and their distributions overlap in the northern half of the Bering Sea and the Sea of Okhotsk, but not in the Gulf of Alaska (Turnock et al. 2017). Hippoglossoides elassodon is more abundant than H. robustus in the eastern Pacific (McGilliard et al. 2018). Studies are needed to examine the genetic structure throughout its range (Turnock et al. 2017,Vinnikov et al. 2018).

Russia: This species is abundant in Russian waters (Orlov and Tokranov 2019, Orlov et al. 2020). According to Russian scientific trawl surveys conducted over the past 42 years (since the late 1970s), the catch per unit effort (CPUE) of this species increased over time (I. Volvenko pers. comm. 2020). From 1992-2002, its abundance in waters of the northern Kuril Islands to southeastern Kamchatka fluctuated widely mostly due to natural fluctuations in recruitment that might be attributed to climate (oceanographic) variability (Orlov et al. 2010).

In eastern Kamchatka, this is the second-most abundant pleuronectid species, but only composes about 9% of the flounder commercial catch and is considered underutilized. From 1950 to 2006, the biomass of this species in eastern Kamchatka peaked in the early 1950s around 60,000 t, declined to a low of less than 20,000 t in the late 1960s to early 1970s, increased to a peak of nearly 60,000 t in the late 1990s, and declined thereafter by 50% to about 30,000 t in 2006. Based on observations of flounder biomass trends over time, it was expected to continue to decline for the years 2010-2015, but then begin to increase again (Zolotov and Zakharov 2008).

In western Kamchatka, this species is one of the five pleuronectid species targeted by the flounder fishery. From 1963 to 2006, the abundance of this species increased overall with a peak in 2002 and then a decline to at least 2006. Biomass forecasts projected that a decline in overall flounder biomass and spawning stock was expected to continue from 2007-2008 to 2011-2012, followed by an increase until the mid-2010s, and then a decline to 2020 (Dyakov 2009). From 2006 to 2014, the CPUE in trawl surveys conducted in western Kamchatka declined over time (I. Volvenko pers. comm. 2020).

United States: On the U.S. West Coast (Washington, Oregon and California), this species accounts for a minor proportion of groundfish catches and a formal stock assessment is not undertaken. Its distribution and abundance from Washington to California are influenced by environmental conditions, especially trends in the California Current System (Keller et al. 2013). Annual stock assessments are conducted for the Gulf of Alaska and Bering Sea/Aleutian Islands. 

In general, this species is more abundant in the Bering Sea than it is in the Gulf of Alaska (D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020). According to the most recent assessment of the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands stock, overfishing is not occurring, and this stock is not overfished nor approaching an overfished condition. The exploitation level has been light in recent decades. Fishery-independent scientific surveys conducted annually in the eastern Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands since 1982 show an overall increasing trend in biomass over the 37-year time period; from a low of 192,037 t in 1982 to a peak of 769,783 t in 1997. After 1997, survey biomass declined somewhat, but fluctuated between about 380,000 t to 600,000 t during the past 20 years, or 1999 to 2019. Survey biomass has had an increasing trend since 2015. The catchability of this species in the surveys is partly driven by shifts in bottom water temperature. Modeled spawning biomass, from 1964-2020, declined from 1970-1983, with the lowest value of 87,811 mt estimated for 1983, biomass then increased to a peak of 226,535 mt in 1999, and subsequently declined to 154,356 mt in 2018, representing a 32% decline over the past 20 years. A period of low recruitment occurred from 2004-2010, possibly linked to environmental conditions (Wilderbuer et al. 2013; McGilliard et al. 2018, 2019a). 

According to the most recent assessment of the Gulf of Alaska stock, overfishing is not occurring, and this stock is not overfished nor approaching an overfished condition. In addition, exploitation levels are sustainable. Scientific surveys conducted in the Gulf of Alaska since 1984 show that biomass has fluctuated somewhat around an average of 215,000 t over the entire 35 year period, with a low of 153,594 t in 2001 and a peak of 281,402 t in 2007. According to modeled spawning biomass from 1978-2017, the overall trend has been increasing over this 49 year period, and spawning biomass has been stable around 80,000 t since about 1990, or over the past 30 years (Turnock et al. 2017, McGilliard et al. 2019b).

Canada: This species is common and abundant off British Columbia, Canada. It is not directly targeted, and no formal stock assessment has been conducted (Workman et al. 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the North Pacific Ocean from the northern Sea of Japan, southern Sea of Okhotsk, across the Bering Sea to central California (Sakamoto 1984, Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Parin et al. 2014). In the western Pacific, it is found from off Hokkaido, Japan; from the Tatar Strait, eastern Sakhalin Island, Kuril Islands, and southwestern Kamchatka, Russia; and the Bering Sea. In the eastern Pacific, it occurs in the eastern Bering Sea, including the Aleutian Islands of Alaska, and south to off Monterey, California (Hart 1973, Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Nakabo 2013, Parin et al. 2014, Kells et al. 2016). The depth range is 0-1,050 metres (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Nakabo 2013, Parin et al. 2014, Kells et al. 2016), but the species typically occurs shallower than 300 m (Turnock et al. 2017).
useTrade: This species is taken in commercial trawl fisheries in Russian waters (Orlov 2011, Orlov and Tokranov 2014) and in the Gulf of Alaska, the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands (Turnock et al. 2017; McGilliard et al. 2018, 2019a,b). It is also retained as bycatch in commercial trawl fisheries along the U.S. West Coast from Washington to California.
conservationActions:
The subpopulation of this species in US waters is closely monitored through scientific surveys and annual stock assessments. Stocks in US waters from Alaska to California are managed through the Pacific Coast Groundfish Fishery Management Plan, the Gulf of Alaska Groundfish Fishery Management Plan, and the Bering Sea/Aleutian Islands Groundfish Fishery Management Plan. Fishing is regulated through permitting, size limits, daily and total catch limits, seasonal and area fishing closures, gear restrictions, and a trawl catch share program.

Studies are needed to examine the genetic structure of this species throughout its range and to compare genetics with those of Hippoglossoides robustus to clarify some taxonomic uncertainty (Turnock et al. 2017, Vinnikov et al. 2018). Research is also needed to determine the cause of the recent decline in spawning stock biomass in the Bering Sea.

rationale:
This widely distributed, cold-water, demersal species has an estimated generation length of 14 years. It is targeted by commercial fisheries in a large part of its range. It is likely more abundant in the western Pacific as compared to the eastern Pacific. According to stock assessments for U.S. waters, it is not overfished, and overfishing is not occurring. In the eastern Bering Sea, survey biomass declined by 92% over the past two generation lengths, or since 1991; however, this decline is suspected to reflect movement of the subpopulation farther northward where surveys are not conducted regularly. In addition, previous confusion with Hippoglossoides elassodon may have confounded survey data for the 1980s and 1990s. It is common and abundant in Russian waters and the flounder stock is in stable condition in the Sea of Okhotsk. It is recommended to increase scientific survey effort in the northern Bering Sea in U.S. waters to investigate shifts in the distribution. Although some uncertainty is associated with the possible decline in biomass in the eastern Bering Sea, it is listed as Least Concern. 

The findings and conclusions in this document are those of the authors, and do not necessarily represent the views of the National Marine Fisheries Service.
habitat:
This demersal species occurs over soft bottoms from the intertidal zone to the continental slope. It appears to prefer mud as compared to coarser substrates (Mecklenburg et al. 2007). It attains a maximum total length of 52 cm (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Tuponogov and Kodolov 2012).

According to work by the Alaska Fisheries Science Center, it has been aged to a maximum of 33 years (https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/alaska/commercial-fishing/fish-species-maximum-age-data). The natural mortality rate is estimated to be 0.2 (McGilliard et al. 2019). Age and length at first maturity of this species are 8.7 years and 24 cm in the eastern Bering Sea (Stark 2011, McGilliard et al. 2018). When applying the equation recommended by the IUCN Red List methods: 1/adult mortality + age of first reproduction, the generation length is estimated to be about 14 years.
threats: Fishing activity is not expected to be driving population declines approaching levels at which the species would qualify even for Near Threatened status at this time. The preference of this species for cold water may cause it to be particularly susceptible to periods of extended warming (Stark 2011), and therefore it may be negatively impacted by climate change and the related increasing water temperatures. Preliminary data suggest that this species may have shifted its distribution northward in response to increasing water temperatures (D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020).
population:
This species has a similar morphology to the Flathead Sole (Hippoglossoides elassodon) and their distributions overlap in the northern half of the Bering Sea and the Sea of Okhotsk, but not in the Gulf of Alaska (Turnock et al. 2017). Hippoglossoides elassodon is more abundant and generally inhabits warmer water than H. robustus at least in the eastern Pacific (McGilliard et al. 2018). Studies are needed to examine the genetic structure throughout its range (Turnock et al. 2017, Vinnikov et al. 2018). 

Russia: This species is common and abundant in the Sea of Okhotsk, off western and northeastern Kamchatka, in Aniva Bay, off the northern Kuril Islands and in the Chukchi Sea (Li et al. 2017, Lukyanova et al. 2018, Dyldin et al. 2018, Saveliev et al. 2019, Orlov et al. 2020). Its abundance increased on the Chukchi shelf in the Russian EEZ in 2012 (Gavrilov and Glebov 2013). The stock of flounders in the Sea of Okhotsk, where this species is taken in commercial fisheries, is considered stable (Ovchinnikov et al. 2017). According to Russian scientific trawl surveys conducted over the past 42 years (since the late 1970s), the catch per unit effort of this species has been stable with no noticeable trend over time (I. Volvenko pers. comm. 2020).

United States: This species is abundant in the Chukchi Sea off Alaska (Norcross et al. 2013). Annual stock assessments are conducted for this species in the Gulf of Alaska and Bering Sea/Aleutian Islands. According to the most recent assessment of the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands stock, overfishing is not occurring, and this stock is not overfished nor approaching an overfished condition. The exploitation level has been light in recent decades. This species composed only 0.5% of the total commercial catch in 2017 and 2018, and the highest catch proportion was 6% in 1980. It is naturally uncommon in the Aleutian Islands. Fishery-independent scientific surveys have been conducted annually in the eastern Bering Sea since 1983, or over the past 36 years. Survey biomass peaked in 1991 at 27,630 t and then declined to a low of 2,092 t in 2019, which represents a 92% decline over the past 29 years (McGilliard et al. 2018, 2019a). In the southeastern Bering Sea, water temperature was relatively warm from 2001 to 2005 before undergoing a distinct shift to relatively cold from 2006 to 2010. This environmental change corresponded with changes in fish catches in the Bering Sea shelf trawl survey (Stevenson and Lauth 2012). The preference of this species for cold water may cause it to be particularly susceptible to periods of extended warming (Stark 2011).

There are several sources of uncertainty associated with the survey biomass trend. During the 1980s and 1990s, this species could have been easily confused with H. elassodon, and this causes the biomass estimates at the beginning of the decline (1991) and just prior to be uncertain. Availability of this species to the surveys also introduces uncertainty. It is suspected the species is more common in the western Pacific as it is more frequently captured in the U.S. surveys conducted near the Russian EEZ boundary. In addition, it is suspected this species has shifted its distribution northward beyond the current survey extent (D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020).
range: This species is distributed in the North Pacific and Arctic oceans, from the northern Sea of Japan and Sea of Okhotsk, in the Bering Sea, the Arctic Ocean and south to the Aleutian Islands (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Parin et al. 2014). In the Sea of Japan, it occurs from Toyama Bay to off Hokkaido and in the Tatar Strait. In Russian waters, it occurs off the Iturup and Paramushir islands (Kuril Islands), in the Sea of Okhotsk off northern and eastern Sakhalin Island, off southeastern Kamchatka, and in the Chukchi and East Siberian seas. It is also found in the Bering Strait; the Bering Sea, off the Alaskan Peninsula; and to Akutan Island, in the Aleutian Islands (Sakamoto 1984, Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Nakabo 2013, Parin et al. 2014, Kells et al. 2016). It occurs in the Beaufort Sea in low densities (Rand and Logerwell 2011). The depth range is 1-560 metres (Kells et al. 2016, I. Volvenko pers. comm. 2020).
useTrade: This species is taken in commercial fisheries in Russian waters (Parin et al. 2014, Dyldin et al. 2018) and is targeted by commercial bottom trawls in the Bering Sea and off the Aleutian Islands (McGilliard et al. 2018, 2019a).
conservationActions:
The subpopulation of this species in U.S. waters is closely monitored through scientific surveys and annual stock assessments, managed through the Bering Sea/Aleutian Islands Groundfish Fishery Management Plan. Fishing is regulated through permitting, size limits, daily and total catch limits, seasonal and area fishing closures, gear restrictions, and a trawl catch share program. 

Studies are needed to examine the genetic structure of this species throughout its range and to compare genetics with those of Hippoglossoides elassodon to clarify some taxonomic uncertainty (Turnock et al. 2017, Vinnikov et al. 2018). It is recommended to increase scientific survey effort in the northern Bering Sea in U.S. waters to investigate shifts in the distribution of this species.

rationale:
This widely distributed, demersal species has an estimated generation length of 19 years. It is highly valued by commercial and recreational fisheries throughout its range and has been exploited since the 1800s. Abundance is higher in the eastern Pacific than in the west. Biomass in Russian waters experienced declines by the early 1970s due to high fishing mortality but increased from the mid-1980s to 2000s as fishing pressure was reduced. Catch per unit effort in scientific surveys conducted since 1976 has been stable over time. In the western Bering Sea and Karaginskaya, biomass fluctuated widely in some years from 1996 to 2017 but these stocks are currently considered stable and exploited at a sustainable level. Biomass in Petropavlovsko-Komandorskaya, however, has declined since 2007 with some stabilization at lower levels in recent years. Fishing is regulated and managed by catch limits, including vessel monitoring. 

Spawning biomass in the U.S. and Canada over the past three generations, or since about 1964, has fluctuated. Since increasing to a peak in 1997, biomass declined by about 70% to 2010 and has been stable at that lower level since then. The primary cause of this most recent decline is a decline in size-at-age of individuals since the 1970s, the cause of which is not clearly understood. Suspected contributing factors include size-selective fishing, increasing abundance of competing predators, changing water temperatures and reduced availability of high-energy prey items. As water temperatures are projected to continue increasing as climate change progresses, there is concern for impacts to this species related to future biomass decline or shifts in distribution. Though high fishing mortality contributed to past declines, fishing effort is now stringently managed and is not likely a driver of decline. 

On the global level, this species is listed as Least Concern with a recommendation to improve the application of total allowable catch limits in the western Pacific and to continue research on declines in size-at-age in the eastern Pacific. 

The findings and conclusions in this document are those of the authors, and do not necessarily represent the views of the National Marine Fisheries Service.
habitat:
This demersal species occurs on soft and hard bottoms from coastal bays to the continental shelf and slope (Tokranov et al. 2005, Kells et al. 2016, Hurst 2016). Post-larvae feed on small zooplankton. One- to three-year-old fish feed on small shrimp and other small crustaceans (e.g. crabs), as well as small fishes (IPHC 2014, Lajus et al. 2019). Adults feed on both benthic and pelagic prey, especially cod, sablefish, Walleye Pollock, rockfishes, sculpins, smelt, sand lance, capelin, and flatfishes (including smaller Pacific Halibut), but also relatively high amounts of hermit crabs (IPHC 2014, Webster 2014, Lajus et al. 2019). To a lesser extent, adults also feed on cephalopods, larger crabs, and clams (Hart 1973, Lajus et al. 2019). 

During its life history, this species undergoes ontogenetic and long-term movements, though these movements typically decrease with age and size (IPHC 2014). It conducts annual feeding and spawning migrations (Webster et al. 2013). In the summer, the species typically occurs shallower followed by movement to deep water in the autumn, a secondary movement to an even deeper depth stratum in winter, and a return to shallow water the following spring. Some individuals return to the same feeding grounds in the summer after spawning in winter. Subsequent studies also indicate high rates of interannual homing in conjunction with the potential for basin-scale segregation among spawning groups (Seitz et al. 2017). 

Spawning typically occurs between November and March in deeper waters (180-500+) along the continental slope concentrated in submarine canyons (Hart 1973, St. Pierre 1984, IPHC 2014, Drinan et al. 2016). Documented major spawning sites include Cape St. James, Langara Island, and Frederick Island in British Columbia, Yakutat, Cape Suckling – Yakataga, Portlock Bank, and Chirikof Island in Alaska, as well as Middle Canyon near the US/Russia border in the eastern Bering Sea (IPHC 2014, Drinan et al. 2016). It is unclear if individuals return to their natal spawning sites to spawn (Drinan et al. 2016). 

This species batch spawns pelagic eggs that hatch after 15-20 days and the pelagic larval duration is typically 5-6 months, during which time larvae are carried counterclockwise around the northeast Pacific by the Alaskan Stream and/or Alaska Coastal Current (IPHC 2014, Drinan et al. 2016). Settlement of juveniles in shallower nursery areas leads to southerly and easterly (clockwise) migration over an additional 2-3 years and potentially hundreds of miles before reaching the adult stage (IPHC 2014). 

The maximum total length recorded for this species is for a female of 267 cm (Hart 1973). The largest specimen had a live weight of 500 lbs (227 kg). Females grow faster and reach larger sizes than males (Hart 1973, Mecklenburg et al. 2018), but they reach maturity slower than males (IPHC 2014). Males reach maturity at about 72 cm (fork length) and eight years of age, and females mature at about 120 cm and 12 years. Despite substantial size-at-age decreases in recent decades, the average size/age of maturation has not changed in the eastern Pacific (IPHC 2014). The maximum age is approximately 55 years. Recently, female natural mortality is estimated to be 0.15-0.22, although some uncertainty is associated with this estimate (Stewart and Hicks 2020). However, earlier studies (Thompson and Herrington 1930, Myhre 1967) report substantially higher natural mortality rates (around 0.30). When applying the equation recommended by the IUCN Red List methods: 1/adult mortality + age of first reproduction, the generation length is estimated to be about 19 years.
threats: Changes in the biomass of this species are largely driven by changes in size-at-age and variability in recruitment. The recent biomass decline in the eastern Pacific is primarily driven by declines in size-at‐age, and despite several studies, the cause of this is still not fully understood. Projections suggest that further decline is a result of poor recruitment. Size-selective fishing, which occurs when fishers preferentially capture or retain large individuals, may have contributed to the decline (Sullivan 2016). A recent modelling study reported the changes in size-at-age could be driven by changes in growth potential related to reduced foraging rates and availability of high-energy prey items, such as Walleye Pollock, which is related to anomalous warm conditions observed in Alaskan waters (Holsman et al. 2019). For example, according to an examination of the isotopic signatures of Pacific Halibut otoliths, oceanic conditions differed between the Bering Sea and the Gulf of Alaska during the early 1990s (Gao and Beamish 2003). Declines in size-at-age may persist given that water temperatures are projected to increase according to climate change forecasts and that the abundance of predators/competitors may continue increasing in the Gulf of Alaska (Holsman et al. 2019). A large increase of Arrowtooth Flounder (Atheresthes stomias) biomass in the Gulf of Alaska that occurred from the 1960s to mid-2010s has been explored as a source of prey competition. A recent study concluded that dietary overlap between these two flatfish species is low, but the potential impact from competitive interactions requires further investigation (Barnes et al. 2018). Further research is needed on the implications of high trophic-level prey species availability in the eastern North Pacific for the growth of the largest size-at-age Pacific Halibut females, which have a relatively specialized diet (Wolf et al. 2019).
population:
Genetic and spawning unit structuring are present, but are relatively low across the extent of the stock in the eastern Pacific (Drinan et al. 2016, Seitz et al. 2017). Low-level genetic differentiation exists between eastern (United States and Canada) and western (Russian) Pacific Ocean sampling locations (Drinan et al. 2016). Connectivity between the western and eastern subpopulations is poorly understood, but studies are underway (Stewart and Hicks 2020). More work is needed to fully understand the genetic population structure of this species.

Overall, this species is more abundant in the eastern Pacific (U.S. and Canada) as compared to in the western Pacific (Russia and Japan) and propagule exchange would be expected to occur from the east to the west (Orlov 2000, 2004). This species has been described as "abundant" from the Sea of Japan, the Aleutian Islands, and from the Bering Sea to California, but it is considered "uncommon" to "rare" in the Artic Ocean (Mecklenburg et al. 2018). 

Russia: In Russian waters, this species is abundant in the Sea of Okhotsk, the Gulf of Anadyr and the Olyutorsky and Navarinsky regions of the western Bering Sea, but is naturally rare in the Sea of Japan (Batanov et al. 2017, Orlov and Tokranov 2019). In fisheries catches, it is lumped with three other species that are categorized by fishers as 'halibut', including Kamchatka Flounder (Atheresthes evermanni), Arrowtooth Flounder (Atheresthes stomias), and Greenland Halibut (Reinhardtius hippoglossoides). The Pacific Halibut and Greenland Halibut represent the majority of the halibut catches with Kamchatka Flounder and Arrowtooth Flounder constituting a very small quantity. Total annual halibut catches were stable around an average of 15,000 tons per year for the period 2008-2019 with a decreasing trend since 2016. Catch per unit effort (CPUE) of halibuts has declined since 2012. According to Russian scientific trawl surveys conducted over the past 42 years (since 1976), the CPUE of this species was stable with no noticeable trend over time. Survey CPUE slightly declined over time in the western Bering Sea, increased in eastern Sakhalin, was stable in western Kamchatka, and declined in eastern Kamchatka and the northern Kurils (I. Volvenko pers. comm. 2020).

Age structure of the catch in the northwestern Bering Sea did not noticeably change from the 1930s to the 1960s and did not change in the southern Kuril Islands over the last century. Age composition did change to younger ages in the 2000s in the northern Kuril Islands and southeastern Kamchatka despite suggested relatively low fishing pressure in the western Pacific (Orlov et al. 2011). From the mid-1980s to the 2000s, biomass of this species increased in the western Bering Sea, the Sea of Okhotsk and eastern Kamchatka. From 1998-2008, catches of this species in the bottom longline fishery operating in the western Bering Sea declined from 1998 to 2000, but increased thereafter. The proportion of the catch that it composed also increased over time (Tuponogov et al. 2013). This species had declined due to high fishing mortality by the early 1970s, but the cessation of targeted fishing effort in 1975-1985 allowed biomass to increase in Russian waters from the mid-1980s to 2000s. In the most recent decade, annual catches exceeded total allowable catch limits in some Russian stocks, and combined with reduced recruitment in recent years, this is cause for concern regarding population status. In the western Bering Sea zone and Karaginskaya subzone, biomass fluctuated widely in some years from 1996 to 2017 but remained above the sustainable total biomass limit. These stocks are currently considered to be stable and exploited at a sustainable level. Biomass in the Petropavlovsko-Komandorskaya subzone has declined since 2007, has remained below the maximum sustainable yield limit since 2012, and is stable at a relatively low level in recent years (Lajus et al. 2019).

United States and Canada: This species has been commercially fished in North American waters since the 1800s. Large declines occurring through the 1920s may have been a result of increased fishing mortality in the early 1900s. To manage the stock and establish a recovery plan, the International Pacific Halibut Commission (IPHC) was formed in 1923. The stock is assessed as a single unit throughout its known range within the IPHC Convention Area. This known range extends from northern California to the Aleutian Islands and Bering Sea (including Canada but excluding Russia). After improved fishery management and reduced fishing effort, spawning biomass increased overall from about 1930 to 1997. Over the past three generations, or since about 1964, biomass declined somewhat from 1964 to 1980, increased to a peak in 1997, declined by about 70% by 2010 and has been stable at that lower level since then. 

Fluctuations in stock biomass are linked to changes in recruitment, which are related to the decadal changes in productivity of the Northeast Pacific Ocean. The most recent biomass decline is primarily driven by a 50% reduction of individual size-at-age since the 1970s and somewhat weakened recruitment as compared to the 1980s and is not driven by fishing intensity (Stewart and Hicks 2020). Until about 1985, males and females recruited to the fishery in the central Gulf of Alaska at about the same age (males at seven years and females at eight years). As a result, commercial catches were composed of sex ratios relatively similar to underlying abundance (Clark 2004). However, between the mid-1980s and mid-1990s, mean growth rates declined across the population, generating a sex-specific disparity with respect to fishing mortality. Females now enter the central Gulf of Alaska fishery on average at 10 years of age and males at nearly 15 years (Galindo et al. 2011). Size-at-age was also low in the early 1900s. Harvest reductions were made as the modern-day declines were detected. The cause of the reduced size-at-age is unknown (Stewart and Hicks 2020). Size-at-age changes are thought to result from a combination of factors, such as density-dependent competition for food, ocean productivity, size-selective fishing, etc. (see threats section for more details).

The relative spawning biomass has been above the 30% limit since 2015, which indicates fishing intensity is at a sustainable level. In the most recent assessment (2019-2020), it was 32% (Stewart and Hicks 2020). Size-at-age was also low in the early 1900s. Harvest reductions were made as the modern-day declines were detected. The cause of the reduced size-at-age is unknown. Spawning biomass is projected to continue declining through at least the next three years, or until 2023, based on the known strength of cohorts and status quo fishing mortality levels. There are several integral points of uncertainty related to the biology and population dynamics of this species that lead to a high degree of uncertainty in both stock scale and trend (Stewart and Hicks 2020).
range: This species is distributed in the North Pacific Ocean. In the western Pacific, it occurs off both coasts of Japan, from Toyama Bay on the west coast and off the Tohoku District on the east coast, north to off Hokkaido. In Russian waters, it occurs from Peter the Great Bay and Primorye in the Sea of Japan, the Sea of Okhotsk, the Kuril Islands, southeastern Kamchatka, the Bering Sea, including the Gulf of Anadyr and the Commander Islands, to the southern Chukchi Sea. In the eastern Pacific, this species ranges from the Aleutian Islands, Bering Sea, and Gulf of Alaska, U.S. south to northern Baja California, Mexico (Sakamoto 1984, Mecklenburg et al. 2002, 2018). It is uncommon to rare in the Arctic Ocean (Mecklenburg et al. 2018). The depth range is 6-1,200 metres, but usually occurs shallower than 300 m (Nakabo 2013, Parin et al. 2014, Mecklenburg et al. 2018).
useTrade:
This species is directly targeted and highly valued by commercial, subsistence and recreational fisheries throughout its range (Tokranov et al. 2005, Parin et al. 2014, Stewart and Hicks 2020). In the U.S. and Canada, it is only permitted to be targeted by hook and line; when captured as bycatch in non-directed fisheries, it is not permitted to be retained (Stewart and Hicks 2020). This species is of high importance to indigenous peoples of Alaska, British Columbia and the state of Washington. Local management of these fisheries is overseen by the tribal groups and the Northwest Indian Fisheries Commission. The Pacific Halibut sport fishery is substantial in U.S. and Canadian waters and this species is very popular with recreational anglers (IPHC 2014). 

Although this is a highly valuable commercial fish, no specialized fishery exists for this species in Russian waters. In Russia, it is primarily taken and retained as bycatch in commercial longline, gillnet, Danish Seine, and trawl fisheries (Orlov et al. 2011, Datsky and Maznikova 2017). It is among the dominant species taken in a longline fishery in the western Bering Sea and is also caught by longlines on the shelf in the Sea of Okhotsk and off the Kurils and eastern Kamchatka (Orlov et al. 2011, Tuponogov et al. 2013, Lajus et al. 2019).

Although interest has been expressed in culturing this species, little progress has been made to rear fish to market size (Stickney and Liu 1999).
conservationActions:
This is a highly regulated species that has been subject to various management measures throughout its range since at least the 1920s. Regulations are in place for commercial, subsistence and recreational fisheries. The stock in the United States and Canada has been managed by the International Pacific Halibut Commission since 1923 (Stewart and Hicks 2020). Fishing regulations for the U.S. and Canada include total mortality limits, daily bag limits, fish size limits, license and permit requirements, incidental mortality limits, seasonal closures, area closures, and fishing gear restrictions (IPHC 2020). When targeting of groundfishes increased in the early 1960s, bycatch from all areas of the North Pacific steeply increased to a peak in 1965. Bycatch mortality has steadily declined since the early 1990s due to bycatch management measures. In 2011, an Individual Transferable Quota (ITQ) programme was implemented for the U.S. West Coast trawl fishery alongside requirements for 100% observer coverage and a program for managing halibut bycatch, and this substantially reduced bycatch; a similar program also exists in Canadian waters (IPHC 2014). In Alaska, Pacific Halibut bycatch is managed to static mortality limits by the North Pacific Fisheries Management Council. All sources of mortality are included in stock assessment analyses and evaluation of mortality limits set by the IPHC.

There is a total allowable catch limit for this species in Russian waters (Tuponogov et al. 2013). The longline fishery in the western Bering Sea is subject to catch limits, vessel reporting requirements, and other fishing control measures. Improvements in configuring total allowable catch limits may be needed (Lajus et al. 2019).

Research is needed and is currently underway to understand the level of exchange of individuals between Russian and Alaskan waters. This is especially important as water temperatures are warming in the Bering Sea, which may cause increased population movement across international borders (Stewart and Hicks 2020). Fish condition and growth should be monitored in the Alaskan region to identify early indicators of climate impacts on these life history parameters (Holsman et al. 2019). Furthermore, current estimates of natural mortality are uncertain; as such, more research is needed to improve the estimate of natural mortality.

rationale:
This widely distributed, demersal species is taken in commercial flatfish fisheries in Alaska, primarily where it is most common in the Gulf of Alaska. Overfishing is not occurring, but a survey biomass decline of 25% was recorded for the Gulf of Alaska over the past three generations (since 1999). The stock in the Bering Sea/Aleutian Islands is considered stable. Comprehensive fisheries management and the conservation measures related to this are expected to remain in place in the U.S. The cause of the decline in the Gulf of Alaska is not fully understood, but exploitation possibly contributed. Fishing activity is not expected to be driving population declines approaching levels at which the species would qualify even for Near Threatened status at this time; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern with a recommendation to conduct research on the cause of the Gulf of Alaska decline as well as to improve life history information for future assessments. 

The findings and conclusions in this document are those of the authors, and do not necessarily represent the views of the National Marine Fisheries Service.
habitat:
This demersal species occurs over muddy to silty bottoms from the surf zone to the continental slope and sometimes occurs in estuaries (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Kells et al. 2016). Juveniles utilize nearshore habitats as nursery grounds (Stinton et al. 2014). The maximum total length is 56 cm (Miller and Lea 1972, Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Kells et al. 2016).

The natural mortality rate is 0.15 to 0.2, but there is a significant amount of uncertainty associated with this estimate (Turnock et al. 2017, Wilderbuer and Nichol 2019). Longevity is 11 years (Beamish et al. 2006). Age at first maturity is not known. Based on work by Vinnikov et al. (2018), the closest relative to Isopsetta isolepis is Psettichthys melanostictus, and this latter species is considered the most appropriate proxy for generation length for Isopsetta isolepis. Psettichthys melanostictus has a natural mortality rate of about 0.2 (Turnock et al. 2017), a longevity of at least 10 years and length and age at first maturity of 29 cm and 2 years (Pearson and McNally 2005). When applying the equation recommended by the IUCN Red List methods: 1/adult mortality + age of first reproduction, the generation length is estimated to be about 7 years.
threats: Fishing activity is not expected to be driving population declines approaching levels at which the species would qualify even for Near Threatened status at this time. As juveniles of this species utilize estuaries for nursery habitat, degradation of this environment may negatively impact it. Within its range, estuaries of Alaska and British Columbia are healthy, but estuaries farther south, such as the Puget Sound, have been heavily impacted by anthropogenic activity (D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020).
population:
This species is most common from Umnak Island, Alaska to northern California (Kells et al. 2016). It is common off southeastern Alaska, Oregon and Humboldt, California (Stinton et al. 2014, Miller et al. 2015, Mulligan et al. 2017, Sobocinski et al. 2018). The center of its abundance in Alaska is in the Gulf of Alaska, and it is naturally rarer in the Bering Sea/Aleutian Islands (Wilderbuer and Nichol 2015). It is lumped into a species complex south of Alaska and is likely not targeted much there (i.e. Washington, Oregon and California).

In the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands, this species is managed as part of "the other flatfish complex", which besides this species, is primarily composed of Rex Sole (Glyptocephalus zachirus), Starry Flounder (Platichthys stellatus), Longhead Dab (Myzopsetta proboscidea) and Dover Sole (Microstomus pacificus). It is not targeted in this area but is retained as bycatch in fisheries that target other flatfish species and Pacific Cod. In recent years, most of the catch within "the other flatfish complex" is represented by Starry Flounder (Platichthys stellatus) and Rex Sole (Glyptocephalus zachirus). According to scientific surveys conducted from 1982 to 2018, estimated biomass of species in this complex mostly increased over the 36-year period. Fluctuations in estimates of exploitation rate and biomass for this species may reflect its occurrence in survey sampling, and it is expected that its population in the Bering Sea/Aleutian Islands is larger than these estimates. The stock is considered lightly exploited, and the next full stock assessment will be published in 2020 (Wilderbuer and Nichol 2015; 2018; 2019).

In the Gulf of Alaska, this species is managed as part of the "shallow-water flatfish stock complex", which besides this species, is primarily composed of Alaska Plaice (Pleuronectes quadrituberculatus), English Sole (Parophrys vetulus), Sand Sole (Psettichthys melanostictus), Starry Flounder (Platichthys stellatus), Yellowfin Sole (Limanda aspera), Northern Rock Sole (Lepidopsetta polyxystra) and Southern Rock Sole (Lepidopsetta bilineata). According to the most recent stock assessment, overfishing is not occurring and the exploitation rate on this complex is relatively low. This species (butter sole) has the highest exploitation rate out of the others in the complex, though the rate has been declining since 2010. According to scientific surveys, biomass of this species in the Gulf of Alaska from 1984 to 2019 fluctuated widely in some years but declined by 33% over the 35-year time period from 1984 to 2019 (Turnock et al. 2017, Bryan 2019). Over the past three generations (since 1999), survey biomass declined by 25%. Overall, the decline is relatively small, and the trend has been flat over the past three generations. Exploitation is a potential cause of the decline (M. Bryan pers. comm. 2020).
range: This species is distributed in the eastern North Pacific from the southeastern Bering Sea, the Aleutian Islands of Alaska south to Ventura, California (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Kells et al. 2016). Four juvenile specimens were collected from Inner Cabrillo Beach in San Pedro, California in 2013 (Williams et al. 2018), but it is not known if this represents a range extension or waifs. The depth range is 1-427 metres (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Kells et al. 2016).
useTrade: This species is taken in commercial flatfish fisheries, primarily those operating in Alaskan waters. Some of the catch taken off Canada is used for mink food (Hart 1973).
conservationActions: In the United States, the population of this species is monitored by scientific surveys and annual stock assessments, and fishing is regulated through a variety of measures, including total catch limits. Aging data is needed to improve the estimate of natural mortality (Turnock et al. 2017). Research is needed on age at first maturity as well as the cause of the decline of this species in the Gulf of Alaska.

rationale:
This widely distributed, demersal species has an estimated generation length of 14 years. It is taken in commercial flatfish fisheries throughout its range, with most of the catch taken from the Gulf of Alaska. It is not overfished, and overfishing is not occurring. According to scientific survey data, survey biomass in the Gulf of Alaska peaked in 2009 then declined by 44% to 2017, or over a little less than one past generation length. The cause of this decline is not fully understood. Recruitment has been relatively consistent and exploitation has been relatively low and spawning stock biomass has declined by 17% during this same time period. The stock in Canadian waters is considered healthy and has been increasing since 2000 or over nearly two past generations. Comprehensive fisheries management and the conservation measures related to this are expected to remain in place in the U.S. and Canada. Fishing activity is not expected to be driving population declines approaching levels at which the species would qualify even for Near Threatened status at this time; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern with a recommendation to conduct research on the cause of the Gulf of Alaska decline. 

The findings and conclusions in this document are those of the authors, and do not necessarily represent the views of the National Marine Fisheries Service.
habitat:
This demersal species occurs over sandy, mud and gravel bottoms from the continental shelf to slope. It has a maximum total length of about 59 cm (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Kells et al. 2016).

According to work by the Alaska Fisheries Science Center, it has been aged to a maximum of 28 years (https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/alaska/commercial-fishing/fish-species-maximum-age-data). Spawning occurs in Alaskan waters in June and July in bottom water temperatures of 6 degrees celsius. Age and length at female maturity is 9 years and 34.7 cm (Stark and Somerton 2002). The natural mortality rate is assumed to be 0.2 for females and estimated to be 0.26 for males (Bryan and Palsson 2019). When applying the equation recommended by the IUCN Red List methods: 1/adult mortality + age of first reproduction, the generation length is estimated to be about 14 years.
threats: Fishing activity is not expected to be driving population declines approaching levels at which the species would qualify even for Near Threatened status at this time.
population:
This species is easily confused with the Northern Rock Sole (Lepidopsetta polyxystra). Both species occur in the Gulf of Alaska. Lepidopsetta bilineata only peripherally occurs in the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands, while L. polyxystra is significantly more common there (Wilderbuer et al. 2018). Commercial catch data do not report statistics separately for these species, so there is considerable uncertainty surrounding the proportion of the catch that each species represents (Bryan 2017). Its abundance south of the Gulf of Alaska is not well understood, but is found in highest concentrations around Queen Charlotte Sound and Hecate Strait in British Columbia, Canada (Holt et al. 2016) and it is relatively common in Puget Sound, Washington (D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020). 

United States: The most recent assessment of the Gulf of Alaska stock concluded that overfishing is not occurring, and it is not overfished nor approaching an overfished condition. Scientific surveys have been conducted in the Gulf of Alaska since 1984, but catches of 'rock sole' were not differentiated between the two species until 1996. According to these data, survey biomass declined between 1996 and 1999, increased to a peak of 191,765 mt in 2009 and declined thereafter by 44% to 107,985 mt in 2017, or over about one past generation length. Spawning stock biomass (SSB) also declined by 17% during the same period (2009-2017). SSB has been modeled for the 40-year period of 1977 to 2017, which is nearly three generation lengths. The SSB in 1977 (80,187 t) was similar to that in 2017 (76,053 t). During this period, SSB increased from 1982 to a peak in 1990, declined until 2003, increased to 2008 and has declined since 2013. From peak levels in 1990 at 106,318 t, SSB subsequently declined by 33% to a low of 71,433 t in 2019 (about two past generations). The exploitation rate is relatively low and has been mostly declining since 2008. The next full stock assessment is expected in 2021 (Bryan 2017, Bryan and Palsson 2019). The cause of the recent decline in SSB is not fully understood. Prior to 1996, this species was not differentiated from L. polyxystra in survey data and this causes the biomass estimates at the beginning of the decline (1990) and for about five years after to be uncertain (D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020). Recruitment has been relatively consistent and although SSB has exhibited cyclical fluctuations over time, current SSB is only 23% lower than SSB under unfished conditions (M. Bryan pers. comm. 2020). 

This species is not formally assessed for the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands, but biomass is modeled based on the long-term scientific surveys conducted in that area. Estimated biomass from 1997 to 2018 fluctuated widely from year to year but has been increasing since 2015 (Wilderbuer et al. 2018). 

Canada: In Canadian waters, both species of rock sole are taken in fisheries, but catches are composed almost exclusively of this species, the Southern Rock Sole. It has been exploited since at least the 1940s. Since the late 1990s, catches fluctuated, but generally remained below the total allowable catch limit. The stock is considered healthy. Over the past three generation lengths, or since 1978, female spawning biomass declined in the early 1990s to 1998 but has been steadily increasing since 2000 to levels nearing those in 1978 (Holt et al. 2016).
range: This species is distributed in the eastern North Pacific from the southeastern Bering Sea, the Aleutian Islands of Alaska south to Cortes Bank, southern Channel Islands, USA (Orr and Matarese 2000, Mecklenburg et al. 2002). It only peripherally occurs in the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands (Wilderbuer et al. 2018); most records in the Bering Sea are likely misidentifications of L. polyxystra, mixed with legacy records from before the description of L. polyxystra (D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020). The depth range is 12-339 metres (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Kells et al. 2016). Records from the western Pacific (Shinohara et al. 2011, Nakabo 2013) are considered misidentifications of Lepidopsetta polyxystra.
useTrade: This species is taken in commercial flatfish fisheries in Alaskan waters and in British Columbia. It is also incidentally taken in small amounts in demersal trawl fisheries conducted off the U.S. West Coast.
conservationActions: Harvest of this species in the United States is managed by NOAA Fisheries and the North Pacific Fishery Management Council under the Fishery Management Plans for Groundfish of the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands and Gulf of Alaska. On the U.S. West Coast, it is also included under the Pacific Coast Groundfish Fishery Management Plan. Fishing regulations include permit requirements and annual total catch limits. The fishery is monitored, and long-term scientific surveys are in place. The stock is also monitored and managed in Canadian waters by Fisheries and Oceans Canada via total allowable catch limits, trawl net mesh size restrictions and a vessel quota system (Holt et al. 2016).

rationale:
This widely distributed, demersal species has an estimated generation length of 14-15 years. The center of its abundance is on the shelf of the eastern Bering Sea. It is taken in commercial flatfish fisheries throughout its range. It is not overfished, and overfishing is not occurring in the Gulf of Alaska nor in the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands. According to scientific survey data, biomass in the Gulf of Alaska peaked in 2007 then declined by 46% to 2017 (nearly one generation length). Spawning stock biomass (SSB) in the Gulf of Alaska also declined after a peak in 2007 but has been increasing since 2016. According to scientific survey data, biomass in the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands significantly increased from 1982 to 1994 but declined by 50% since then (about two generations). SSB in the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands increased significantly since 1975, or over the past three generations, but has declined by 27% since 2015. SSB is projected to increase again starting in 2022. Biomass declines in the mid-2000s and early 2010s are thought to be due to reduced recruitment success, which, in turn, is caused by decadal-scale and interannual changes in environmental conditions. However, warm water temperatures present in the Bering Sea since 2014 are expected to result in increased recruitment success and eventual increase in adult biomass of this species. In Russian waters, catch per unit effort in scientific surveys slightly increased since 1976. Estimated biomass in eastern Kamchatka and the Northern Kuril Islands declined by 58% from 1989 to 2012, or over a 23-year period. The causes of this decline may be related to interannual variability in environmental conditions, as is suspected for the stock in U.S. waters. Biomass in western Kamchatka increased over the recent decade. Across its entire distribution, fishing activity is not expected to be driving population declines approaching levels at which the species would qualify even for Near Threatened status at this time. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying ecological mechanisms regarding the distributional shifts exhibited by this species in the eastern Bering Sea. It is also recommended that future stock assessments incorporate recruitment models based on environmental forecasts.

The findings and conclusions in this document are those of the authors, and do not necessarily represent the views of the National Marine Fisheries Service.
habitat: This demersal species occurs on sandy bottoms from the continental shelf to the slope. It has a maximum total length of 69 cm (Mecklenburg et al. 2002). Decadal-scale changes in water temperature in the northern nursery area of the eastern Bering Sea drives recruitment success with warm temperature conditions being beneficial (Wilderbuer et al. 2002, Cooper et al. 2014, Cooper and Nichol 2016, Cooper et al. 2019). Spawning occurs on the outer continental shelf in eastern Kamchatka in April and May, in the Sea of Okhotsk in March and April, and in Alaskan waters in January through to the spring at bottom water temperatures of 3°C. Age and length at maturity for females is 9 years and 31 cm in the Bering Sea and 9 years and 33 cm in the Gulf of Alaska (Stark and Somerton 2002, Stark 2012). In the northwestern Bering Sea, females mature at a fork length between 24-27 cm and 6-7 years of age (Datsky and Maznikova 2017). According to work by the Alaska Fisheries Science Center, it has been aged to a maximum of 30 years (https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/alaska/commercial-fishing/fish-species-maximum-age-data). The natural mortality rate is estimated to be 0.15-0.2 (Wilderbuer et al. 2019, Bryan and Palsson 2019). When applying the equation recommended by the IUCN Red List methods: 1/adult mortality + age of first reproduction, the generation length is estimated to be about 14-15 years.
threats: Biomass declines are due to reduced recruitment success, which is caused by decadal-scale and interannual changes in environmental conditions (Wilderbuer et al. 2002, 2013, 2018; Cooper et al. 2014, 2019; Cooper and Nichol 2016). Shifts in distribution of flatfish and other demersal species of the eastern Bering Sea can occur when water temperatures are anomalous, which has been occurring with a climate pattern that has developed in recent years that alternates between above average values for both cold and warm temperatures. This is expected to impact recruitment success and have long-term impacts on the ecosystem (Stevenson and Lauth 2019). The warming water temperatures that have been ongoing since 2014 in the Bering Sea are expected to be beneficial to this species, but ecological changes related to the continuing climate change need further attention (Yeung and Cooper 2020). Across its entire distribution, fishing activity is not expected to be driving population declines approaching levels at which the species would qualify even for Near Threatened status at this time.
population:
This species is easily confused with the Southern Rock Sole (Lepidopsetta bilineata). Both species occur in the Gulf of Alaska. Lepidopsetta bilineata only peripherally occurs in the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands, while L. polyxystra is significantly more common there. Within the Bering Sea and Aleutians, this species is much more common on the Bering Sea shelf as compared to the Aleutians (Wilderbuer et al. 2018). The center of its abundance is on the shelf of the eastern Bering Sea (Walters and Wilderbuer 2000).

Russia: This species is common off southeast Kamchatka and has a lower abundance in the Northern Kuril Islands. It is a major component of demersal fisheries in southeast Kamchatka and constitutes 54% of the total flounder catch (Ovcherenko 2018). In Russian waters, abundance of this species can shift with interannual variability in water temperature (Datsky and Andronov 2014). According to Russian scientific trawl surveys conducted over the past 42 years (since the late 1970s), the catch per unit effort (CPUE) of this species slightly increased over time (I. Volvenko pers. comm. 2020).

Catches in eastern Kamchatka and the Northern Kurils peaked in 1999 at 18.4 thousand tons and began a gradual decline thereafter to a low of 6.5 thousand tons in 2007. Catch was 9-9.5 thousand tons in 2010, 2011 and 2012. This represents a 48% decline over a 13-year period. The causes of this decline are not fully understood. One cause may be a change in fishing effort since it is known that the Russian fishing industry changed significantly from the 1990s to the 2010s. Another possible cause could be shifting of abundance upon environmental variability within the fishing region where there are differing levels of exploitation. Modeled estimated biomass from 1950 to 2012 indicate a peak in 1954 at 104.1 thousand tons, a decline in 1965-1971, an increase in the late-1980s to early 1990s with a peak in 1989 at 111 thousand tons and a gradual decline to 46.5 thousand tons in 2012. This represents a 58% decline over a 23-year period.
