Biomass estimates are complicated by the lack of consistent survey data over a long-term period as well as the exclusion of part of the species' range from the trawl survey coverage (Zolotov 2013). Annual catches of flatfishes, including this species, in western Kamchatka increased significantly from 1994 to 2000 and the biomass of species of Pleuronectidae declined by 55% from 1997 to 2000. It is likely that this decline was a result of natural causes, not fishing effort (Ilyinsky and Chetvergov 2002). Since 2012, scientific survey CPUE in western Kamchatka increased slightly over time to 2018 (I. Volvenko pers. comm. 2020). The density of this species increased significantly from the 1980-1990 period to the 2011-2018 period (Shuntov and Volvenko 2020). 

United States: Commercial catch data do not report separate statistics for the two species of Rock Sole where they overlap in the Gulf of Alaska. Consequently, considerable uncertainty exists regarding the proportion of the catch that each species represents (Bryan 2017). The most recent assessment of the Gulf of Alaska stock concluded that overfishing is not occurring, and the stock is not overfished nor approaching an overfished condition. Scientific surveys have been conducted in the Gulf of Alaska since 1984 but catches of Rock Sole were not differentiated between the two species until 1996. According to these data, biomass declined between 1996 and 1999, increased to a peak of 102,641 t in 2007 and declined by 46% to 55,047 t in 2017 (over nearly one past generation). Spawning stock biomass (SSB) has been modeled for the 42-year period of 1977 to 2019, which is about three generations. SSB varied over time, but declined from 1995 to 2001, increased to a peak in 2007, declined to a low in 2016 and has been increasing since then. Compared to 1977 (42,070 t), SSB increased to 47,104 t in 2019. Mean body length in the survey data has been relatively stable over time, but declined between 2007-2009, increased in 2011, declined in 2013-2015 and increased again in 2017. The exploitation rate has been mostly declining since 2008. The next full stock assessment is expected in 2021 (Bryan 2017, Bryan and Palsson 2019). The SSB trend is relatively flat over time with some decline from 2008 to 2018 (M. Bryan pers. comm. 2020).

The most recent assessment of the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands stock concluded that overfishing is not occurring and it is not overfished nor approaching an overfished condition. The stock is at a high and stable level but has been in a slow decline since 2010. According to scientific surveys conducted in the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands since 1982, biomass increased to a peak of 2,893,472 t in 1994 but has since declined by 50% to 2018 (about one and a half past generations). The decline from 1995-2003 is attributed to below average recruitment during the 1990s. Recruitment was also poor from 2006 to 2013. Compared to 1982 (578,714 t), biomass increased to 1,051,503 t in 2018, or over the past 36 years. Spawning stock biomass (SSB) has been modeled for the 44-year period of 1975 to 2019, which is nearly three generations. SSB increased to a peak of 591,189 t in 2002, declined to 2009, increased to near peak levels in 2015 (573,222 t) and declined by 27% to 417,800 t in 2019. This decline is likely caused by the lack of good recruitment as compared to strong levels seen in 2001-2003 and 2005. Compared to 1975 (50,702 t), SSB increased significantly to 2019, or over about the past three generations. Female spawning biomass is projected to increase from 2022 to at least 2028 in part influenced by the strong recruitment year of 2014. Fishery exploitation is light. Recruitment success is correlated with changes in environmental variables (Wilderbuer et al. 2018, 2019). Low ice cover and high bottom water temperature are correlated with higher abundance and northward expansion of this species. Warm water temperatures that have been present in the Bering Sea since 2014 are expected to be beneficial to juveniles of this species (Yeung and Cooper 2020). Models predict that recruitment for the 2015-2018 year classes was above average, which suggests that biomass will increase in the future (Cooper et al. 2019). A spike in recruitment in the northern part of its distribution may indicate that the population is shifting northward (Stevenson and Lauth 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the North Pacific Ocean from off northern Hokkaido, Japan; the northeastern Sea of Okhotsk; off western and southeastern Kamchatka, Russia; to the Kuril Islands; the Bering Sea, including the Gulf of Anadyr; in Alaskan waters from St. Lawrence Island to the Aleutian Islands; and south to Puget Sound, Washington, United States (Sakamoto 1984, Orr and Matarese 2000, Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Parin et al. 2014). The depth range is 0-1,200 metres (Parin et al. 2014, Kells et al. 2016, I. Volvenko pers. comm. 2020).
useTrade: This species is taken by commercial fisheries in Russian waters on the Pacific shelf of Kamchatka and the northern Kuril Islands, and also in the western Bering Sea (Orlov 2007, 2011; Glubokov et al. 2018). It is taken in commercial flatfish fisheries in Alaskan waters, as well as off British Columbia, Canada. It is targeted for its particularly highly valued roe (Wilderbuer et al. 2018).
conservationActions:
Harvest of this species in U.S. waters is managed by NOAA Fisheries and the North Pacific Fishery Management Council under the Fishery Management Plans for Groundfish of the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands, and of the Gulf of Alaska. Fishing regulations include permit requirements and annual total catch limits. The fishery is monitored, and long-term scientific surveys are in place. In Russia, there is a total allowable catch limit for this species (Zolotov 2013). 

The distributional shifts exhibited by this species in the eastern Bering Sea due to changes in water temperatures should be monitored for direct impacts to this species and indirectly through other aspects of changes in this ecosystem (Stevenson and Lauth 2019). Further research is needed on the underlying ecological mechanisms, including predator-prey interactions, to understand the response of this species and other groundfishes to the warming climate (Yeung and Cooper 2020). It is also recommended that future stock assessments incorporate recruitment models based on environmental forecasts, especially considering the impact of water temperature on juveniles (Cooper et al. 2019).

rationale:
This widely distributed, demersal species has an estimated generation length of 19 years. It is highly valued and exploited by commercial flatfish fisheries throughout its range. In U.S. waters, overfishing is not occurring. According to scientific survey data and stock assessment models, survey biomass in the Gulf of Alaska declined by 43% over the past 35 years, or since 1984 (about two generation lengths), while exploitation has been low. The cause of this decline is not well understood, but it is not likely related to fishing pressure, but rather may be related to the population range shift, which alters the proportion of the population existing in surveyed areas. In the eastern Bering Sea, which has a higher abundance than that in the Gulf of Alaska, total and female spawning biomass significantly increased since 1964, or over the past three generation lengths. However, a gradual decline of 23 and 27% has occurred since 1985 and 1994, respectively. The decline is due to reduced recruitment strength, which is caused by interannual changes in bottom water temperatures. Stock assessment models indicate that female spawning biomass is projected to slightly increase through 2032 in the Bering Sea, and biomass has been increasing since 2010 in the northern Bering Sea. Fishery management and monitoring are stringent in U.S. waters and expected to remain in place. Declines over the past one to two generation lengths and projected about one generation into the future do not reach the quantitative thresholds to qualify for even a Near Threatened status at this time. In Russian waters, biomass of this species has been declining in some areas since the mid-1990s, or a little over one generation length. Cyclical changes in environmental conditions that led to reduced recruitment success are considered the primary cause of this decline, with fishing pressure as a secondary cause in some areas, especially when high fishing pressure occurs during periods of undesirable environmental conditions. Catch per unit effort in scientific surveys conducted in Russian waters since 1976 was stable over time. Fishing is managed by annual catch limits and some seasonal closure to bottom trawling. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern. Recommendations include: collecting quantitative data to verify that there is a northward population shift, to evaluate the impacts of changing water temperatures and sea ice extent, as well as to conduct further research on genetics, population structure, movement between the Eastern Bering Sea and the Gulf of Alaska, identifying spawning areas in the Gulf of Alaska, and regarding certain aspects of its life history. 

The findings and conclusions in this document are those of the authors, and do not necessarily represent the views of the National Marine Fisheries Service.
habitat:
This demersal species occurs on soft and hard bottoms from the continental shelf to the slope. It has a maximum total length of 56 cm (Tuponogov and Kodolov 2014). It conducts an annual feeding migration to the shelf-slope break in the winter and a spawning migration to nearshore waters in spring and summer. Juveniles utilize coastal bays as nursery grounds. The diet primarily consists of polychaete worms, miscellaneous worms, clams, and benthic amphipods.

The natural mortality rate is estimated to be 0.12 and sexual maturity occurs at about 10.5 years of age (TenBrink and Wilderbuer 2015, Spies et al. 2019). In Russian waters of the southwestern Bering Sea, age and length at first maturity for males is 4.6 years and 21.4 cm and for females, 7.7 years and 28.5 cm (Zolotov 2008). According to work by the Alaska Fisheries Science Center, it has been aged to a maximum of 40 years (https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/alaska/commercial-fishing/fish-species-maximum-age-data). When applying the equation recommended by the IUCN Red List methods: 1/adult mortality + age of first reproduction, the generation length is estimated to be about 19 years.
threats: Shifts in distribution of flatfishes and other demersal species of the eastern Bering Sea can occur when water temperatures are anomalous, a situation which has been occurring with a climate pattern that has developed in recent years where water temperatures alternate between above average and below average annual values. In addition to impacts in adult habitats, nursery grounds, such as Norton Sound and Kuskokwim-Togiak Bays in the eastern Bering Sea, are also experiencing higher than normal temperatures due to climate change. These anomalous water temperatures are expected to impact growth and condition of juveniles of this species (Spies et al. 2019), which, in turn, likely affect recruitment success and have long-term impacts on the ecosystem (Stevenson and Lauth 2019). In Russian waters, similar declines in biomass are also attributed to cyclical climatic changes that have led to reduced recruitment success, which are amplified by fishing pressure (Zolotov et al. 2014). Anthropogenic activities in nearshore, coastal habitats that serve as nurseries for juveniles are likely to negatively impact this species.
population:
Russia: This species is common and abundant in the northwestern Bering Sea (also known as the Olyutorsky-Navarin region), especially on the Koryak Shelf. Its subpopulation is considered stable there based in part on the continued presence of older individuals in scientific survey catches in the northwestern Bering Sea (Datsky and Maznikova 2017). It is also common in the Sea of Okhotsk and western Kamchatka shelf (Napazakov 2015), and northeastern Kamchatka (Orlov et al. 2020). According to Russian scientific trawl surveys conducted over the past 42 years (since the late 1970s), the catch per unit effort (CPUE) of this species was stable with no noticeable trend over time (I. Volvenko pers. comm. 2020).

This species is the primary target of flounder fisheries in the Sea of Okhotsk. Fishing mortality was high in the mid-1970s but declined with the reduction of effort when EEZ boundaries were implemented in the late 1970s (Dyakov 2014). The fishery remains active but is no longer open access (Yusupov 2014). Exploitation remained at low levels until 2004 when an industrial targeted fishery began in the Magadan region of the northern Sea of Okhotsk (Pustovoit and Yusupov 2011). Off Sakhalin Island, targeted fishing of this species began in the late 1940s. Catches were high in the 1950s, but declined in the 1960s to an average of 2.6 thousand tons, and averaged between 1.7 to 2.1 thousand t to the 1990s. Abundance of this species was high in the 1950s to 1960s and 1985-1995, but declined in 1970-1980 and in the mid-1990s to 2013 (the terminal year of data). Similar patterns were reported in the western Bering Sea and for the western Kamchatka shelf. The primary cause of decline is attributed to natural cyclical fluctuations in water temperature that led to reduced recruitment success, but fishing pressure during the years of undesirable conditions is considered to amplify such declines. In the 15-20 years preceding 2014, fishing effort changed due to a large-scale reorganization of the fishing fleet. In western Sakhalin in 2001-2013, fishing effort was unsustainable. Changes in the size and age composition from 2001 to 2012 indicated the stock underwent a sharp decline. In 2014, new regulations were introduced to address overfishing. Scientific bottom trawl surveys were conducted from 2000-2013 off Sakhalin, and according to those data, the biomass of this species averaged 5 thousand tons in 2000-2005, but then declined by about 60% to 1.6-2.1 thousand t in 2007-2013, with a low of 1.1 thousand t recorded in 2010. In eastern Sakhalin, targeted fishing began in the 1950s and the stock gradually declined as the average annual catch declined significantly to 4.6 thousand tons in the 1960s, 2.9 thousand t in the 1970s and less than 1 thousand t by the early 1980s. A flounder fishing moratorium was implemented from 1981 to 1990. Fishing was reinstated with stricter controls in 1991-1994, and catches gradually increased to 5.6 thousand t in 2000 and afterwards averaged 2.7 thousand tons to 2013, with a range from 1.6-4.6 thousand t. Similar to the subpopulation off western Sakhalin, that off the eastern coast is also suspected to be undergoing some level of overfishing in the 2000s based on changes in the size and age composition of individuals in the catches in 2000-2012 (Zolotov et al. 2014). Survey CPUE in east Sakhalin since 2013 slightly declined over time to 2018 and the species did not occur in survey catches in 2015 and 2016 (I. Volvenko pers. comm. 2020).

In the Pacific waters off the northern Kurils and southeastern Kamchatka, the highest survey indices were observed during 1994-1998, with lowest values in 1992-1993 and 1999-2002 (Orlov and Tokranov 2014). On the western Kamchatka shelf, this species constitutes the majority of the flounder catch and its stock increased until the late 1990s (Dyakov 2009). According to scientific surveys conducted on the western Kamchatka shelf, biomass of all species of Pleuronectidae harvested significantly declined from a peak of a little over 1 million tons in 1997 to about 400 thousand t in 2000, and catches remained between 400-500 thousand t until the terminal year of data in 2010. This decline is thought to be due to natural causes rather than overfishing since exploitation levels were below catch limits (Gorbatenko and Savin 2012). Survey CPUE of this species in western Kamchatka since 2010 was stable over time to 2018 (I. Volvenko pers. comm. 2020). In southeastern Kamchatka, this species constitutes a lower proportion (15%) of the flounder catch. Stocks of flounder declined there in the 1960s to a minimum in the mid-1970s, increased in the 1980s to the mid-1990s and then declined again from 2001-2006. Declines are thought to be due to natural cycles, but further study is needed (Zolotov and Zakharov 2008). In northeastern Kamchatka in the Karaginsky and Olutorsky bays, this species constitutes 45-85% of the catch in Danish seine and trawl fisheries, and declines in size and age of this species in the early 2000s are thought to have been caused by overfishing (Zolotov 2008). Off Primorye, in the Sea of Japan, where this species constitutes a dominant portion of the flatfish catch, abundance of flatfishes declined since the mid-1990s to at least the early 2000s. Since fishing levels were low and slightly declined over time, this decline is inferred to be due to changes in productivity during the natural 50-year cycling of cold and warm periods. Flatfish abundance was high during warm periods and low during cold periods (Antonenko 2007).

United States: The abundance of this species is naturally lower in the Gulf of Alaska than it is in the Bering Sea. In the Gulf of Alaska, this species is managed as part of the "shallow-water flatfish stock complex", which besides this species, is primarily composed of Alaska Plaice (Pleuronectes quadrituberculatus), English Sole (Parophrys vetulus), Sand Sole (Psettichthys melanostictus), Starry Flounder (Platichthys stellatus), Butter Sole (Isopsetta isolepis), Northern Rock Sole (Lepidopsetta polyxystra), and Southern Rock Sole (Lepidopsetta bilineata). According to the most recent stock assessment, overfishing is not occurring and the exploitation rate on this complex is relatively low. According to scientific surveys conducted from 1984 to 2019 in the Gulf of Alaska, biomass of this species declined overall by 43% from 1984 to 2019, or over the past 35 years (Turnock et al. 2017, Bryan 2019). This decline is not well understood, but fishing was not likely to be a driver. The exploitation rate (i.e., catch/biomass) has been less than 0.001 per year since 1993 (Bryan 2019). Temperature-mediated differences in seasonal spawning migrations into and out of inshore areas effect the availability of the population to trawl surveys in the eastern Bering Sea (Nichol et al. 2019), and a similar phenomenon may affect survey-based biomass estimates in the Gulf of Alaska. The connectivity between the Eastern Bering Sea and the Gulf of Alaska is not well understood. However, a large proportion of the population in the Gulf of Alaska is concentrated near the western boundary of the survey area, and there are no notable barriers between the survey area and the Aleutian Islands to the west, or the Bering Sea to the north. Thus, some proportion of the population may be moving out of the Gulf of Alaska and into the surrounding regions over time (M. Bryan and D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020). 

This is one of the most abundant flatfish species in the eastern Bering Sea, but it is encountered in low abundance in the Aleutian Islands. The bottom trawl fishery, which included foreign fleets, began targeting this species on the Bering Sea shelf in 1954 and this stock was overexploited by 1959-1962. In the later 1970s, fishing effort was reduced, and the stock showed recovery by the early 1980s. The most recent assessment of the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands stock concluded that overfishing is not occurring and it is not overfished nor approaching an overfished condition, but the stock has been in a slowly declining condition since 1994, or over the past 26 years. According to scientific surveys conducted in the eastern Bering Sea since 1982, biomass declined by 45% from 1983 to 1986, and has mostly fluctuated somewhat at around 2 to 2.5 million tons since then (34 years). Variability in this survey's estimate of biomass is in part due to the level of overlap in the timing of the survey and timing of annual spawning migrations into nearshore areas not sampled by the survey. The migration to inshore spawning grounds occurs earlier than normal in warm water years and somatic growth also increases. Biomass estimates are generally lower in years with colder shelf bottom temperatures. Water temperature has been warmer than the mean annual temperature in recent years. Survey biomass in the northern Bering Sea increased from 310,617 t in 2010 to 520,029 t in 2019. A large-scale shift of abundance from the eastern Bering Sea to the northern part has not yet been detected but this possibility should be monitored as climate change progresses. Total biomass and female spawning biomass (FSB) have been modeled for the 65-year period of 1954 to 2019. Total biomass was low in the 1960s and early 1970s, but doubled between 1975 and 1979, peaked at 4,025,010 t in 1985 and slowly declined thereafter by 23% to 3,090,480 t in 2019, or over the past 35 years. FSB increased to a peak of 1,455,350 t in 1994 and then gradually declined thereafter by 27% to 1,062,990 t in 2019, or over the past 26 years. This decline is likely caused by mostly below average recruitment strength in the years from 1984-2005. Compared to 1964 (26,218 t), FSB increased significantly to 2019 (1,062,990 t), or over the past three generations. FSB is projected to slightly increase through 2032. The exploitation rate is low to moderate (Nichol et al. 2019, Spies et al. 2019). Due to warming temperatures in the Bering Sea, the population might be shifting northward outside the historical extent of scientific surveys, and this would introduce uncertainty to biomass estimates (I. Spies and D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020).
range: This species is distributed in the North Pacific and Arctic oceans from Korea to the Beaufort Sea, and south to Canada (Hart 1973, Mecklenburg et al. 2002). In the western Pacific, it occurs in the Sea of Japan, from Busan (South Korea), Peter the Great Bay, Primorye, and the Tatar Strait; all coasts of Hokkaido; the Sea of Okhotsk; southeastern Kamchatka; the Bering, Chukchi, and Beaufort seas; and south to Barkley Sound, British Columbia, Canada (Hart 1973, Sakamoto 1984a,b; Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Shinohara et al. 2011, Nakabo 2013, Parin et al. 2014). The depth range is 4-716 metres, but it typically occurs shallower than 150 m (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Shinohara et al. 2011, Nakabo 2013, Parin et al. 2014, Kells et al. 2016, I. Volvenko pers. comm. 2020).
useTrade: This species is the target of the largest flatfish fishery in the world. It is targeted by commercial fisheries throughout its range.
conservationActions:
Harvest of this species in U.S. waters is managed by NOAA Fisheries and the North Pacific Fishery Management Council under the Fishery Management Plans for Groundfish of the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands, and Gulf of Alaska. Fishing regulations include permit requirements and annual total catch limits. The fishery is monitored, and long-term scientific surveys are in place. In Russian waters, annual catch limits and seasonal area closures to bottom trawl fishing likely provide some conservation benefit to this species (Zolotov et al. 2014). 
 
Genetic studies are needed to improve the understanding of stock mixing. Studies are also needed on maturity at age and juvenile growth in relation to habitat quality (Spies et al. 2019). The distributional shifts in the eastern Bering Sea due to changes in water temperatures should be monitored for impacts on this species and other aspects of that ecosystem (Stevenson and Lauth 2019). Specifically, more extensive monitoring of movements northward and/or to inshore areas is needed as the water temperatures in the southeastern Bering Sea are predicted to increase and ice extent decrease over the next decades (Nichol et al. 2019).

rationale:
This widely distributed, demersal species inhabits relatively shallow coastal areas, including estuaries. It is taken in commercial bottom trawl fisheries. Life history parameters are relatively poorly understood for this species. Using age at maturity data for a proxy species, the generation length is estimated at about 13 years, though this may be an overestimate, as the proxy species is substantially longer-lived than the Longhead Dab. In the U.S. Bering Sea, survey biomass declined by about 90% from 2007 to 2015, or over about one past generation. The cause of this decline is not fully understood, but it is not likely related to fishing pressure, as exploitation levels are relatively low. Rather, as is the case for Limanda aspera, another relatively shallow-water species occurring in the eastern Bering Sea, the decline may be related to a population range shift into shallower and more northern waters, where surveys do not extend into or only inadequately sample. Consequently, the biomass estimated by the present survey may not adequately reflect that of the Eastern Pacific subpopulation. This limitation introduces uncertainty to the biomass estimates for this species in this region. Catch per unit effort in Russian scientific surveys conducted since 1976 slightly increased over time. Based on these data, this species is listed as Least Concern. Limitations associated with the biomass data in the eastern Bering Sea and poor understanding of the cause of the decline in survey biomass is of concern regarding the status of this species in the eastern Bering Sea. Recommendations include: collecting quantitative data to verify a potential northward population shift, by expanding survey effort into northern and coastal parts of the Bering Sea; to evaluate the impacts of changing water temperatures and sea ice extent on the spatial distribution of this species; as well as to conduct further research regarding certain aspects of its life history. 

The findings and conclusions in this document are those of the authors, and do not necessarily represent the views of the National Marine Fisheries Service.
habitat:
This demersal species inhabits soft bottoms on the continental shelf (Mecklenburg et al. 2002), including brackish lagoons and estuaries (Schmidt 1950, Dyldin and Orlov 2017). It consumes amphipods, copepods, crustaceans and bivalves (Alfonso 2018). The maximum total length is 41 cm (Andriashev 1954; Mecklenburg et al. 2002, 2018), but more commonly occurs to 30 cm or less (D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020).

According to work by the Alaska Fisheries Science Center, the natural mortality rate is about 0.26 and it has been aged to a maximum of 16 years (https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/alaska/commercial-fishing/fish-species-maximum-age-data). Ageing structures of this species are infrequently collected during surveys, and age at first maturity is not known. The closest potential proxy species is the Alaska Plaice (Pleuronectes quadrituberculatus), which has a maximum total length of 62 cm, maximum age of 37 years (Matta 2012), a natural mortality of 0.13 (Wilderbuer and Nichol 2019), and an age at first maturity of 9.5 years (TenBrink and Wilderbuer 2015). Based on these data, generation length for P. quadrituberculatus was estimated as 17 years. By comparison, Myzopsetta proboscidea is shorter-lived and smaller-bodied, so its generation length is inferred to be less than 17 years. If an age at first maturity of 9 years and a natural mortality of 0.26 is applied to the equation recommended by the IUCN Red List methods: 1/adult mortality + age of first reproduction, the generation length is estimated to be about 13 years. However, additional research on species-specific life history parameters is needed to refine this estimate.
threats: Fishing activity is not expected to be driving population declines approaching levels at which the species would qualify even for Near Threatened status at this time.
population:
Russia: This species is common in Russian waters (Parin et al. 2014). According to Russian scientific trawl surveys conducted over the past 42 years (since the late 1970s), the catch per unit effort (CPUE) of this species slightly increased over time (I. Volvenko pers. comm. 2020). Since the 1980-1990 period, the density of this species increased in the Anadyr Bay/Navara region to the 2011-2018 period and was stable or increasing during the same periods in western Kamchatka (Shuntov and Volvenko 2020).

United States: This species is rare along the Arctic North American coast to Bathurst Inlet (Mecklenburg et al. 2018). In the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands, it is most common in coastal parts of the Bering Sea, and naturally uncommon in the Aleutians (D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020). It is managed as part of the "other flatfish complex", which besides this species, primarily comprises Rex Sole (Glyptocephalus zachirus), Starry Flounder (Platichthys stellatus), Dover Sole (Microstomus pacificus) and Butter Sole (Isopsetta isolepis). It is not targeted in this area but is retained as bycatch in fisheries that target other flatfish species and Pacific Cod. In recent years, the majority of the catch within the "other flatfish complex" has been represented by Starry Flounder (Platichthys stellatus) and Rex Sole (Glyptocephalus zachirus). The stock is considered only lightly exploited, with biomass across the complex currently at a relatively high level. Fishery-independent scientific surveys have been conducted annually in the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands since 1982. Survey biomass of this species in the Bering Sea was highest in 1982 at 103,806 t before declining from 1983 to 1985 to 9,107 t, although the variability around these data years is high. From 1985 to 2007, biomass was stable at an average of 13,000 t, but since 2007 it declined by about 90% from 16,733 t to a time series low of 1,647 t in 2015 (Wilderbuer and Nichol 2015, 2018, 2019). The cause of this decline is not well understood, but is not thought to be related to fishing activities. The survey in the Bering Sea does not sample the shallow, coastal parts of the distribution of this species, which introduces uncertainty to the biomass estimates. In addition, substantial areas of suitable habitat are available in the Bering Sea, an area not regularly surveyed, where this species is potentially shifting northward to as sea ice extent decreases over time (D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020).
range: This species is distributed in the North Pacific and adjacent Arctic Ocean (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, 2016, 2018; Alfonso 2018). Off northern Hokkaido, Japan, it occurs off Mombetsu and Abashiri. In Russian waters, it is found off the northern Kuril Islands to Sakhalin, including the northern Sea of Okhotsk and southeastern Kamchatka. It occurs in the Bering Sea to Unimak Island, Alaska; the southern Chukchi Sea; with a few records from Point Barrow in the Beaufort Sea, and from Arctic Canada east to Bathurst Inlet (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, 2016, 2018; Nakabo 2013; Parin et al. 2014; Dyldin and Orlov 2017; Alfonso 2018). Its depth range is 0-540 metres (Parin et al. 2014, Kells et al. 2016, I. Volvenko pers. comm. 2020), but it usually occurs shallower than 100 m (Mecklenburg et al. 2002).
useTrade: This is a commercial species in the Sea of Okhotsk (Pustovoit and Yusupov 2016) and off Kamchatka, Russia (Zolotov 2010). It is retained as bycatch in demersal fisheries in U.S. waters (Wilderbuer and Nichol 2015).
conservationActions:
The population of this species in US waters is closely monitored through scientific surveys and annual stock assessments. It is managed through the Bering Sea/Aleutian Islands Groundfish Fishery Management Plan. Fishing is regulated through permitting, size limits, daily and total catch limits, seasonal and area fishing closures, gear restrictions, and a trawl catch share program. 

Additional research is needed on life history characteristics and on its abundance in the shallower parts of its range. As with Limanda aspera, more extensive monitoring of movements northward and/or to inshore areas is needed as the water temperatures in the southeastern Bering Sea are predicted to increase and ice extent decrease over the next decades (Nichol et al. 2019).

rationale: This widely distributed, demersal species is common and abundant in parts of its range. The estimated generation length is 13 years. It is not targeted by commercial fisheries, but when captured as bycatch, it is retained and marketed. It has a relatively low market value. According to scientific surveys conducted in waters of Russia and the United States, abundance has been increasing in parts of its range in recent decades, and no major threats are known; therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This demersal species occurs on sand and mud bottoms on the continental shelf and upper slope (Parin et al. 2014, Kells et al. 2016, Mecklenburg et al. 2018). The maximum total length is 36 cm (Orlov and Tokranov 2014). The oldest individual (22 years) was collected in the western Bering Sea (Dyakov 2014). Length and age at first maturity is 13 cm and 3 years. Spawning occurs on the western Kamchatka shelf at 40-60 m depth in July to August (Lindberg and Fedorov 1993 cited in Napazakov 2014). When applying an age at first reproduction of 3 years and longevity of 22 years, the estimated generation length for this species is 13 years, based on the following equation recommended by the IUCN Red List methods: Age at first reproduction + (Age at last reproduction – age at first reproduction)/2.
threats: No major threats are known.
population:
Russia: This species is common and abundant in Aniva Bay located in the Sea of Okhotsk off southern Sakhalin Island (Dyldin et al. 2018), on the western Kamchatka shelf, and on the shelf of the northern Sea of Okhotsk (Shuntov and Temnykh 2018, Saveliev et al. 2019). It is common off western Sakhalin (Kim and Kim 2019) and northeastern Kamchatka (Orlov et al. 2020). It is less common off the northern Kuril Islands and southeastern Kamchatka (Orlov and Tokranov 2014, Savin et al. 2019). It is rare in the northwestern part of the Sea of Japan (Panchenko et al. 2016). Abundance and spawning stock biomass of this species increased significantly from 1963 to at least 2014 in the eastern Sea of Okhotsk (Dyakov 2015, 2016). Biomass of this species has been increasing since 2005 off northeastern Sakhalin (Tok 2014). According to Russian scientific trawl surveys conducted over the past 42 years (since the late 1970s), the catch per unit effort of this species increased slightly over time (I. Volvenko pers. comm. 2020). Since the 1980-1990 period, the density of this species increased significantly to the 2011-2018 period (Shuntov and Volvenko 2020).

United States: This species is present, but not particularly abundant in Barrow Canyon located in the northeastern Chukchi Sea and western Beaufort Sea (Logerwell et al. 2018). In the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands, this species is managed as part of "the other flatfish complex", which is primarily composed of Rex Sole (Glyptocephalus zachirus), Starry Flounder (Platichthys stellatus), Longhead Dab (Myzopsetta proboscidea), and Dover Sole (Microstomus pacificus). It is not targeted in this area but is retained as bycatch in fisheries that target other flatfish species and Pacific Cod. It is a minor component of catches, with an average of less than one ton taken annually from 1995-2016. In recent years, the majority of the catch within "the other flatfish complex" is represented by Starry Flounder (Platichthys stellatus) and Rex Sole (Glyptocephalus zachirus). The stock is considered lightly exploited. In general, this species is relatively rare on the shelf in the eastern Bering Sea, and more common north of this area. It prefers cold water, and according to scientific surveys conducted in the eastern Bering Sea, it was more abundant in the 1980s and 1990s when waters were colder than average. Although temperatures have been warmer in recent years, biomass appears to be increasing (Wilderbuer and Nichol 2015, Conners et al. 2016).
range: This species is distributed in the western North Pacific Ocean and adjacent Arctic Ocean from the Sea of Japan, from Northern Primorye to the Tatar Strait; off Hokkaido, Japan; the Sea of Okhotsk, including the Kuril Islands off Kamchatka; the Bering Sea off Koryak Land; the southeastern Chukchi Sea; and off St. Lawrence Island, Alaska to the southeastern Bering Sea. The depth range is 9-415 m (Nakabo 2013, Parin et al. 2014, Panchenko et al. 2016, Mecklenburg et al. 2018). Some distributional records may reflect confusion in at-sea identifications of this species as it is easily confused with Limanda aspera or species of Hippoglossoides (Napazakov 2015, Mecklenburg et al. 2018, Han et al. 2019).
useTrade: This species is exploited by commercial fisheries in Russian waters (Parin et al. 2014), but has a low market value due to its small size (Orlov and Tokranov 2014). It is occasionally taken as bycatch in Danish seine and bottom trawl fisheries off eastern Kamchatka (Vasilets et al. 2019, Terentyev et al. 2019). In the eastern Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands, it is retained as bycatch in commercial trawl fisheries (Wilderbuer and Nichol 2015).
conservationActions: The subpopulation of this species in U.S. waters is monitored through scientific surveys and annual stock assessments. Stocks are managed through the Bering Sea/Aleutian Islands Groundfish Fishery Management Plan. Fishing is regulated through permitting, size limits, daily and total catch limits, seasonal and area fishing closures, gear restrictions, and a trawl catch share program.

rationale:
This widely distributed, demersal species is long-lived and has an estimated generation length of 24 years. It is taken in commercial, demersal fisheries throughout its range, but remains lightly exploited. Regular stock assessments and long-term fishery independent scientific surveys are conducted in the Gulf of Alaska, which is the only part of the range of this species where it is directly targeted. It is not overfished, and overfishing is not occurring, and annual catches have been well below the total allowable catch limit in recent years. Modeled total biomass for the Gulf of Alaska shows about a 40% decline since 1987, or 33 years (about one and a half generation lengths) although there is some uncertainty associated with this trend as most scientific surveys do not extend to the deep depths that this species occupies. Biomass in the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands has been mostly increasing since the 1990s. The stock in Canada is stable. Spawning biomass models for the U.S. West coast (Washington to California) show a slight decline (about 18%) since the 1920s. Shifts in biomass may be caused by movements that the species conducts ontogenetically to offshore areas, as well as movements to follow preferable water temperatures, which can fluctuate interannually. Comprehensive fisheries management and the conservation measures related to this are expected to remain in place in the U.S. and Canada. It does not meet the quantitative thresholds to qualify even for a Near Threatened status at this time; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern with a recommendation to conduct research on the cause of the possible decline in the Gulf of Alaska. 

The findings and conclusions in this document are those of the authors, and do not necessarily represent the views of the National Marine Fisheries Service.
habitat:
This demersal species occurs over sandy and muddy bottoms from nearshore to the continental slope. The maximum total length is 76 cm (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Kells et al. 2016). Individuals migrate to deeper depths with age, and adults typically occur deeper than 300 m. It exhibits an extended spawning season in the Gulf of Alaska from January to August with a peak in May (Abookire and Macewicz 2003). Females conduct a seasonal feeding migration to shallower depths on the mid-continental shelf in the summer. Diets consist of benthic infaunal (mostly) and epifaunal invertebrates (Hart 1973).

The maximum observed age is 59 years, age at first maturity is 12.5 years, and the natural mortality rate is 0.085 (McGilliard et al. 2019). When applying the equation recommended by the IUCN Red List methods: 1/adult mortality + age of first reproduction, the generation length is estimated to be 24 years.
threats: Fishing activity is not expected to be driving population declines approaching levels at which the species would qualify even for Near Threatened status at this time.
population:
Connectivity between stocks in the Gulf of Alaska and British Columbia and the U.S. West coast stock (Washington to California) is poorly understood (Wetzel and Hamel 2019). This species is rare in Russian waters and more numerous in the eastern Pacific (I. Volvenko pers. comm. 2020).

Canada: The Dover Sole fishery of British Columbia has been operating since 1954 but was relatively small prior to 1970. The exploitation rate has been low in recent years. Biomass in the Hecate Strait stock has been increasing since 1984. The Queen Charlotte Sound stock biomass has been increasing since 2006. The West Coast of Vancouver Island stock biomass has had a flat trend since 2006. Overall, it is not considered overfished and overfishing is not occurring, although the stock assessment recognized a significant amount of uncertainty associated with the relative terminal biomass and harvest rate (Johnson and Cox 2019).

United States: In the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands, this species is managed as part of the "other flatfish complex", which besides this species, primarily consists of Rex Sole (Glyptocephalus zachirus), Starry Flounder (Platichthys stellatus), Longhead Dab (Myzopsetta proboscidea) and Butter Sole (Isopsetta isolepis). It is not targeted in this area but is retained as bycatch in fisheries that target other flatfish species and Pacific Cod. In recent years, the majority of the catch within the "other flatfish complex" is represented by Starry Flounder (Platichthys stellatus) and Rex Sole (Glyptocephalus zachirus), but overall, the exploitation rate has been relatively low since 1997. The stock is considered only lightly exploited with biomass across the complex currently at a relatively high level. Fishery-independent scientific surveys have been conducted annually in the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands since 1982, but this species composes a small part of the catch in part due to its deeper depth preference beyond the scope of most surveys. Also, it is naturally relatively rare in the Bering Sea, with a much higher abundance in the Gulf of Alaska, although this could be partly attributed to the limited sampling effort in deeper depth strata. Commercial fishing in Alaskan waters also does not frequently occur at the deeper depths that this species occupies (D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020). Nonetheless, modeled biomass of this species has had a mostly increasing trend in this area since at least about 1990. The next full stock assessment will be published in 2020 (Wilderbuer and Nichol 2015, 2018, 2019).

In the Gulf of Alaska, this species is managed as part of the "deepwater flatfish complex", which besides this species, is also composed of Greenland Turbot (Reinhardtius hippoglossoides) and Deepsea Sole (Microstomus bathybius). The Dover Sole (Microstomus pacificus) composes the majority (77%) of the catch. According to the most recent assessment of this stock, overfishing is not occurring, and this stock is not overfished nor approaching an overfished condition. Fishery-independent scientific surveys conducted annually in the Gulf of Alaska since 1990 show that biomass has mostly declined over the past 29 years, or a little over one past generation. Survey biomass was 104,959 t in 1990, experienced a secondary peak of 101,509 t in 2003 and reached a low of 48,452 t in 2019, which represents about a 54% decline. Total biomass and spawning biomass have been modeled for 1978 to 2021 (over nearly two past generations). Total biomass peaked in 1987 at 143,062 t and shows a gradual decline thereafter of 41% to a low of 84,771 t in 2021. Spawning biomass showed a similar trend with a peak in 1989 at 48,650 t and a gradual 45% decline to 27,011 t in 2021. Spawning biomass has been in a declining trend since 2013. The decline in biomass is not well-understood but could reflect changes in its catchability or natural mortality. Fishing intensity has been exceptionally low and annual catches have been well below the total allowable catch limit (TAC) in recent years in part due to a shift in targeting. Over the history of the fishery, catches have been exceptionally low except in the years from 1991 to 1993 (McGilliard et al. 2019). The relatively high exploitation rate in the 1990s could have contributed to this decline, but fishing effort has declined overall. Availability of this species to the surveys introduces uncertainty to the survey biomass trend. Survey effort in the deeper depth strata of the Gulf of Alaska has decreased, and a warm period in 2016 may have caused the population to shift to deeper, colder waters that are outside the survey extent (D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020).

On the U.S. West coast (Washington to California), this species is common and abundant and has been commercially exploited there since the early 20th century. According to fishery independent scientific surveys conducted in 1980-2013, spawning biomass declined from about 430,000 t in 1980 to 300,000 t in 1995 and then increased until 2010 to 400,000 t before declining again until 2013 to 360,000 t. This stock has tended to move northward along this coast since the mid-1990s (Selden et al. 2020). In this region, specifically the California Current System, recruitment success and the spatial distribution of biomass of this species fluctuates with climate/environmental conditions, with abundance shifting southward during cool phases and northward during warm phases (Keller et al. 2013). Landings of this species have been declining across all three states (Washington, Oregon and California) since 2009, but the exploitation rate has remained low and spawning biomass is well above the management target. According to models, spawning biomass declined slightly (about 18%) over the entire time series, or since the 1920s. Spawning biomass declined slightly between the 1970s and early 1990s, reached a low in the mid-1990s, increased through much of the 2000s, and then declined slightly from 2010 to 2019. There is uncertainty in estimating recruitment trends over time (Wetzel and Hamel 2019). 

Mexico: This species is common off Baja California but is not the most common species of Pleuronectidae (Martínez-Muñoz et al. 2013).
range: This species is distributed in the North Pacific from the southeastern Bering Sea, including Navarin Canyon in Russian waters, and the Aleutian Islands of Alaska, south to southern Baja California, Mexico (Mecklenburg et al. 2002). Records off Koryak Land and Bering Island are misidentifications (Parin et al. 2014). The depth range is 1-1,500 metres (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Parin et al. 2014, Kells et al. 2016, McGilliard et al. 2019).
useTrade: This species is targeted by the multi-species bottom trawl fishery in the Gulf of Alaska. It is also taken as bycatch in other demersal Gulf of Alaska fisheries, including those that target Pacific Cod, Walleye (=Alaska) Pollock and other flatfishes, but it is frequently discarded (McGilliard et al. 2019). Elsewhere in its range, including the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands as well as the U.S. West coast (Washington to California), it is retained as bycatch in groundfish trawl fisheries (Wilderbuer and Nichol 2015, Selden et al. 2020). It is also taken in demersal trawl fisheries off British Columbia, Canada (Johnson and Cox 2019). It is taken in trawl fisheries off Baja California, Mexico, but has a low commercial value there (Martínez-Muñoz et al. 2013).
conservationActions: The population of this species in the United States is closely monitored through scientific surveys and annual stock assessments. Stocks from Alaska to California in the United States are managed through the Pacific Coast Groundfish Fishery Management Plan, the Gulf of Alaska Groundfish Fishery Management Plan and the Bering Sea/Aleutian Islands Groundfish Fishery Management Plan. Fishing is regulated through permitting, size limits, daily and total catch limits, seasonal and area fishing closures, gear restrictions, and a trawl catch share program.

rationale:
This widely distributed, demersal species has an estimated generation length of 9 years. It is retained as bycatch in demersal, commercial fisheries throughout its range. According to fishery independent scientific surveys, biomass in the Aleutian Islands has been fluctuating with no clear trend since at least 1991. Biomass in the Gulf of Alaska increased overall since 1984 with peaks in biomass occurring within the past decade, including the most recent year of 2019. In the U.S. West Coast stock (Washington to California), spawning biomass has been increasing since the 1970s. Several stringent fishery management measures are in place throughout its range. Of concern is the degradation of estuaries throughout its range. Juveniles are estuarine-dependent and these areas provide essential nursery habitat. At this time, declines are not expected to be approaching even a Near Threatened status. It is listed as Least Concern. 

The findings and conclusions in this document are those of the authors, and do not necessarily represent the views of the National Marine Fisheries Service.
habitat:
This demersal species occurs over soft bottoms from the lower intertidal zone to the continental slope (Mecklenburg et al. 2002). The maximum total length is 61 cm (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Kells et al. 2016). This species may undertake seasonal migrations into shallower water during spring and then moving into deeper water during winter (Hart 1973). Spawning occurs on the continental shelf break and larvae are transported to nearshore and estuarine nursery habitats (Stowell et al. 2019). Diets consist mainly of clams and clam siphons, other small molluscs, marine worms, small crabs and shrimps, and brittle stars (Hart 1973).

Longevity is 23 years and age at maturity is 4 years (Cope et al. 2015). Natural mortality is estimated as 0.2 (Turnock et al. 2017) and 0.26 (Cope et al. 2015). When applying the equation recommended by the IUCN Red List methods: 1/adult mortality + age of first reproduction, the generation length is estimated to be about 9 years.
threats: Fishing activity is not considered a major threat at this time. Degradation of estuarine habitats due to coastal development and pollution, including impacts from hypoxia caused by eutrophication, are known to negatively affect this species during the juvenile stage (Hughes et al. 2015). In addition, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) exposure, which frequently occurs in estuarine habitats, has negative impacts on the reproduction of this species (Moser et al. 2013).
population:
In the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands, this species is naturally relatively rare and is much more abundant in the Gulf of Alaska. It is managed as part of the "other flatfish complex", which primarily comprises the Dover Sole (Microstomus pacificus), Rex Sole (Glyptocephalus zachirus), Starry Flounder (Platichthys stellatus), Longhead Dab (Myzopsetta proboscidea), and Butter Sole (Isopsetta isolepis). It is not targeted in this area but is retained as bycatch in fisheries that target other flatfish species and Pacific Cod. In recent years, the majority of the catch within the "other flatfish complex" is represented by Starry Flounder (Platichthys stellatus) and Rex Sole (Glyptocephalus zachirus), but overall, the exploitation rate has been relatively low since 1997. The stock is considered only lightly exploited with biomass across the complex currently at a relatively high level. Fishery-independent scientific surveys have been conducted annually in the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands since 1982. This species does not occur in the Bering Sea shelf surveys but does occur in Aleutian Islands surveys (conducted since 1991). Biomass of this species in the Aleutians fluctuated over time with no distinct trend. The next full stock assessment will be published in 2020 (Wilderbuer and Nichol 2015, 2018, 2019).

In the Gulf of Alaska, this species is managed as part of the "shallow-water flatfish stock complex", which besides this species, is primarily composed of Alaska Plaice (Pleuronectes quadrituberculatus), Starry Flounder (Platichthys stellatus), Sand Sole (Psettichthys melanostictus), Butter Sole (Isopsetta isolepis), Yellowfin Sole (Limanda aspera), Northern Rock Sole (Lepidopsetta polyxystra) and Southern Rock Sole (Lepidopsetta bilineata). According to the most recent stock assessment, overfishing is not occurring and the exploitation rate on this complex is relatively low. According to scientific surveys, biomass of this species in the Gulf of Alaska from 1984 to 2019 increased overall from a low of 3,202 t in 1984 to peaks in 2009 of 18,671 t and in 2019 of 18,414 t. This species is not directly targeted, and catches and exploitation rate are relatively low (Turnock et al. 2017, Bryan 2019).

This species is common and abundant in waters off the U.S. West coast from Washington to southern California (Miller and Schiff 2012, Hughes et al. 2015, Mulligan et al. 2017, Sobocinski et al. 2018, Stowell et al. 2019, Gross et al. 2019, Burns et al. 2019). It has been taken in bottom trawl fisheries since the late 1800s. A stock assessment conducted in 2007 concluded the biomass was at or above the target biomass since 2000. According to the most recent assessment (2015), which includes landings reported for the states of Washington, Oregon and California, overfishing is not occurring, and this stock is not overfished. According to the modeled spawning biomass, declines occurred from about 1915 to 1970, and then increased to levels near those of the 1880s and early 1900s by 2015. The exploitation rate of this species has been relatively low in the last few decades (Cope et al. 2015). Recruitment success was particularly high in the 1990s (Keller et al. 2011). In this region, specifically the California Current System, recruitment success and the spatial distribution of biomass of this species fluctuates with climate/environmental conditions, with abundance indices being higher during cool phases (Keller et al. 2013). Declines in juvenile abundance have been observed in Elkhorn Slough during years with elevated hypoxia, which causes reduced recruitment success (Hughes et al. 2015).
range: This species is distributed in the eastern North Pacific off Alaska from Nunivak Island to the Alaska Peninsula and Aleutian Islands to San Cristobal Bay, central Baja California, Mexico (Hart 1973, Mecklenburg et al. 2002). The depth range is 1-550 metres (Hart 1973, Mecklenburg et al. 2002), but most commonly, it occurs shallower than 200-250 m (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Cope et al. 2015).
useTrade: This species is not directly targeted but is retained as bycatch in commercial trawl fisheries throughout its range. It has long been a popular fish in British Columbia (Hart 1973).
conservationActions: The subpopulation of this species in waters of the United States is closely monitored through scientific surveys and annual stock assessments. U.S. stocks are managed through the Pacific Coast Groundfish Fishery Management Plan, the Gulf of Alaska Groundfish Fishery Management Plan, and the Bering Sea/Aleutian Islands Groundfish Fishery Management Plan. Fishing is regulated through permitting, size limits, daily and total catch limits, seasonal and area fishing closures, gear restrictions, and a trawl catch share program.

rationale:
This widely distributed, demersal species prefers cold waters. It has an estimated generation length of 17 years. It is exploited by demersal commercial fisheries throughout its range. According to fishery independent scientific surveys, biomass on the eastern Bering Sea shelf has been gradually declining since 1984 (over about two past generations), but remains at sustainable levels. This decline may be attributed to a northward shift in the population to areas beyond the extent of surveys. Exploitation has been light, and it is not considered to be overfished. Biomass in the Gulf of Alaska varies widely from year to year but has increased overall since 1984. Biomass of this species has had an increasing trend over the past two decades in many parts of Russian waters. Catch per unit effort in Russian scientific surveys conducted since 1976 has increased over time. Fishing activity is not expected to be driving population declines approaching levels at which the species would qualify even for Near Threatened status at this time. No major threats are known; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern. To improve future assessments, it is recommended that the possible decline in biomass in the Bering Sea be investigated by increasing scientific survey effort in the northern Bering Sea to document whether a northward shift in the distribution is occurring.

The findings and conclusions in this document are those of the authors, and do not necessarily represent the views of the National Marine Fisheries Service.
habitat:
This demersal species occurs on sand, silt and mud bottoms from the continental shelf to the slope. It also enters estuaries and brackish lagoons (Dyldin and Orlov 2017). Juveniles occur in shallow coastal waters and larger individuals occur deeper, but typically shallower than 110 m in summer. The physiology of this species allows it to tolerate very cold temperatures as the blood contains a glycol-protein that inhibits ice crystal formation. It is not known what impact warm waters has on the species, but it does appear to prefer colder temperatures. The maximum total length is 66 cm (Datsky and Maznikova 2017, Mecklenburg et al. 2018), but according to Zhang et al. (1998), an average size of trawl caught fish in the Bering Sea is about 32 cm. 

Natural mortality is estimated at 0.13 (Wilderbuer and Nichol 2019). Age and length at first maturity are 32 cm and 9.5 years (TenBrink and Wilderbuer 2015). According to work by the Alaska Fisheries Science Center, it has been aged to a maximum of 37 years (Matta 2012). When applying the equation recommended by the IUCN Red List methods: 1/adult mortality + age of first reproduction, the generation length is estimated to be about 17 years.
threats: Fishing activity is not expected to be driving population declines approaching levels at which the species would qualify even for Near Threatened status at this time.
population:
Russia: In Russian waters, this species has the highest density off western Kamchatka and in the Bering Sea (Napazakov 2018). It is not uncommon off the western coast of Sakhalin Island (Kim and Kim 2019). It is common and abundant in the northwestern Sea of Okhotsk (Saveliev et al. 2019) and common in the northwestern Bering Sea (Savin 2018) and off northeastern Kamchatka (Orlov et al. 2020). It is rare in the northwestern Sea of Japan (Panchenko et al. 2016) and has a low abundance in the Kuril Islands (Orlov and Tokranov 2014). According to Russian scientific trawl surveys conducted over the past 42 years (since the late 1970s), the catch per unit effort of this species increased over time (I. Volvenko pers. comm. 2020).

It is taken in commercial fisheries in Terpeniya Bay, in the northern part of the Tatar Strait off the coast of Aleksandrovsk-Sakhalinsky and other more northern areas (Dyldin and Orlov 2017). On the Chukchi shelf, the biomass of this species significantly increased in the early 2010s in part due to a period of particularly cold water present in the area (Gavrilov and Glebov 2013). In the Karaginsky and Olutorsky bays of northeastern Kamchatka, biomass of this species gradually increased since the mid-1990s through to at least 2012. On the West Kamchatka shelf, the flounder stock, which includes this species, is considered underexploited as of 2011. The flounder stock declined in the early 1980s to the 1990s but has been increasing since 2006 to at least 2011. Fishing effort has declined significantly since the 1980s and 1990s (Zolotov et al. 2013). Biomass of this species has been increasing since the early 2000s off northeastern Sakhalin Island (Tok 2014). The multi-species demersal fish stock of the northwestern Bering Sea is dominated by Pacific Cod (Gadus macrocephalus), but Alaska Plaice occupies a subdominant position. Biomass of this mixed-species stock was very high in the mid-1980s, significantly declined in the late 1990s to early 2000s, and has been increasing since the mid-2000s (Savin and Glebov 2016).

United States: This species is more abundant in the Bering Sea as compared to the Gulf of Alaska. In the Gulf of Alaska, this species is managed as part of the "shallow-water flatfish stock complex", which besides this species, is primarily composed of Starry Flounder (Platichthys stellatus), English Sole (Parophrys vetulus), Sand Sole (Psettichthys melanostictus), Butter Sole (Isopsetta isolepis), Yellowfin Sole (Limanda aspera), Northern Rock Sole (Lepidopsetta polyxystra) and Southern Rock Sole (Lepidopsetta bilineata). According to the most recent stock assessment, overfishing is not occurring and the exploitation rate on this complex is relatively low. According to scientific surveys, biomass of this species in the Gulf of Alaska from 1984 to 2019 fluctuated widely between years, but overall, increased over time. Biomass peaked in 2017 at 13,784 t, but then declined the following survey year by 67% to 4,617 t (Turnock et al. 2017, Bryan 2019). 

The Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands stock is mostly concentrated on the eastern Bering Sea shelf, with only small amounts present in the Aleutian Islands. In warm years, it occurs further north, and further south in cold years. From 1975 to 2019, this species has been only lightly exploited, and has been primarily taken as bycatch in the fishery that targets Yellowfin Sole. The stock is in a state of slow decline, but according to the most recent stock assessment, overfishing is not occurring, and it is not overfished nor approaching an overfished condition. Fishery independent scientific surveys were conducted on the eastern Bering Sea shelf in 1975 and from 1979 to 2019.  Estimated total biomass increased from 459,100 t in 1975 to a peak of 750,000 t in 1984, declined to 545,300 t in 2003, increased to 563,300 t in 2006 and gradually declined thereafter to 424,400 t in 2019. Total biomass was relatively stable from 1982 to 2012, but has been declining since 2012. Over the entirety of the period (since 1975 or about two and a half past generations), biomass in 2019 (424,400 t) was near the same level as that of 1975 (459,100 t). Since the peak in 1984, or over the past 35 years (about two generations), biomass declined by 41% to 2019. Survey biomass has also declined since peaking in 1984. Female spawning biomass has slowly declined since 1985 but remains at sustainable levels. Recruitment was below average from 2005 to 2015, which is a particularly extended period and likely contributed to the overall decline in biomass, though strong recruitment occurred in 2014. In years when the survey included stations north of St. Lawrence Island (2010, 2017 and 2019), large amounts of this species were captured, which may indicate some pole-ward movement of the stock occurred, but further investigation is needed. Temperatures in the eastern Bering Sea have varied widely in recent years, and it is not yet understood what potential impact this may have on this species that has a clear preference for cold water (Wilderbuer and Nichol 2019). The population is likely shifting northward outside the survey extent, so the decline in survey biomass may be attributed to that (D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020).
range: This species is distributed in the North Pacific Ocean and adjacent southern Arctic Ocean. In the northwestern Pacific, it occurs throughout the waters surrounding Hokkaido, Japan and off Russia, from Peter the Great Bay to the southern Gulf of Anadyr, the Tatar Strait, the Sea of Okhotsk, the southern and northern Kuril Islands, and southeastern Kamchatka; and in the Bering Sea to the southern Chukchi Sea. In the eastern Pacific, it occurs from the southern Chukchi Sea, to the eastern Bering Sea, to off Unalaska Island, and in the Gulf of Alaska to near Ketchikan, Alaska (Sakamoto 1984; Mecklenburg et al. 2002, 2018). A single record records this species (as P. pallasii) from Bellingham Bay, Washington (Townsend 1936; Sakamoto 1984; Mecklenburg et al. 2002, 2018). The depth range is 0-850 metres (Nakabo 2013, Parin et al. 2014, Kells et al. 2016), but is more common shallower than 200 m (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, 2018; Napazakov 2018).
useTrade: This species is an important component of commercial fisheries in Russian waters in the northwestern Bering Sea (Datsky and Andronov 2014, Parin et al. 2014). It is retained as bycatch in bottom trawl fisheries in U.S. waters, especially in the fishery that targets Yellowfin Sole. It is sometimes discarded due to relatively low market value, though retention has increased in recent years (Wilderbuer and Nichol 2019).
conservationActions:
The subpopulation of this species in U.S. waters is closely monitored through scientific surveys and annual stock assessments. It is managed through the Bering Sea/Aleutian Islands Groundfish Fishery Management Plan and the Gulf of Alaska Groundfish Fishery Management Plan. Fishing is regulated through permitting, size limits, daily and total catch limits, seasonal and area fishing closures, gear restrictions, and a trawl catch share program. Research is needed on the genetic structure of the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands stock (Wilderbuer and Nichol 2019). An increase in scientific survey effort in the northern Bering Sea is needed to better understand likely northward shifts in its distribution and to improve monitoring of abundance trends (D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020).

In Russian waters, there is a common total allowable catch (TAC) for the primary flatfish species (Alaska Plaice, Yellowfin Sole, and Flathead Sole) of the stocks off western Kamchatka. This TAC is based on data from bottom trawl surveys and the mean proportion of particular species in the total flatfish catch (A. Orlov pers. comm. 2020).

rationale:
This widely distributed, demersal species occurs in a variety of habitats from inshore areas to the continental slope. It is common in a large part of its range. No major threats are known; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern. 

The findings and conclusions in this document are those of the authors, and do not necessarily represent the views of the National Marine Fisheries Service.
habitat: This demersal species occurs over a variety of bottom types in estuaries and nearshore habitats from the surf zone to the continental slope. The maximum total length is 36 cm (Miller and Lea 1972, Hart 1973, Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Kells et al. 2016).
threats: No major threats are known. It may be impacted by anthropogenic activities occurring in estuaries and nearshore habitats.
population: This species is common in waters of the San Juan Islands, in the Strait of Georgia, and throughout Puget Sound of Washington state (Pietsch and Orr 2015) as well as in the Southern California Bight (Love et al. 1986, Altstatt et al. 2014). It rarely occurs in scientific surveys conducted in the Gulf of Alaska, although these surveys do not extend into the shallower areas inhabited by this species (D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020).
range: This species is distributed in the eastern North Pacific from Sitka, Alaska, United States to southern Baja California, Mexico (Hart 1973, Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Pietsch and Orr 2015). The depth range is 1-350 metres (Hart 1973, Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Kells et al. 2016), but typically this species occurs shallower than 20 m (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Pietsch and Orr 2015).
useTrade: This species is taken in small quantities and marketed in Canada, but generally it is not commercially valued. It is incidentally captured very rarely in Alaskan fisheries.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place. Its distribution may coincide with marine protected areas in parts of its range.

rationale:
This widely distributed, demersal species is common in parts of its range. It is a minor component in U.S. groundfish trawl fisheries catches. Abundance indices have fluctuated over the past 17 years with a recent declining trend in the data. No major threats are known. It is listed as Least Concern with a recommendation to conduct research on life history parameters and to continue monitoring the recent declining trend to improve future assessments.

The findings and conclusions in this document are those of the authors, and do not necessarily represent the views of the National Marine Fisheries Service.
habitat: This demersal species occurs on soft bottoms along rocky to sandy areas from estuaries to the continental slope. The maximum total length measured is 36 (Fitch 1963, Mecklenburg et al. 2002). Life history data are limited. The only appropriate proxy species would be Pleuronichthys coenosus, but the data needed to estimate generation length are not available for that species either.
threats: No major threats are known. Individuals inhabiting nearshore and estuarine areas may be impacted by anthropogenic activities conducted in these areas.
population:
This species rarely occurs in scientific surveys conducted in the Gulf of Alaska, although these surveys do not extend into the shallower areas inhabited by this species (D. Stevenson pers. comm. 2020). It is rare in the Salish Sea in Washington state (Pietsch and Orr 2015).

It is commonly taken in the annual groundfish survey conducted along the US west coast from Washington to California (Keller et al. 2017). The species shifts its distribution southward and offshore during years of cooler conditions (Keller et al. 2013). According to survey data from 2003 to 2019, the catch per unit effort of this species fluctuated over time with a period of decline from 2003 to 2007, increase from 2011 to 2013, and decline from 2013 to 2019 (NWFSC/FRAM 2020). The cause of the more recent declining trend is not likely due to changes in environmental conditions (e.g., anomalous warm waters), and it remains possible that a future strong year class will cause the trend to increase once again. In addition, differences in survey design, such as variations in the number of vessels available to the survey in some years, may account for some variability in these data (A. Keller pers. comm. 2020).
range: This species is distributed in the eastern North Pacific from the Gulf of Alaska in the United States to off Punta San Juanico, southern Baja California, Mexico (Hart 1973, Mecklenburg et al. 2002). The depth range is 1-533 metres, usually nearshore at depths less than 20 m (Hart 1973, Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Kells et al. 2016).
useTrade: This species is a minor component of U.S. west coast groundfish demersal trawl fisheries catches (Bellman and Heery 2013). Hart (1973) reported this species as having little commercial importance in Canadian fisheries.
conservationActions: The U.S. west coast groundfish demersal trawl fishery is regulated under the Pacific Coast Groundfish Fishery Management Plan and the fishery is limited entry (Bellman and Heery 2013). Its range may overlap with marine protected areas.

rationale:
This widely distributed, relatively shallow-water, demersal species is common in parts of its range and has an estimated generation length of 7 years. It is a relatively minor component in U.S. groundfish trawl fisheries catches. Several stringent fishery management measures are in place throughout its range. No major threats are known; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.

The findings and conclusions in this document are those of the authors, and do not necessarily represent the views of the National Marine Fisheries Service.
habitat:
This demersal species occurs on sandy bottoms from the intertidal zone to the continental slope, but is more frequently found in shallower waters (Hart 1973). Diets consist of a variety of small fishes, crustaceans, polychaetes and molluscs (Hart 1973). The maximum total length is 64 cm (Hart 1973, Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Kells et al. 2016), but typical size is less than 53 cm. Juveniles enter estuaries (Pearson and McNally 2005).

Natural mortality is about 0.2 in the Gulf of Alaska (Turnock et al. 2017). It has been aged to a maximum of 8 years, but likely lives to at least 10 years. Length and age at first maturity are 29 cm and 2 years (Pearson and McNally 2005). When applying the equation recommended by the IUCN Red List methods: 1/adult mortality + age of first reproduction, the generation length is estimated to be about 7 years.
threats: Fishing activity is not expected to be driving population declines approaching levels at which the species would qualify even for Near Threatened status at this time. Anthropogenic activities conducted in nearshore and estuarine waters could negatively impact this species.
population:
This species has a low biomass in the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands according to trawl surveys that have been conducted there since 1982 (Wilderbuer and Nichol 2015). In the Gulf of Alaska, this species is managed as part of the "shallow-water flatfish stock complex", which besides this species, is primarily composed of Alaska Plaice (Pleuronectes quadrituberculatus), English Sole (Parophrys vetulus), Starry Flounder (Platichthys stellatus), Butter Sole (Isopsetta isolepis), Yellowfin Sole (Limanda aspera), Northern Rock Sole (Lepidopsetta polyxystra) and Southern Rock Sole (Lepidopsetta bilineata). According to the most recent stock assessment, overfishing is not occurring and the exploitation rate on this complex is relatively low. According to scientific surveys, biomass of this species in the Gulf of Alaska from 1984 to 2019 fluctuated widely in some years. Biomass peaked in 2007 at 3,168 t, had a secondary peak in 2019 at 3,023 t, and has been increasing since 2015 (Turnock et al. 2017, Bryan 2019).

This species is common and abundant in the Puget Sound of Washington state (Reum and Essington 2011), and off Oregon and central California (Pearson and McNally 2005). It is a relatively minor component of California groundfish demersal trawl fisheries catches (Miller et al. 2014) and is taken elsewhere from Vancouver to central California, but exploitation is relatively low (Pearson and McNally 2005).
range: This species is distributed in the eastern North Pacific from Unalaska Island to Port Heiden in the Bering Sea to the Gulf of Alaska and south to Balboa Pier, California, United States (Hart 1973, Mecklenburg et al. 2002). It has been recorded as far south as La Jolla Shores, California but is not expected to maintain stable populations there (Moore et al. 2011). The depth range is 1-326 metres (Mecklenburg et al. 2002, Kells et al. 2016), but this species most commonly is found shallower than 70 m (Pearson and McNally 2005).
useTrade: This species is a small component of commercial demersal fisheries in U.S. waters and is also taken recreationally. It has a relatively low overall economic value compared with that of other flatfish species (Pearson and McNally 2005).
conservationActions: The subpopulation of this species in waters off the United States is monitored through scientific surveys and annual stock assessments. The U.S. stocks are managed through the Pacific Coast Groundfish Fishery Management Plan, the Bering Sea/Aleutian Islands Groundfish Fishery Management Plan, and the Gulf of Alaska Groundfish Fishery Management Plan. Fishing is regulated through permitting, size limits, daily and total catch limits, seasonal and area fishing closures, gear restrictions, and a trawl catch share program.

rationale: This marine, coastal species is known from the North Pacific, where it occurs from the Bering Sea to Southern California. It is common throughout its range and not targeted by fisheries.  There are no known major threats; therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This marine, demersal species is associated with rocky areas and outcroppings with dense algal coverage, tidepools and the intertidal zone (Fitch and Lavenberg 1975, Pietsch and Orr 2019). Its coloration makes it cryptic, especially among seaweed (Hutchins et al. 2003). This nocturnal species can reach a maximum length of 20 cm and feeds mainly on small crustaceans (Hutchins et al. 2003). In late winter and early spring, females migrate to shallow water during high-tide and spawn, depositing their adhesive, demersal eggs in mussel beds (Matarese et al. 1989). Larvae hatch with an approximate standard length of 0.7 cm and are pelagic until they settle in benthic habitat with a maximum length of about 2.6 cm (Richardson and Washington 1980). It is unknown when transformation occurs, however the largest pelagic specimen reported measured 1.7 cm (Richardson and Washington 1980). Individuals reach maturity at one year of age (Matarese et al. 1989).
threats: There are no known major threats to this species; however, because it deposits eggs in mussel beds, the elimination or reduction of these habitats (by harvesting, pollution, or other stressor) may impact the population (Hutchins et al. 2003).
population: This species is considered common throughout its range; however, it is not very commonly encountered as it is nocturnal and most surveys are conducted during the day when it hides in crevices (Pietsch and Orr 2019, REEF 2020).
range: This species is distributed in the North Pacific Ocean, where it occurs along the coast of North America from the southeastern Bering Sea, the western Gulf of Alaska in the Shumagin Islands, to San Miguel Island, California from the intertidal zone to 110 metres deep (Maslenikov et al. 2013, Pietsch and Orr 2019).
useTrade: This species is popular with night divers and public aquariums and is not taken for any other purpose (Hutchins et al. 2003). Larvae are easily cultured, and this species has been bred successfully in captivity since the mid-1970’s (Hutchins et al. 2003). It is not targeted, but it can be occasionally caught by hook and line (Fitch and Lavenberg 1975) and as bycatch in prawn traps (Favaro et al. 2010).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place; however, it occurs in multiple marine protected areas throughout its range (U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service 2004, NOAA 2006, Dolphin et al. 2010).

rationale: This marine, demersal species is widely distributed from Alaska to southern California, in the eastern North Pacific. It is common and locally abundant, and stocks are considered healthy despite being targeted by recreational and commercial fisheries in parts of its range. There are no known major threats; therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
This species can be found intertidally and subtidally over rocky reefs, kelp beds and eelgrass habitats, typically up to 50 meters deep but sometimes deeper (Cope and MacCall 2005, Berger et al. 2015, Kells et al. 2016).
